review: Thought the scriptwriting was brilliant, but I didn't enjoy the actual sets and scenes so much.

Extraordinarily faithful to the tone and style of the originals, The Force Awakens brings back the Old Trilogy's heart, humor, mystery, and fun. Since it is only the first piece in a new three-part journey it can't help but feel incomplete. But everything that's already there, from the stunning visuals, to the thrilling action sequences, to the charismatic new characters, has reawakened and solidified my love for the series. This film deserves a Best Picture nomination.

Rey, a young smuggler, is thrust into a battle between the First Order and the resistance when she teams up with a storm trooper who suffered a crisis of conscience.The new entry into the Star Wars universe is profoundly derivative, essentially an updated retelling of A New Hope, and while ignoring the backstory about the First Order largely mutes the events of Return of the Jedi, the new characters are interesting enough that J.J. Abrams has successfully made me excited about the new installments, rather than cringing, as I did after The Phantom Menace. It's a fun, popcorn film, returning to its roots, and this isn't all bad, even if it fails to advance the scope of the original films.I especially like Daisy Ridley as Rey. Ridley gives Star Wars a feminist character, one whose hand should never be held and whose life isn't dependent on others, but the film doesn't allow Ridley to explore enough of the character because it withholds so much information in the name of suspense.Also, Star Wars as a series is based on the struggle between good and evil. In the original trilogy, we accepted the empire as evil and the rebellion as good - the bad guys had red light sabers and the good guys had green or blue light sabers. In the second trilogy, George Lucas bungled a political plot, which by necessity forced the film to explore intricacies of good and evil and descent into evil. Obviously that failed. In order to deal with the rise of the First Order, we needed a political plot, but yet the film disavowed itself of this responsibility, and as a result, the film's antagonists are hollow and the series doesn't hold together as a narrative whole. Star Wars has to get better at politics, not just for the sake of Episode VIII but for the continuity of the series as a whole.Overall, I liked this newest film if only because it manages to return the franchise to the rails; now if only Episode VIII can get the train moving again.

JJ Abrams is very good and knowing what his audience wants and giving just that to them. He is not great, however, because he rarely shows us something we didn't know we wanted. This film derives a lot from the first Star Wars, and just goes along as you might expect, yet it is still very enjoyable because it's Star Wars. The old faces were cool to see, and the new ones do very well. As a standalone film there's nothing great about the plot, directing or dialogue, but the hype, nostalgia and sentiment made this a great movie going experience.

Well, I always thought A New Hope was the best Star Wars movie... Episode 7 has kept the style of the original movie, its soundtrack, not just the score - the entire sound scape, but it should have left it at that. What we have feels like a fan remake of the original; re-hashing every plot element, every character, every scene, even ripping off several lines of the dialogue directly. I was half-expecting Rey to do the Obi-Wan sound diversion trick at one point. Alas, the new plot seems like it's in far too much of a rush at times, and thus each re-hashed scene fails to deliver the impact of the original whilst also feeling unoriginal. The characters' journey's don't touch you as much, and there's no strong emotional scenes such as when Luke stood watching the two suns rising over his home world in the first movie. Still, it has a strong female role and it was fun to see the old Star Wars well and truly return to continue the story; hopefully the next movie will do something original and do it well!

It may not be an example of originality (let's face it, this episode is basically a rehash of A New Hope, following to the letter the structure of that movie), but even so it is a wonderful, nostalgic return to the original films while incredibly fresh and thrilling as a follow-up as well.

"The Force Awakens" is a good and enjoyable film with all the excitement of the original, but without the poor script writing. Unfortunately, "The Force Awakens" overuses references to the original film -- meaning that nearly every plot twist is telegraphed almost from the first 20 minutes of the film for anyone who has seen the original. Liked the Death Star in the original? We got it -- but different! Liked the cantina scene in the original? We got it -- but different! Liked Darth Vader in the original? We got it -- but different! Liked the Jawas scavenging droids? We got 'em -- but different! Same goes for the "I am your father" moment, the Luke Skywalker character innately strong with "the Force", the entire plan for attacking the new Death Star, R2-D2, "emperor" communicating only via hologram, and smuggling messages in droids to keep them from the "First Order" (it's the "Empire" -- but different). Heck, nearly the entire original cast and the Millennium Falcon itself make appearances! It's hard to argue that "The Force Awakens" isn't largely a remake of the original, but somehow, it's still effective. It's certainly a galaxy far, far ahead of the previous lame trilogy. Seeing "The Force Awakens" is worth your while, just don't expect any surprises.

I thought this is so over-hyped. I didn't feel that this was a new unique film. There was too much recreation and fan service of the the original film(s) and felt more like a nostalgia film rather than a new film. I wasn't impressed with Kylo Ren. I expected more out of the action sequences. I didn't feel I cared too much for the new characters. There was one emotional scene but other than that I didn't feel this film brought any new exciting things to the table.
That girl doesn't need you to take her hand, she said.
I liked the tall bear-man

J.J. Abrams has no problem awakening the force in Star Wars: The Force Awakens.Spanning more than a couple hours, and while rehashing similar concepts from the past, the film manages to entertain for its entirety. Never dragging too long and never moving too quickly, Star Wars: The Force Awakens providers enough details at all the right times to get its story across.The universe relies heavily on CG; however, the film doesn't look like a CG forest and this is a great thing. The stunning visuals look as real as the characters.There isn't much to say regarding the old timers. They've done it before and they get it done again. Daisy Ridley is an absolute gem addition to the cast, along with John Boyega and Oscar Isaac.Star Wars: The Force Awakens, delivers as expected, laying it all out in a epic universe.
Well they definitely picked the right director to re-ignite this franchise! I loved it! Can't wait for Episode VIII!

May 19,1999 is a day that lives in infamy legions of Star Wars fans. The day hoped died. I remember trying to convince myself that The Phantom Menace was good but a second viewing confirmed my earlier fears. These movies were not going to be the same as the original trilogy, and George Lucas confirmed that with each successive release. I've had debates with teenagers who swear that the prequels are better films. They aren't. This isn't a matter of opinion; this is fact. After Revenge of the Sith was released in 2005, you could sense that Lucas was burned out and had no desire to further awaken the ire of the fandom. Then in 2012 he surprised everyone by selling the Star Wars empire, along with other properties like Indiana Jones, to Disney for four billion dollars. Immediately Disney let it be known that they wanted to get new Star Wars movies into production ASAP. They tapped J.J. Abrams to spearhead the first steps in a new direction. No other movie has felt the weight of hype and expectation like Episode VII: The Force Awakens. Fans don't want to be hurt once more by someone they loved. For millions of fans that grew up on the original trilogy, The Force Awakens will be the Star Wars movie they have long been waiting for. It erases the bad feelings of the prequels and recalibrates the franchise. However, it is also flawed and seems too indebted to nostalgia. It's certainly good but I cannot put away my nagging reservations (far, far less than what I felt with the prequels).Thirty years after the events of Return of the Jedi, the First Order has risen in place of the evil Empire. The First Order is lead by General Hux (Domhnall Gleeson) and aspiring sith lord Kylo Ren (Adam Driver). They're searching for the droid BB-8 and its own, Resistance pilot Poe Dameron (Oscar Isaac). The droid has a map that leads to the whereabouts of the last known Jedi - Luke Skywalker (Mark Hamil). A Stormtrooper who adopts the name of Finn (John Boyega) runs away from his mission and joins forces with Rey (Daisy Ridley), a scavenger waiting for her family to return to her world. The duo finds BB-8 and seeks to return the droid to the Resistance. They run into Han Solo (Harrison Ford) and Chewbacca (Peter Mayhew) and a few other familiar faces on their journey to the Resistance base and to escape the reach of the First Order. Abrams has captured the essential magic of what made the original trilogy so enjoyable and timeless. The prequels carried the burden of setting up characters we had come to love, and so as we watched younger versions of them or characters integral to their development, it was hard to ignore just how little we cared. It didn't feel like Lucas himself cared that much, more content to direct his green screens than his actors. The special effects had improved but for much of the three prequels it felt like watching disinterested actors recite poorly written lines while they run around fake environments with no semblance of reality. The details that Lucas emphasized were ones that were unnecessary, like treaties and trade tariffs and the notorious midichlorians, which made the force into a blood disorder. The prequels harmed the legacy of the franchise. It takes only seconds for you to feel like you're in better hands when you read the opening text crawl. No trade disputes. No galactic senate. It sets up its central chase and the important players in three brief paragraphs. And then we're off and the movie rarely lets up.We pass the torch to a new generation of characters and it's here that Force Awakens is able to leave the large shadow of the original trilogy. The characters are great. Finn gives the viewer an entry point into a world we've never explored onscreen in any real depth, the life of a Stormtrooper, the cannon fodder of the series. He has moral crises and goes AWOL from the duties he has been raised to do. He doesn't want to be a mindless killing-machine and forges his own destiny. Watching him embrace a sense of individuality is entertaining. He's charming and excitable but also fearful of what may catch up to him. Then there's the hero's journey with Rey, a plucky heroine who comes of age over the course of the movie's 135 minutes. Ridley has the presence and poise reminiscent of Keira Knightley, and the screen just adores her. It also helps win her character is easy to root for. Boyega (Attack the Block) and Ridley are terrific and even better paired together. They have a great chemistry and much of the humor is born from the characters rather than lame visual gags like in the prequels. It's fun to hear characters verbally spar with actual good dialogue. Driver was the first actor hired and it's easy to see why. If you've been watching the man on HBO's Girls, you'll know that he has a magnetic presence that separates him from the herd. He plays a villain that so badly wants to follow in Vader's footsteps but the thing that holds him back is the "temptation of the light." In one moment, a badass and imposing villain with super force powers had now also become an interesting character wrestling with his influences. Isaac (Ex Machina) is suave and cocksure as an ace pilot. His affection for the other characters is touching, particularly the robot BB-8. This little guy is going to be the toy that every child on Earth demands for the holidays. BB-8 is adorable from its first moment on screen and made me forget about R2D2. The big worry with Force Awakens was that its new characters would be compelling on their own. After one movie I'm looking forward to more adventures with the new kids on the block. Abrams has restored the sense of fun and awe that resonated from the original trilogy and the biggest compliment is that Episode VII feels like a Star Wars movie (more on which below). The action sequences are quick and filled with great visuals and shot arrangements. For those worried about Abrams' penchant for lens flairs in the Stark Trek reboots, they are completely absent in Force Awakens (Fun fact: for Star Trek Into Darkness, computer effects had to go in and take out lens flairs because Abrams later admitted he had gone a bit overboard). There are some beautifully orchestrated shots and sequences all around here. The first 40-minutes is the best part of the movie, before the older stars come back for their due. The rest of the film is enjoyable, no doubt, but I was more pleased with the original material. The technical expertise has never been higher. Like Mad Max: Fury Road, there's a joy with watching characters interact with a real world of practical effects. Watching the characters run around real environments and real sets rather than immense green screens just makes it feel more real and vital. I enjoyed how worn and weathered the technology in this world comes across. The special effects are judiciously utilized and are excellent as anticipated. It's easy to sense the reverence that Abrams and others have for the series as well as their determination to not repeat the mistakes of the prequels. The first mission for Episode VII is to reset the course, to wash away the bad taste of the prequels that haunt many. Abrams has gone back to what works with these movies and recreated the playbook. It's a movie that will satisfy the hardcore fans and reawaken their love for the series. And yet it almost feels like Force Awakens is a swing too far in the other direction, an overcorrection to the prequels that turns a reboot into a loving homage that approaches facsimile. I was amazed at just how closely Episode VII follows the plot beats of A New Hope (mild spoilers to follow - for real, if you don't want to be spoiled in the slightest, and I'm no monster and won't dare include anything that would substantially deter your viewing, skip to the spoiler safe area). Here goes: once again we start with an escape from an evil starfleet ship, only to land on a desert planet. The hunt is for a droid with valuable information. Our dispirit band of characters collect on the desert planet and flee, only to be eventually pulled back to the evil base of operations, which once again is a giant floating orb that specializes in planet destruction and this orb seems to have the same pesky design flaw that plagued Death Star 1.0 and 2.0. How does this one design flaw still exist? Are there not backups and redundancies? It would be like Titanic 3.0 going down by hitting another iceberg. There are more parallels involving the characters and personal revelations that mirror Episode IV but I won't go into detail on those (end of spoilers). Suffice to say, it felt like I was watching a cover act remind me how much I enjoyed the first Star Wars release. Perhaps Abrams felt his rabid audience needed to go backwards before going forward, pay homage to what had been built by practically reliving its plot in a galaxy not so long ago as it once was (it still is likely the same distance: far far away). It's a movie that cannot escape the nostalgia of its predecessors, and so it indulges it instead. In deferring to fan demands, Force Awakens has moments that waver into the dangerous territory of fan service. This will harm its overall staying power once the glow wears off from audiences overcome with fan relief. Thankfully, the new main characters are compelling and I'll be happy to follow their continuing adventures with Episodes VIII and IX and who knows. Abrams and company have set up the next generation of fan favorites that have the chance to grow out of the sizeable shadow of the original cast. However, not all elements are given that same nurturing care. The Force Awakens is so briskly paced that it rarely has time to establish the new history of its universe. We get character relationships and reunions but I couldn't help but feel that the larger plot they inhabited felt rushed. The First Order seems rather vague and their rise to power needed at least some explanation. Instead we're dropped right into a timeline with an Empire knockoff. It's just easy fascism placeholder. Why are the Republic and the Resistance two separate entities? The villains with the exception of Kylo Ren are pretty one-note and also callbacks to the bad guy types from Episode IV. Captain Phasma (Gwendoline Christie) is in the movie for a lousy three minutes. I'm also not a fan of either of the two motion-capture performances from Oscar-winner Lupita Nyong'o (12 Years a Slave) and mo-cap pioneer Andy Serkis (Rise of the Planet of the Apes). I hated Nyong'o's character and her performance. The character design for both of those creatures is rather weak and weirdly unimaginative. There's also a habit of characters being naturals at things that would ordinarily require expertise. The worlds we visit and the creatures we encounter are all a bit too similar to earlier sources and distinctly unmemorable. We don't learn much via our locations and geography and so it feels a tad interchangeable and meaningless, which is a shame. The Force Awakens is a mostly exciting return to the rich world of Star Wars with characters we care about, old and new, lively action that feels substantial and real, and a sense of fun that isn't at the expense of your full brainpower. Abrams had two missions: 1) eliminate the disappointment over the prequels, and 2) set up new characters and stories for future installments. Both have been accomplished. Abrams may have been the perfect candidate to restart the Star Wars series as he has a history of making films as loving homage to his cinematic influences. Super 8 was Abrams' homage to Spielberg and Episode VII is very much homage to Episode IV. The well-trod story allows for the series to reset comfortably while setting up its new characters to take a greater storytelling burden from here on out. I hope future installments give us more development to make the worlds and the history matter just as much as Rey, Finn, Kylo, Poe, and BB-8. This may be an unpopular opinion but I feel that Abrams' rollicking 2009 Star Trek reboot is a better Star Wars movie than The Force Awakens. Abrams and company has proven you can make a new and good Star Wars movie. Now my own new hope is that writer/director Rian Johnson will be able to steer the franchise into a fresher direction with Episode VIII. In the meantime, fans can sleep well once again.Nate's Grade: B+

While a lack of originality and creativity is a little disappointing, J.J. Abrams brings Star Wars bursting back with great new characters and a renewed sense of fun. This feels like the original trilogy, which is both good because it feels like it belongs and bad because they literally rehashed most of the plot points from the original trilogy. That would be my biggest complaint. It was exciting to reunite with the original cast and also see how they will transition to new characters. I am excited about the prospects of where they are going to take this story now that the setup is out of the way. It wasn't perfect, but it was a nice start to a new trilogy. It's great having Star Wars back.

"Star Wars" is back! Walking out of the theatre, there really is not much else to say until you give it quite a bit of time to sink in. As a starting point for these new characters entering this universe, I really do not believe (give the story at hand) that it could have been handled any better than it was. Beginning right off the bat with fresh faces and hilarious comedy, we were given a glimpse at what is to come in this new trilogy. "Star Wars: The Force Awakens" follows Rey, as she uncovers a droid owned by Poe Dameron, an X-Wing pilot whom he forms a bond will ally Finn. These three catalysts of this new trilogy are all incredible characters and I cannot wait to see where their adventures lead. Kylo Ren is amazing as the new focus, even though there is much more to the dark side this time around. With more character depth than I was expecting, this film soars on multiple levels. If I had to complain about one aspect, it would be that when familiar elements come into play, calling out moments from the past or nearly copying them, it felt a little risky; However, they make everything work and I bought into everything. Once you can get past that this film is just a starting point and of course there will be similarities, then you will have an experience at the movies unlike anything in years. "Star Wars: The Force Awakens" is Hollywood at it's absolute best and J.J. Abrams has definitely brought us back into a Galaxy Far, Far Away, in more ways we could have ever asked for. I can praise the hell out of this film all day, because that is just what this film is. A crowd pleaser all around, it welcomes newcomers with it's fresh characters, and it will blow minds of the die hard fans. It really is everything fans have been asking for. There are so many spoilers to be said by talking about the plot, so I will simply say this... This film does not disappoint. In the end, "Star Wars: The Force Awakens" is amazing entertainment, and even though things may feel familiar at times, there is no denying the sheer greatness that this film truly is. Amazing comeback! Big screen filmmaking at it's finest!

A masterful blend of the old generation and the new, Star Wars: The Force Awakens brings the franchise back to its full, impeccable form. The seventh installment's nostalgic direction, colorful characters (old and new) well-rounded story and adventurous sequences is something for fans of young and old to enjoy and crave more of as it launches a new wave of its space-operatic-narrative. 4.5/5

Star Wars Episode VII: The Force Awakens is the continuation of the saga started by George Lucas almost forty years ago. Since then the franchise has grown beyond its beginning to crave itself out a huge place in popular culture not only in the United states, but across the globe. There have been dark times for this franchise when it has lost its way (Episodes I, II, and III), but it has continued to thrive with three generations. The Force Awakens signals the start of not only a new trilogy, but new creative forces and new ownership of the Star Wars universe. The film follows a trio of new characters Poe Dameron, Finn, and Rey (Oscar Isaac, John Boyega, and Daisy Ridley) each coming from a different background, yet they all find themselves on the same quest. Along the way they encounter heroes from the previous films such as Han Solo (Harrison Ford), Leia Organa (Carrie Fisher), and Chewbacca (Peter Mayhew) as they come in conflict with The First Order, a resurgence of the ideals of the Galactic Empire. Led by the Force wielding Kylo Ren (Adam Driver) they continue terrorizing the galaxy in that classic Imperial way. There are many winks and nods throughout the film that doesn't seem like blatant fan service except at a few points in the film. The Force Awakens is the film that we had hoped the prequels would be. The audience genuinely cares about the new characters as opposed to Episodes I, II, and III. People in this film are not as wooden as they were in those films and there are many contribution factors that could affect that fact. Poor acting, poor writing, performing in front of nothing but a green screen probably all contributed to that fact. This film harkens back to nonstop action and adventure that doesn't turn down at all during its 2 hour and 15 minute running time. The story is a great continuation of Star Wars lore that develops patterns in the story, just like human history. We all keep making the same mistakes over and over again. The question is did we learn from them? That will be seen as this trilogy plays out.
I'll let the hype die down and then rate again. Great movie.-mirror-music
When an Irish audience applauds before, during and after a movie, you know it's something special.

Me and my 8 year old son enjoyed it and it was great to re-live the way I felt when I first watched A New Hope. The story line however is a re-telling of the originals in many ways and the ending felt like it had been bolted on in the 11th hour.

The 4th best Star Wars movie. Far superior to the prequels. This one has actors. And a script. It also seems to be building towards something. Whereas the original trilogy was figured out as they went. Good new characters. Returning favorites used well. It does have that modern day pacing though, which is almost breakneck. It's nice to slow down and breathe sometimes. Extra half star for the cliffhanger ending, making me more excited for episode 8 than I was for episode 7
I was enamored by the action and pure entertainment value, though I can't help but feel the sole purpose of this movie is to setup a whole new franchise of movies, and for that I'm offended.

Everyone likes to say they saw this movie when it was called 'A New Hope'. Well, they have a valid argument as there were many similarities, but my argument is this - "Who cares? 'A New Hope' was damn good and so is this."

Sorry to say, I found the movie to be a bit lacking. Still a good movie, but in my opinion it was barely better than Jedi (thanks to the stupid Ewoks) and not as good as Sith (fight scenes were the tie breaker for Sith). That puts it #4 on my list of all Star Wars Movies.There are a lot of small issues such as how adept new users can be with, well everything. However of these minor issues, the biggest issue was with the light saber. Apparently training isn't necessary. With that said, instead of listing the remainder of my minor issues item by item, I'm just going to touch on my two biggest irreconcilable issues. First and biggest of my issues is that in their attempt to go back to the "winning formula," they "borrowed" too much from previous movies. There's good familiarity that makes you feel warm and fuzzy. Then there's been there done that, got the t-shirt familiarity that makes your commitment to the franchise feel insulted. If you've seen all the movies, you know what I'm talking about.**SPOILER ALERT**Second major issue was how easy a storm trooper could just break away from the First Order during his very first battle after being taken as a child, brainwashed, and reprogrammed. Some would argue that scene somehow humanizes the Stormtroopers. OK let's go with that. So you are asking the audience to then believe that this human character, who drank the kool-aid his whole life, but had an epiphany after seeing one of his brothers in arms killed, then had no problem killing so many of them moving forward? #nofriendsgrowingup. Beyond that, the rebels just welcomed him in without question or suspicion? #nospiesinspace.Sorry JJ Abrams, I am disappointed. It's sad that I could be disappointed in a good movie. But you had a great franchise, and a great track record, so yeah, a good movie is a disappointment. You did such a masterful job with the revisioning of the Star Trek franchise that maybe I was expecting too much. I will submit that I'm as much of a Star Wars fan as I am a Star Trek fan so there is no bias here. My litmus test is simply that if I'm not ready to leave the theater and immediately get back in line for a movie from the biggest franchise in history, you have failed sir.
Lots of fun. What I was expecting

Star Wars Episode 8 brings back the awe and wonderment that every Star Wars lover went through when they first experienced the movies. Kylo Ren, although perceived as deadly, turns out to be a character with great depth and surprising explanation to his actions. The dynamic between Po and Finn is electric, providing a familiar taste like Han and Lando in the prequels. Rey's story is unfinished and thrilling, a rags to riches story actually worth watching. I would definitely recommend.
It was a great movie

"Star Wars Episode VII: The Force Awakens (2015)" is about Rey (Daisy Ridley), a poor hard-working young woman on planet Jakku, who is doing what she can just to get her next meal. Her life changes when she encounters a droid, a secret Storm Trooper, and a broken-down hunk of metal that is the Millennium Falcon.Rey lives on a dangerous planet, and in a dangerous universe, a universe where the new dominant power is not a force for good but a force for evil. It is called the First Order, and it is the spiritual and political successor to the Galactic Empire. It is headed up by a mysterious figure named Kylo Ren (Adam Driver), who is the primary agent of an even more mysterious figure who calls himself Supreme Leader Snoke (Andy Serkis).The droid she encounters has within it a secret message for Luke Skywalker (Mark Hamill), the Rebel alliance's "only hope" to save the galaxy. Rey makes it her mission to get this secret message to Skywalker, who has been missing since the rise of the First Order.This film is almost as great as "Empire Strikes Back" (1980), and yet still crucially depends on that film and the original trilogy for its understanding. Nevertheless, a newcomer to the franchise will no doubt enjoy this film, which hopefully is the inauguration of a whole new beautiful trilogy.
although you have seen this movie before you can't help but love it

I loved it. What I loved best was the performances by Daisy Ridley and John Boyega.
Great movie although it was just a copy of other Star Wars movies.

A fun ride but not a lot of original elements.

"Star Wars Episode VII: The Force Awakens review The Good, The Bad, & (in some cases) The Greedy" IntroductionIt's here! Finally! Star Wars: Episode VII. 32 years after the release of Return of The Jedi, and 10 and a half years after the release of Revenge of The Sith. It's next to impossible to be excited for this release, or go to the theater without having any sort of expectation. For the last year, I've ignored all rumors surrounding The Force Awakens. I only pay attention to trailers, posters, and TV spots which have all been promising. JJ Abrams takes over the director's chair, promising classic return and old school style approach to making Episode VII. Also including some original cast members, writers, and crew members. Less use of heavy CGI, and more focus on using practical effects, costumes, makeup, models, and real sets. Before even being released, The Force Awakens was already a breath of fresh air to the Star Wars series, which has unfortunately fallen victim to its prequel trilogy amongst most fans and audiences. However, The Force Awakens comes with a lot of nit picking, but the fact that you have to nit pick the film says it's a really good film. Really good!The Force Awakens StorylineThe Force Awakens takes place 29 years after the fall of Galactic Empire. The film opens with a new evil force in place of the fallen Empire, called The First Order. Led under the guidance of the evil Kylo Ren, a fallen Jedi apprentice who desires to be Darth Vader. The First Order and Kylo Ren are under the leadership of a new mystery Supreme Leader by the name of Snoke, who wants the Jedi destroyed for good. In light of everything Luke Skywalker, the last of the Jedi, has gone into hiding, leaving Kylo Ren in desperate search for the map pieces that lead to Skywalker's location and ultimate demise. Also searching for Skywalker is the Resistance. A Republic military group deep in the fight against The First Order, and led by General Leia Organa. The missing map piece is in the care of a droid, BB-8, on the desert planet of Jakku. He's rescued by Rey, a scavenger girl who was abandoned on Jakku over 20 years ago. She remains hopeful that her family will return for her one day. Rey and BB-8 cross paths with Finn, a young ex-Stormtrooper who abandoned The First Order and their cause. Finn agrees to help Rey return BB-8 to The Resistance, and to make sure the map to Skywalker doesn't fall in the hands of Kylo Ren. However, in the shadows of the galaxy The First Order have completed their new ice planet star base called Starkiller. A planet like Death Star with the capability to drain the power of near by stars. Thus using that energy to destroy multiple planets with one single strike. Along Rey and Finn's journey they receive help from Poe Dameron, the best fighter pilot in the Resistance, as well as Han Solo, Chewbacca, Leia, and many other new and old familiar faces. On their journey to not only finding Skywalker but also stopping The First Order, Throughout the course of Rey's journey to delivering BB-8 safely to the Resistant she discovers a hidden power in her. The Force. Rey is strong with the Force, but this power and her family past remains a mystery best saved for Episode VIII. The Force Awakens, as said by a very old familiar voice in the film (Obi-Wan), is Rey's first steps with letting the Force in. The Pros The Force Awakens comes at you bursting with Star Wars excitement and thrills. JJ Abrams stood his ground strong from day one of Disney and LucasFilm hiring him to take on the great challenge of being the film's director. Disney originally slated Force Awakens for a May 2015 release, giving Abrams only a year and a half to complete a script, cast new actors, find locations, build sets, shoot, post-production effects, editing, scoring. Abrams demanded an extra year from Disney to avoid a rush production and to ensure a spectacular new chapter. Disney gave him 7 extra months, which was the absolute right decision. Can you image what Episode VII would've looked like if it had been released back in May? A mess! In the wake of Return of The Jedi's conclusion, we lose some major players of Star Wars, mainly Darth Vader, Darth Sidious (The Emperor), and Yoda. The Force Awakens does welcome back old familiar names and faces, Han, Luke, Leia, Chewie, Threepio, R2, even Admiral Ackbar! The real joy of Episode VII is in the enjoyment of the new additions. Rey, Finn, Poe, Kylo Ren, Snoke BB-8. The new characters of The Force Awakens are a key element to the start of this new Star Wars trilogy, which was missing in Episodes I-III. Not to say I did not like Ewan McGregor or Liam Neeson or Natalie Portman. Unknown to most audiences who are too quick to highlight these A-list actors with their acting in the prequels with, "They were so wooden. Lacked depth. Their scenes were too one dimension". Yeah, these poor actors were A) Not allowed to see the script until the day of the shootB) Were only allowed to access to the scene they would be shooting, not the complete scriptC) Were only allowed 3 takes for each scene. D) People seem to forget. Star Wars is a space opera. AKA, a soap opera set in space with loads of action! Soap operas are cheesy, campy, and filled with terrible acting. These limitations in the production of the prequels were to avoid crazy fans leaking out details about the films. However, The Force Awakens has more mystery and sets up for more future surprises the previous 6 films combined! I'm sure the actors of The Force Awakens had some restrictions with access and details to the plans of the new trilogy, but their performances are good. Really good! In fact, it's the best performances Star Wars has ever had! Believable, genuine, character depth, and yet there is still a touch of the old school space opera acting we grew up watching. However, despite all the security measures taken in production, I expect Abrams to allow his actors more scene takes and more script time. Every performance looks, sounds, and feels like time and thought was carefully executed. One of the biggest surprises in The Force Awakens comes from the character side of BB-8. Yes, a droid, which has also been a major marketing symbol for the film. It's hard to even think of replacing C-3PO and R2-D2, let alone have one single smaller droid stand in for them. BB-8 is not only a great addition to the Star Wars saga, but he is a wonderful character who alone can re-create the same charm C3-PO and R2-D2 displayed in the deserts of Tatoonie in A New Hope. The promise return of practical model effects, make-up, alien costumes, and real sets rather than just all out green screen with CGI left and right in The Force Awakens was the absolute right decision and best way to get fans back on board with continuing the Star Wars saga. Abrams admits to being a long-time fan of Star Wars, and his execution to story, characters, and details proves his childhood love. The Cons Which Should Never Have BeenThe Force Awakens is bursting with excitement, thrills, and great fun. It's a worthy new installment into the Star Wars film franchise. Was I completely satisfied with the film? No. The problem lies in the bar level The Force Awakens has long been aiming for. The target is to be on the same level of greatness as A New Hope and The Empire Strikes Back. The prequels never had this in mind which made them easy for me to come out of the theater saying, "That was great, I loved it so much!" The Force Awakens has had it sights on being a return to a similar level of greatness, which has made A New Hope and The Empire Strikes Back timeless, unlike the prequel and even Return of The Jedi. However, whenever a film aims to be great, you find yourself noticing every little detail and nit picking. This is not nit picking such as, "Why did they make Snoke CGI, he should've been more realistic looking" If your critique of the film is picking at something like this, then your not standing back and looking at the whole picture here. I have little nit picks, but also some that may end up being greater than just a little nit pick.1. Slightly disappointing editing which drops the Star Wars scope 2. So many unanswered questions & the Disney problem3. Leave the damn mask on!4. The musical score lacking the Star Wars magicEditing Leaves Out Star Wars ScopeMany will argue that The Force Awakens has a thin plot, yes but so does A New Hope. Or that The Force Awakens also has a lot of unanswered questions, true but so did A New Hope. Do you think anyone in 1977 knew what the hell the Clone Wars were? Most of the answers to The Force Awakens will come in Episode VIII and IX. My biggest dissatisfaction comes from the film's editing and the scope of the film, something that should've never been a problem. JJ Abrams and his team have come through on their word of using practical effects and going back to the elements which made Star Wars so classic, but why was The Force Awakens not fully edited to the scope of Star Wars? I'll be the first to admit this, but I preferred so many of the shots in the trailers to the ones used in the theatrical cut. Trailer 1 - the beautiful shot of the 3 X-Wings flying across the water. Trailer 2 - the wide shot of the Tie Fighter tied up in the Star Destroyer hanger while flying around and blasting Stormtroopers, one trooper even gets tossed into the air. Key shots like these completely sold me on the studio's promise to film Force Awakens in the same scope as the original trilogy. They looked and felt like classic Star Wars and old school Lucas filmmaking of the 70s and 80s. The decision to go with lesser impressive angles and shots was not only a distraction, but also slightly upsetting. I am not saying I did not find any joy or magic in these scenes, I still found myself smiling from the visual thrills. However, I would be lying if I said that I was satisfied with the scope, editing, and pace of each flight action sequence. There are too many action sequences in which shots jump too quickly without giving the audience time to process the grand imaginary. The already fast pace dogfight battles were too rushed. The shots of the Falcon being chased by Tie Fighters on Jakku were paced perfectly in the trailers. TRAILER 1, the first time we got to the see the Millennium Falcon dodges out across the sky then dips down to avoid a pair of in-coming Tie Fighters. The exact same sequence was in the final cut, but the frame rate was sped up greatly in the film making it difficult to even know what was going on. TRAILER 2, the shot of the Falcon flying inside the engines of the crashed Executor Star Destroyer was trimmed down a few frames making it a quick flash of the Falcon followed with immediate explosions, rather than cut to a single shot looking down the long engine shaft with the rear of the Falcon flying out while laser blasts from the pursuing Tie Fighter hit parts of the old ship creating head-on explosions. Why??? The editing of the dogfighting scenes was not edited with the scope of original Star Wars trilogy in mind. The trailers clearly showed us months, even a year ago, these spectacular widescreen scope shots done for the film, only to be thrown onto the cutting room floor for less impression replacement shots. In the final film, early scenes on Jakku had the scope I'm referring to. However, the dogfighting action scenes suffered tremendously from using more quick cuts, sped up frames, and shots which would rather put us as close as humanly possible rather than sit back and watch in awe all the visual splendor happening all across the screen in one grand sensational shot. This is not a small nit pick, this one is crucial, because it makes the film feel less like Star Wars. The same can be said about seeing the film in 3D. The 3D for The Force Awakens is good, but having the 3D makes the film feel less like Star Wars and more like Iron Man. Plus, add in the editing changes of speeding up frames and making cuts quicker than they originally were make watching The Force Awakens trickier to watch in 3D. You can't easily sit in the movie theater and process what it is your seeing in the film's action scenes.  Another technical flaw in the film, which was explained to me before my second viewing of the film comes in the director of photography (DP)/cinematography department. For the scenes inside the space station Starkiller, the film's DP crafted and used a special lens filter to help make give the space station a similar gritty, steel, and hazy gray look to the space station environment. However, because of DP's self-satisfaction with the final result of those scenes, he applied the same filter to the scenes with The Resistance. The result had many of these scenes looking out of focus and fuzzy. The biggest stand out involved Leia being completely out of focus when she approaches Han to talk about his involvement in the assault on Starkiller. Unprofessional. Completely unprofessional. The DP used filters designed for a completely different location involving the film's villains, and decided to use for something completely opposite in the film. Was there no testing prior to shooting dates to see if this would work? Rather than assuming everything be great looking in the end? I have to be upset with this, because the cinematography's job is highly critical. Why do you think Scotland looked so stunning in Skyfall? Why do you think Hoth looked so cold and desolated in Empire Strikes Back? For the amount of money a DP would make on Episode VII, and trust me it's an insane amount, this was not a professional grade A job. So Many Unanswered QuestionsThe Force Awakens does have a lot of unanswered questions. As it should have, but there comes a point when around every corner of the film is yet another unanswered question.How and why was The First Order able to achieve and pick up were the Empire left off? (This question kills me) Can the giant Starkiller planet actually move? After it drains up the power of all nearby stars can it travel to a new location? It's a planet, how can it travel? If it can't move, how is it able to re-locate to other stars once it drains up all the nearby stars? How was The First Order established? When did The First Order rise into power?Why are they supported in the galaxy when they directly stand on the same practices as the Old Galactic Empire?Who started The Resistance? Is the Republic without an army or is The Resistance their army? The Rebel Alliance was started by a band of militia style fighters and those committed to the Old Republic, easily explained in A New Hope, not so well in The Force Awakens. Why did Han leave Leia and the Resistance? I assume it was because of Kylo Ren? For Han to abandoned everything when the conflict involves him seems very unlike Han Solo. The film made it seem like there was another reason for him leaving. How did Supreme Leader Snoke come into power? Who is he really?How was Kylo Ren able to be seduced to the Dark Side by Snoke while being trained by Luke Skywalker. Did Kylo and his Knights of Ren kill other Jedi Knights?Darth Vader was the evil Sith Lord who redeemed himself by saving the Jedi and destroying the Sith Emperor, so why does Kylo Ren want to follow in the footsteps of Vader so bad?Is Captain Phasma important? Why was she only in the film for about 5 minutes? Maz is an old friend of Han Solo, but how and from when? One line of dialogue would've solved this.How was Maz able to retrieve Anakin and Luke's lightsaber, which fell from Cloud City? I loved that Maz acknowledged that the answer to the saber's discovery will be saved for later. Is Rey related to Obi-Wan or is she a Skywalker?Say what you want about the prequels, but the prequels properly set up the birth of the Empire. The Sith tricked the Republic into having a Galactic Empire, by using pawning the Trade Federation into a dispute with the Republic over the layout trade in the galaxy which led to war and their formation of the Separatists droid army which led to the great Clone Wars. The Force Awakens does more than slightly ignore, the film does very little to explain how we've arrived to the point in the saga's timeline. 29 years after the events of Return of The Jedi is a pretty big gap to cover, and to not explain anything and skip over 29 years to pick up Episode VII here is unfortunate. I'm all for mystery and letting things go unsolved until the following Episodes. However, there comes a point where I should not have a pile of bothering questions while watching the film, take for example the new Starkiller planet base. I like Starkiller, but while it's bigger than the previous two Death Stars it's place in Episode VII is minimal and does not give it the impact or nearly as much dread as compared to the first two Death Stars. Both previous Death Stars were mobile space stations which could travel to a near by planet and destroy it with the station's core firepower. Were over halfway through the film and within 10-15 minutes of the climatic finale assault by the time we fully see Starkiller and its full power potential. And as I said before, can the giant Starkiller move? This is question I should not have to ask, which bugs me to death! After Starkiller drains up the power of all nearby stars can it travel to a new location? It's an ice planet converted into a space station, so does it have the ability to travel? If Starkiller can travel, we never hear this mentioned or see this happen. If Starkiller is not able to travel, its pointless once all the nearby stars have been drained. Another possible reason for the massive pile of unanswered questions, and probably the main reason why is Disney's greed. Before The Force Awakens was released Disney announced their intentions to make Star Wars the first ever forever franchise. Sounds awesome! Until you hear what that entails. Disney plans to release a new Star Wars movie every year. Whether it is another spin off film or another official Episode in the Star War cannon. You would think I would as excited as a kid on Christmas morning upon hearing this. I wasn't. In fact I was disgusted. In the past, the time span of the original trilogy and the prequel trilogy was a new Episode every three years until the trilogy was done. Disney plans to release a new Episode of this trilogy/saga every two years with spin off films in between. The marketing for The Force Awakens was the biggest movie marketing ever. There was not a single place you can be without seeing something Star Wars related. TV, radio ads, Malls, grocery stores, department stores, billboards, pet stores, everywhere! It got to a point where I just wanted the film to be released so things would calm down. I was finding myself a little tired of being a fan. A Star Wars movie every year! I don't think I can take this every year. Disney does the same with Marvel films, and I've been sick of those for the last two and a half years. Disney will do to Star Wars what George Lucas never did. Disney may end up killing Star Wars not just for me, but also for everyone. Leave The Damn Mask On!With the redeeming death of Darth Vader in Return of The Jedi we lose one of the greatest villains of all-time. That's a lot to live up to. Enter Kylo Ren a mystery-masked villain of The First Order with Jedi-like training and strong training with the Force. Kylo is the body and fighting skills of Darth Maul with the mask, voice, and temper of Darth Vader. Midway through the film it is revealed that Kylo Ren is the son of Han Solo, trained by Luke Skywalker, turned to the Dark Side by the mysterious Supreme Leader Snoke, and desires to follow in the footsteps of his grandfather Darth Vader. Why follow is evil grandfather when he actually redeems himself by destroying the Sith Lord/Emperor and saving the galaxy? No clue! However, Kylo Ren is a pretty badass villain. His dark shadow of mystery and anger is intension and fun to have back in Star Wars. However, Kylo Ren removes his mask, twice in the film. The second time he removes the mask is 100% fitting. The scene has him and Han Solo, face-to-face, father and son. The removal of Kylo's mask to reveal is undamaged young adult face would've bettered this scene if he had not removed it earlier. During an interrogation scene between Kylo Ren and Rey, he removes the mask. No! No, No, No! The minute the mask comes off and his face is revealed, Kylo Ren is less of a villain. Which makes perfect sense when he displays his struggle to his father. However, having him remove his mask makes him a wild card young adult playing dress up and trying to be something he's not. What if Darth Vader revealed his Anakin face in The Empire Strikes Back? The Dark Side has taken him, and Anakin Skywalker is lost. He would be less Vader. Once he takes the mask off in Return of the Jedi to be face-to-face, father and son with Luke, he's no longer Darth Vader he's Anakin Skywalker once again. The decision to have Kylo Ren remove his mask a few scenes early when it wasn't critical was wrong, very wrong.The Hardest Comment to MakeOne of the biggest problems I have with The Force Awakens is one I never thought in a million years I would be down on. John Williams' is the simply the best, I love everything this man does. Even his scores for films like Always and 1941. I hate to admit this was even a problem, but it was. The score for The Force Awakens is missing the thrill, the excitement, the joy, the triumph, but most importantly the magic heard in every prior Star Wars score. Not saying the score here is not good at all. It's a good and solid score for an action adventure, but this is Star Wars Episode VII and it's missing all the wonder and triumph of the epic space adventure. The score is more suited for a series like Indiana Jones, or a film like Hook. The key musical factors missing are themes and dominating action music. Don't freak out, the music has the classic Star Wars theme, the Force theme, Han and Leia love theme, but the original material here is a little flat. Take Episode I, you have Duel of Fates, Anakin's theme, the Droid Invasion March, Jar-Jar's theme. Episode III, you have General Grievous theme, Battle of Heroes, Anakin's Seduction and Betrayal. The Empire Strikes Back, you have the Imperial March, Han and Leia's love theme, Yoda's theme, Cloud City's theme. With The Force Awakens you have Rey's theme, the Resistance March, maybe possibly a theme for Snoke, and this is pretty much it. No Kylo Ren theme, no First Order theme, no themes for Finn, Poe, Maz, or even BB-8! In every Star Wars film the score has been fantastic in every scene, with new original material in each Episode to add a great finishing shine to the visuals. This time around the score is not very memorable. The music sinks in without jumping out at the audience, unless a classis theme suddenly comes up. The score often carries a repetitive non-pulse feel from scene to scene. If you listen carefully the music is different throughout the scenes, but it does not sound any different. In other words the score does not aid in telling the story at key times. In every previous Star Wars Episode you could listen to the soundtrack and knew without seeing the film what kind of action was happening, or what the characters were feeling. Duel of The Fates - a grand lightsaber battle. Anakin's Betrayal - the destruction of the Jedi.Anakin's Dark Deeds - the complete fall of Skywalker into the power of the Sith. The Pit of Carkoon - feelings of intensity for our captured heroes until they break free and Luke unleashes his Jedi training for the heroic rescue. The Force Awakens' key action scene is the Millennium Falcon's chase on Jakku, which returns us to the old gunner nest of the Falcon from A New Hope, as well as the classic feel of the asteroid chase in Empire Strikes Back, and yet the music has none of that sensational thrill to light up the screen with the sound of adventure. At the very least someone should've added a nod to The Asteroid Field track as the Falcon races through the wreckage of the upside down Executive Star Destroyer. No Star Wars film would be complete without a climatic lightsaber battle, and The Force Awakens does have a solid saber duel. However, the music playing with the duel goes unnoticed. Williams has always scored big with creating a grand lightsaber duel music track. Episode I - Duel of The FatesEpisode III - Battle of The HeroesEpisode V - The Clash of LightsabersEpisode VI - Vader and Luke's Final Fight (track "The Battle of Endor II") For the climatic lightsaber duel in The Force Awakens between Kylo Ren, Finn, and Rey the music on the soundtrack comes and goes without the listener even realizing what they just heard was a duel. This was the first time I walked out of the theater after seeing a new Star Wars film and had no idea what the music was during a fight scene. John Williams has always been brilliant and consistent with his scores. The first act of Force Awakens has a solid score, with the exception of the Falcon's chase on Jakku, but the score for the last half of the film becomes almost completely forgettable. What happened with The Force Awakens? Was it his old age? Is Williams tried of doing these scores? I don't believe it to be any of these. What was missing was his collaboration with George Lucas. Yes! Lucas and Williams have collaborated on the musical score for all 6 previous Star Wars films. The Force Awakens was scored without Lucas' involvement. Which not only greatly shows, but also adds something greatly disappointing to George Lucas not being involved anymore. Some magic has gone missing already in Star Wars. The music of Star Wars has always been a factor. Whether the film was good or bad, the music was always masterful! The score for Episode VII is the weakest of all 7 films, and makes viewing The Force Awakens feel less Star Wars.  ConclusionFor better or worse I have a love/dislike for The Force Awakens. So many of the promising shots I saw in the trailers were substituted with lesser impacting shots, the film presents too many unanswered questions, the collaboration for the music of The Force Awakens was not there. However, I love the characters of The Force Awakens. The acting is some of the strongest I've seen out of 7 films. In the end the film is fantastic. Did The Force Awakens miss its mark of being as great as A New Hope and The Empire Strikes Back? Yes. The beauty of a film like The Empire Strikes Back wasn't to be as great as A New Hope, but to continue the story in superior fashion. The Force Awakens overall production was spot on with how to return to the fun old school cinema approach of shooting Star Wars. However, Disney and the modern style of movie making need to be more mindful for the scope and magic of Star Wars for Episode VIII and IX.Where does Episode VII fall in the rankings of Star War films?1. The Empire Strikes Back2. A New Hope3. Revenge of The Sith4. Return of The Jedi5. The Force Awakens6. The Phantom Menace7. Attack of The Clones
This was fantastic! Action, drama... everything you want in a movie.

it has a few flaws, but all in all, it's great fun and is an excellent sequel to return of the jedi.

Not only is Star Wars: The Force Awakens my favorite movie of the year but it is also the BEST movie of the year! The whole time I was watching it I couldn't believe I was watching another Star Wars movie! Everything works, the story, the new characters clashing with the old characters, the special effects mixed with practical effects, the music, the humor and the action scenes. J.J. Abrams nails everything and still remains one of my favorite directors working today. John Boyega, Daisy Ridley, Oscar Isaac, Adam Driver, and BB-8 are perfect and you love their interactions and look forward to seeing them in more Star Wars movies. The ending is fantastic and you wish the next movie was out! I loved this movie and can't wait for the next one!

El ejercicio visualmente es mas o menos atractivo gracias a la alta definicin, el contraste, los escenarios etc. Pero debajo de todas esas herramientas la narrativa es absurda hasta romper el lmite, cada escena que pasa el absurdo se amplifica y se convierte en un video compuesto de retacera, surcidos episdicos metidos con calzador por un sastre que opta por obviar al pblico, aparenta que no existe y sirve solo al fin publicitario. Primarily, "The Force Awakens" had to produce an experience of a fun, exciting, and emotional Star Wars, driven by the characters-characters that I give a shit about-and second, it had to be set visually in the tactile world that the original Star Wars trilogy, so amazingly, told the story in, by the use to puppets, models, and large practical sets: 'The Force Awakens' SUCCESSFULLY DID BOTH THOSE THINGS!! Thank you, Kathleen Kennedy and JJ Abrams!

The Force Awakens is definitely something special. While the recycled plot elements and excessive nostalgia affect the story at times, all in all, what else can we ask for? A lot of care went into making this newest Star Wars movie and I see it as an exciting sign of things to come.
Successfully combining familiar nostalgic elements with new characters and story, this film provided much joy, thrills and outright fun. Was it worth the wait? Most definitely.

As a newcomer to the series (yes, I'm just as horrified as you are) the over-reliance on mythology was difficult to swallow for much of the opening act, but by the end of this extravaganza, it was hard to find fault it, thanks to strong performances (particularly from Domnhall Gleeson, particularly not from Adam Driver), the phenomenal score, and just a blast of a time.

Abrams makes it painfully obvious that Star Wars is now going in a new direction, led by a female warrior and her coloured beau. Aside from that, Star Wars is a treat, and leaves us waiting with abated breath for the sequel. This is not the Star Wars of Episodes 1-2-3, thank god... it's more along the lines of Episodes 4-5-6. The fact that they were able to tell the story in 3D, makes it all the more appealing. Star Wars was made to be shown in 3D. 3D was intended to showcase movies like Star Wars. Bravo.

saw it once more in 3D and it was everything I wanted in the setup episode of the new Star Wars trilogy: strong new characters alongside the respectfully aging familiar ones, visually stunning throughout, thoughtful dialogue, above-average acting, superb mix of action and plot-heavy scenes, dozens of new alien creatures, and plenty of elements of untold story. Abrams, Kasdan, and the cast & crew did Disney fans and Star Wars fans proud. It was not a perfect film. The musical score paled in comparison to Williams previous work. There were some eye-rolling action sequences. But the faults did not take away from a tremendous entertainment experience that restored order to the saga.
Better than expected. Much better.
I have renewed hope in the brand.

Holy cow - wow! What an awesome addition to the Star Wars trilogies after the lame prequels of the late 90's/early 00's. I really loved how Abrams brought the film back to its roots with the retro sci-fi setting and periodic goofball humor that made the originals so addicting. Cast members from the original movies returned to the screen and set the stage for a new era of star wars characters. The movie is an ode to the first film, following a very similar plot line. Although, the similarities are predictable, the movie remains captivating. That being said, if the series continues to follow storylines of the original movies, it will quickly become a flop. Hopefully, Abrams and Disney can come up with a more original storyline for the 2nd movie.
Same old same old, for the most part. The climax makes me not want to come back again.

If I were to summarize this movie in one word, it would be "fatigued". What few effects there were lacked professionalism, modernization, and any sort of epic feel.There were only a handful of characters, way too many close ups. The movie felt confining, claustrophobic, and narrow. It was very slow paced, and failed to keep my attention. Moments were so slow I thought it was for comic relief, when it was actually being serious. The acting was forced and awkward. I think I saw Harrison Ford's pain in his eyes at how bad Leia's acting was. The plot was weak, with a sudden "New Order" evil appearing. Somehow they already secured a planet sized superweapon, aimed at a solar system conveniently next to where the heroes were staying and with the first firing of the weapon just so happened to destroy every other planet filled with people except they one they were staying. Episode III was much better. I have no plans on seeing Episode VIII or IV, and if I by chance do, it certainly won't be in theaters. I had set my expectations much higher for Disney. This movie was terrible. 1 out of 10. I want my money back.

The newest installment in the franchise definitely evokes the nostalgia, and even some basic plot ideas, of the original trilogy. Nothing terribly new here (Abrams plays it studio safe) and that is ok. A welcome return to what fans of the original trilogy want. It will be nice to see the next films in the series branch out in to new territory without overdoing it the way Lucas did with the awful prequels. How they will keep it fresh and take chances, yet stick to the tried to formula Abrams used is what we wait for...
For someone who has never watched any previous Star Wars movies (I know shocking) this was easy to follow and I enjoyed it. Not sure why most of the cast has an accent though haha
Much better than expected. Ford's presence gives the film real 'heft' & gravitas, and Ridley makes an engaging star. Packed with wit, action & good performances.
J.J. Abrams did it better in Star Trek. Lack of character development. Still enjoyable and fun.
Everything, I've been waiting for...Kylo Ren is a real basket case and I love it!
After seeing this, you never think about the terrible prequel movies.
All in all a fantastic adventure action film. Everything you would want from a star wars film. A great mashup of the vibes of the new film while bringing a new generation.

It plays it safe, but doesn't get stupid. A nice pace while setting up some questions for future movies. Could it have been more creative? Yes. The old turn a switch and the "Death Star" blows up was boarder line lazy. Still, the cast is good, the nostalgia is good and remaining questions are intriguing. A solid and safe part one that is just the door opener. Going through the door should bring the room into view.

Half exciting space opera, half unapologetic fan service, Episode 7 does a solid job advancing the Star Wars saga. However, a little too much time was spent settling up future episodes. Fair warning: if you see this movie, you will be unable to stop yourself from seeing the next one.

Best effects, yeah for sure. An absolute blast. I felt like I was a kid again. Bravo. Should have been nominated for best picture.

Definitivamente no es la mejor de todas. Para un servidor que ha visto las 6 pelculas en incontables ocasiones fue un refrito ms que una continuacin. An cuando las dems tienen su sello, fuera de la participacin directa de George Lucas, esta rompe completamente con el ciclo para trazar uno nuevo. Se suman a sus fracasos los caprichos de Harrison Ford y Lawrence Kasdan. Si vio las anteriores y am las precuelas, evtela. Si simplemente es fan de todas, veala sin esperar tanto para no arruinarse las sorpresas, si es fan acrrimo del universo creado por novelas y cmics, evtela tambin, no le hace justicia. Si simplemente quiere ver una pelcula ms y nunca ha sido muy cercano, entonces disfrtela en compaa de gente similar. En mi opinin particular se pudo haber hecho algo mucho mejor y sin embargo se ofreci una golosina hollywoodense ms al puro estilo del que llaman los crticos.
