George Lucas can rest easy after passing the lightsaber on to cinematic genius J.J. Abrams. Abrams has created a masterpiece that left me with the same feeling I had after exiting "Star Wars" in 1977. It lives up to all of the hype leading to the premiere. From the first frame, with the sound of John Williams' rousing score, to the final fade out, there's not a moment of disappointment. Thrills, chills, action and many surprises (no spoilers listed here) are scattered throughout this exciting roller coaster ride. While the energetic young cast members are terrific, it's Harrison Ford who steals the show - many times with just an expression. For the legions of followers, this brilliant new chapter in the series is FANtastic. There are many references to the past classic films, but they cleverly fit into the plot and never get in the way. This can be credited to the screenplay written by Abrams, Michael Arndt and Lawrence Kasdan (who wrote "The Empire Strikes Back" and "Return of the Jedi"). Of course they've included R2-D2 and C-3PO, but there's also a lovable new droid named BB-8. This stellar tribute to the best of the matinee adventures of long ago is also visually stunning, but the audience will be too caught up in the plot to appreciate it - making this one of those rare films that will happily require repeat viewings. The spectacular "Star Wars: The Force Awakens" provides a new hope for future generations of moviegoers.
My wife and I went and we both enjoyed. Great entertainment.

I'll be totally honest - I wanted to go and see these film because I'd seen all the others and there was a lot of hype building with everyone but before this, I'd pretty much forgotten all the old films and was perhaps expecting a decent-ish film.What I got was one of the best films I have seen in a long time. The characters were all great (although I perhaps expected more from Finn (John Boyega) although that could mainly be due to the fact that he isn't as big a character as the trailers may have you believe. Rey is a superb character and I think she is fantastic and the additions of classic characters like Han Solo, Princess Leia, Chewbacca and others adds to the star factor and it all blends together nicely.Kylo Ren might I add is also a quality character.The storyline when you think about it isn't the greatest in the world but you won't care at all because it really is a super journey and all you'll enjoy every minute of this film.

Well I did not have a very good time watching this movie. SPOILERS!And by the way, JJ Abrams is one of my main influences and a wonderfully talented filmmaker and man. So I'm not just a cynical idiot. This is just my opinion.The fever had hit me by this point and I had just re-watched all of the original unaltered Star Wars films from 1977-1983. So I was primed. I saw it with family and everyone was stoked to return to one of our favorite universes. SO what happened? This movie fell on its face, it limped, it crawled, it tried in vain to recapture the magic and the awe. This was 95% failed remake and 5% spectacle. Other then some small throwbacks and homages, plus some epic battle sequences, nothing in the film excited me, impressed me, inspired me, or elicited any emotion that could be categorized under "positive." Mostly I was feeling disappointment and disbelief. The appropriate adjectives for the movie are "safe" "stale" "unimaginative" and "predictable." The convenience of the scenes, the ease of the struggles, the pathetic backstory and undelivered promise of a saga continued instead of repackaged. So many plot holes, illogical concepts and uninspired backstory. Even individual lines felt on the nose. Abrams keeps a pace that is too fast, too fast in that he just wants to get it over with rather than let the weight of the moment consume the audience.How I appreciate the pace of the originals. The characters, the vision of such a good vs. evil story. Luke, Vader, Obi-wan, Yoda, the Emperor, Han, Leia, Chewie, OHHHH so good!!Kylo Ren is trying to be Vader. Fail. Rey is trying to be Luke and Han. Fail. Finn is trying to be - something. Fail. By the way, although I liked Finn, his turn from a stromtrooper is unrealistic and unmotivated in any universe. Rey pretty much is perfect at everything and being left behind by her family was executed poorly though it's a great backstory - except it's been done before. I did like her self-sacrifice towards BB-8.Snoke is - come on. A CGI projection of a deep evil that came from???Kylo Ren kills every other Jedi apprentice, forces Luke into a depression and exile and yet is beaten by Rey who uses a lightsaber for the FIRST time! He doesn't even look like Han. The coolest story is lost in the decades since Return of the Jedi and reduced to flashbacks.Han dies in one of the most predictable scenes in history, plus Harrison wanted out! I didn't even care about his death and I blame that blasphemy on the movie forcing me to know what will happen before it does. R2 wakes up conveniently when the battle is over to reveal the map. Rey finds Luke in 60 seconds. BB-8 is no R2. 3PO adds nothing. Leia and Han have a weird and lazy history. The Empire pretty much wasn't beaten, bigger death star, more planets destroyed, have to destroy the energy shield, I could go on. The General even gave a speech that was part Nazi part why was it in there? This film could have been so much better and different but AT LEAST different.I feel for Abrams because I think Disney enforced a rapid timeline and the script that maybe began as something great was red-inked until it was safe enough to release.This is a return to the Star Wars universe but it offers me nothing I haven't already seen and loved. I didn't like anything that was happening and I will defend any criticism I have. If you enjoyed it, more power to you. Keep enjoying it and DO NOT wake up to the critiques that will surely come with time. I pray Episode 8 is awesome!

Lo primero es lo primero. Amigo, s, est pelcula es mejor que las precuelas, y es una digna sucesora de la triloga original. Ya puedes respirar tranquilo. Ahora al lo.Este sptimo episodio es una pelcula que sin duda se ha rodado con un mimo y un cuidado especial, que tiene unas soberbias interpretaciones, unos set pieces de accin magnficos, un diseo de produccin exquisito, y una banda sonora que es para llorar. Pero eso no quita que existan ciertos problemillas, minsculos.Se nota mucho la mano de Disney, especialmente en el miedo que tenan al tratar la pelcula. No hay ideas innovadoras, no hay nada arriesgado, y las tramas y estructuras del guin son terrorficamente idnticas a Una Nueva Esperanza. Tambin hay que decir que el guin en algunos momentos hace aguas, y por ello ciertas tramas de personaje sufren. Pero tambin es cierto que tenemos dos pelculas ms para rellanar esos agujeros as, no tenemos que esperar nada muy malo aun.

Star Wars: The Force Awakens is not just a great Star Wars movie, it's a freaking fantastic movie in general! From the action, music, performances, direction, and writing, JJ Abrams has made his best movie so far. And has continued the story in the best way possible!

Star wars The Force Awakens has been the most hyed about movie of all time pretty much, it certainly was for me. I have been a die-hard star wars fan all my life and The Force Awakens did not disappoint. Episode VII is not the most original film in the series that is for sure, but it did not have to be. It borrowed many plot lines from A New Hope and even Return of the Jedi, but that is what we wanted isn't it? The prequels were too different aesthetically and therefore JJ gave us something that looked and felt like we were in a galaxy far far away. The new characters, Rey, Finn and Poe are fantastic. Kylo Ren is awesome and is not just a rehash of Darth Vader, he is the most unique villain there has ever been in Star wars. His emotional state is a great element to his character and he is menacing. Supreme leader Snoke is a mysterious but promising character with a great voice. General Hux has some fire to him and also isn't exactly like Tarkin from A New Hope, he gives an epic speech in the movie that fills us in with some backstory as to how the resistance is related to the Republic. Daisy Ridley is a star in the making, her performance is amazing and will be a great face of the franchise for the rest of the trilogy. Now some of the negatives to this film are that there are a lot of unanswered questions, i mean a lot! this movie does not really work as a standalone movie like A New Hope did, i understand this is a new trilogy but i was hoping for some more resolution than we ended up getting. Starkiller base is another death star pretty much and it was not very menacing at all, i did not fear it in any way like i did with the first death star. JJ played it safe and it worked, this is the best film in the series since The Empire Strikes Back and is a great start to the trilogy 4.75/5
Everything I thought it would be and more.
With intense action, familiar sights, and great acting, Episode VII really is strong with the force!

A complete disregard for not only the brilliantly made expanded universe of numerous writers, but also of a vastly more intricate, logical and believable universe then this failure to the entire star war universe. This movie was a waste of money, time, and had almost no new ideas or critical thought put into it.

88%Fitfully balancing what fans love about Star Wars with the energy of modern filmmaking, The Force Awakens jumpstarts the series with new and likable characters and the same sense of fun that made the originals so memorable, even if the retreads are widely apparent.

The film opens with a vast Star Destroyer looming across the screen. A comical droid with information vital to the resistance, running away from the occupants of this Star Destroyer, is dropped onto a desert planet where someone who doesn't know they are a Jedi finds it.The jedi wannabe (who is unsure as to where and who their parents are) and companion escape the planet in the Milenium Falcon, pursued by the bad guys in a sequence involving a zany alien bar complete with musicians. Han Solo, Wookie and male lead go to rescue the female lead from a vast planet sized weapon/spacestation.Bad guy in black with a mask betrays male lead and kills him after demonstrating that he can kill folk without even touching them.Armed with inside information on said vast space station the rebels send their X wings to exploit the weapons one weakness and blow the thing up. Which they do on the second attempt.Jedi Wannabe goes off in search of someone to teach them Jedish.Is it just me or did they make Episode IV all over again almost scene for scene (But in a slightly diferent order. No doubt in the hope no-one would notice). This reached a truly farcical climax when one of the rebel generals felt he had to explain that it really wasn't a Death Star. Why? Solely because it was much much bigger.Virtually the only points of difference are that the Darth Vader character seems to be played by Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen and the Emporer character by Gollums grandad.Lazy, cowardly writing with no cliff hanger ending.At least Mark Hammil learned his lines.
This is the movie we all wanted to see in 1999. I would have given it 5 stars if we're not for the a third Death Star and some inconsistencies.

Fear not, young Padawan. The force is back. In style, and with the integrity it has been missing for decades.I cannot have been the only one whose immense anticipation for Episode VII of the Star Wars saga was only matched by the apprehension that it could turn out to be another colossal let down. George Lucas, in more than one way, had lost the legitimation to be the guardian of the Star Wars universe long, longs before he eventually abdicated. Even though his successor in the directing chair, J. J. Abrams had already demonstrated his ability to reinvent a science fiction series with his excellent work on Star Trek, it was not clear whether he would have the sensibility required to resuscitate the magic of the original Star War trilogy from the ruins that Lucas left with his prequels. For those whose young minds were irreversibly formed by the original trilogy, the term "prequel" is synonymous with "misdeed" and evokes notions of denial, abjuration, self-doubt, screenplay 101, and 'green screen'-coloured sputum. Having thoroughly flatlined through the prequels, the force has at last been resurrected with "The Force Awakens" and I cannot wait to see the Episode VIII which hopefully will mirror Episode V to bring more feel and depth. Are there grounds for nit-picking? Yes, a few. I was happy with all the references to the previous films but found the actual storyline elements being reused verbatim a bit too many for comfort. For viewers new to the saga, this won't matter a bit, though. Why the long pause between Han Solo being stabbed and Chewbacca deciding to revenge him? It only seemed motivated to allow the drama to linger on the screen. Why not have Chewbacca arrive late to the scene in order to avoid this unmotivated delay? At least for me, John Williams' scores no longer are as effective as they used to be. While the score is undeniably very good and significantly contributes to setting an authentic "Star Wars" feel to the movie, Williams seems to shy away from committing to new strong and recognisable themes. The new themes are good but not as divine as previous work for Star Wars. I found Harrison Ford's acting to be weak at times and actually did not mind his character falling out of the storyline. To claim he only has two speed -- "Jaded" and "Not quite so jaded" -- would be unfair but isn't that far from the truth. Carry Fisher looked like she was nailed to the ground and would not have been able to walk if her life depended on it. However, and more importantly, all the new actors are great (even though some of their earth-bound accents feel definitely out of place in a galaxy far, far away) and they fully deliver, showing the old cast the door. Also, humour has been brought back in the way it is meant to be, as a relief born out of natural reactions (as opposed to the embarrassing slapstick Lucas became infamous for). Overall, this movie did the saga justice. Thank you, J. J. Abrams!Here's what I expect some of my favourite film critics to say:Jeremy Jahns: Awesometacular!Tony Zhou (Every Frame a Painting): Abrams is a visual storyteller par excellence and masters the Spielberg Oner to perfection. Mr. Plinkett: This is how it's done, a**holes!EDIT: Now that the Academy Awards nominations are out, I'd like to comment that I believe the movie was justifiably nominated for an Academy Award for editing. The editing is very well done, but so are the choices when not too cut. Not only because of the latter, i.e., Abrams' great ideas for combining many shots into one, I feel the movie was snubbed for best director. Finally, in no way does "The Martian" deserve to be nominated for "best picture" if "The Force Awakens" is not. "The Martian" is OK, but nowhere near Ridley Scott's best work.

I've never been a Star Wars fan but I acknowledge and respect the new step in cinema it took - it could be said that it created the 80s sci-fi craze almost single-handedly. This one? It's just as good as those originals if you ask me. Great acting, well handled fx & action. Classic Spielberg/Cameron style sensibilities from JJ in his best movie. This restarts the mythology in a way the prequels, though they were braver, couldn't come close to.

Maybe, I have become a cinema snob, or after having partaken in over 5,000 movies, I find the latest episode of Star Wars to be bland. It conjures nostalgia for beloved characters from our younger days, but tries to sell the same story, with better special effects and fresh faces. The acting, cinematography, screenplay, etc are all top notch, but the movie doesn't wow all Star Wars fans, as you may have thought reading the reviews. The plot is somewhat predictable, and the climax reminds you of the original Star Wars. At best, this is a re-make of the original with a few minor plot twists.While George Lucas would be licking his lips with the expected billion dollar payoff, I do hope he does not succumb to bland for his next edition. Incidentally the villian in that movie is slated to be Benicio Del Toro - that is formidible. Worth a watch, but not worth a second visit to 3D or IMAX 3D.

I don't blame him I was just waiting for this snooze fest to end. Either have a realistic gripping story or dump the over the top immersion killing humor. You cannot have both. No longer weighted down by the CGI-ridden backgrounds and hooky acting of the previous installments, The Force Awakens is a return to form for the franchise/pop culture phenomenon that, even in its short comings (the similarities to A New Hope for instance) thrilled and satisfied diehard fans. Benefiting from JJ Abrams stylish direction (lens flares are present but not as pervasive as in his previous works) and his genuine care for the making of this production, the film boasts impressive special effects, both visual and, for the most part, practical, as well as a fine cast.

The Force Awakens is about a scavenger (Daisy Ridley) and a renegade stormtrooper (John Boyega) and together they enlist the help of legendary smugglers Han Solo (Harrison Ford) and Chewbacca to transport a droid carrying information regarding the whereabouts of Luke Skywalker. Let me start off by saying that I am and always will be a huge Star Wars fan. The characters and the story has always intrigued me. The Force Awakens is a stunning sequel that arrays a perfect mix of new and old. This movie is everything that you hoped and dreamed that it would be. John Boyega and Daisy Ridley shine and have great chemistry together, as well as Adam Driver perfectly portraying the sinister Kylo Ren. Don't be alarmed, all of your favorite Star Wars characters are back as well. They aren't, however, just in the movie for nostalgic value. All of the classic characters we know and love still bring so much to the table plot wise, and they still deliver key performances. When you put all of these actors and iconic characters under the direction of J.J Abrams, you have what I believe to be the best Star Wars film in the saga. However, the acting/direction isn't the only thing that we must give credit for. John Williams is still composing and his music score is just as powerful as it was when the first movie was released back in 1977. The music gives the movie so much feeling and the score blends perfectly with both the acting and the cinematography. I also must give props to Daniel Mindel who did a fantastic job on the cinematography. He made the movie seem so much more realistic and made it very exciting. Everything in this particular Star Wars movie just seemed bigger and better. Overall, The Force Awakens lives up to the previous films making this a near perfect seventh installment.
Great film. Obviously, you might wanna check it out!
Very good but a bit to similar to a new hope to get the 5 stars for me

The Force Awakens is a generally strong movie. Even after all these years, Star Wars still finds a way to draw us in and lose ourselves in a galaxy far, far away. That being said, the only major issue I have with this movie is that the plot was nearly identical to its predecessors. I am aware that The Force Awakens is a "tribute" of sorts, but that doesn't excuse the laziness of the writers. Carrie Fisher and Harrison Ford both hit home runs, but I wish the other actors could have stepped up their game a little.
As a long time fan (first saw star wars during 1978 re-release) I'm going to keep this simple and just say that it's Star Wars and it's plain old-fashioned fun! Loved it!
Any disappointment with this movie can be blamed pretty squarely on the sheer amount of over-saturated hype in the months leading up the the premier.
One of the best in the series for sure. JJ sure did a great job by staying true to the original with new elements of his own. Daisy, John and Oscar are great in their roles.
Good opening act to revive this series.

Nothing compares to that first night of watching a new Star Wars movie in a packed house full of fans, cheering, laughing, and crying together (hopefully other people cried). Luckily the movie actively encouraged that participation by giving us an enjoyable briskly paced story that kept me engaged throughout the entirety of it. The acting here from everyone is top notch, the new characters with Daisy Ridley, John Boyega, and Oscar Issac, but my personal favorite of the newbies is Adam Driver's Kylo Ren. There are moments in this movie where you can feel his passion and anger leap off the screen, creating a villain you are invested in. However the best overall performance is from Harrison Ford, who brought back Han Solo, with all the quips and charm from the original trilogy. Any drawbacks of the movie are small enough to not affect me in any major way, but after 3 viewings I would some of the pacing is off. The beginning is slower and then it never looks back from there, when maybe it should have. I believe this also plays into the humor of the film, which for the most part was spectacular and surprising, but some jokes were given too much or too little screen time. Overall though this is a favorite movie of mine because it is Star Wars, it feels like Star Wars in every aspect, the characters, the locations, the spaceships, everything just felt like a return to the original trilogy. And that is the most I could have ever hoped for, bring on Episode VIII.
In my opinion is a copy of the film "a new hope" but with better visual effects!

When I first heard that there will be a new trilogy for Star Wars, I just jump and scream as high and as loud as I can. As you can see, I'm a BIG BIG FAN of the Star Wars franchies. I used to watch the previous 6 films EVERYTIME I just went home from school. I would watch it over and over again until the DVD cracked or lost. Since then, Star Wars will always be part of my childhood.So let's get to the movie.The movie is good. Just good. Not perfect. There are things that bothered me and maybe it will be kind of strange for some Star Wars fans. They say the film was the best amongst the others. I don't agree with this. Episode 7 seems to be copying the original Star Wars (1977) formula. When I went to the theatre, I wanted to see something new and fresh - yes, there are but not too convincing to me. They teared up the 50% with the new things, but left the 50% of the original formula. I wanted 75%-80% of new things.The film follows 3 new characters. Those three new characters would be the main protagonists in the new trilogy. Do I hate them? No, I love them! But, Poe should have more screen time. Rey is amazing. There hasn't been a lot of convincing female jedi in the film. Now this is one of the amazing new ideas in the movie.The story lacked of information. Who is Supreme Leader Snoke? Where have Han Solo and Chewie been in the lost 30 years? How does Maz Katana get her hands on Luke's lightsaber? Etc.But as I said, the new ideas were very fresh. You can see the new lightsaber, the new X-Wing, the new characters, and Kylo Ren. Oh, I haven't talked about Kylo Ren.Kylo Ren has a good character arc. Though he was not as strong as Darth Vader, we love his inconsistent emotion and way of thinking. We identified him easily because we too are like Kylo Ren. We are human beings who can't decide which to do and which to think. We sometimes chose the right one, but we also sometimes chose the bad one.The final lightsaber battle was the best in the movie. It was motivated. We don't know if Rey was going to defeat Ren or not. Rey doesn't have any training skills. Because of the motivations behind the battle, we sit with hard tense from your feet to the tip of you hair.But, there are a lot of things that really need to be answered in Episode 8. So... we'll have to wait until 2017.The verdict:The film wants to draw attention to new audience, I understand that. But it lacked a new formula - FORMULA, not ideas.

The franchise has reawakened with this film. Excellent performances by Harrison Ford, Carrie Fisher, Adam Driver, Oscar Isaac, and John Boyega. Daisy Ridley was the stand-out performer in this epic. Looking forward to seeing it again on Sunday!

A good Star Wars flick that kept the characters and some of the Lore from the books intact with the new story. You could definitely see the Disney touch with the writing. Overall a cool epic flick that clearly had a ton of money thrown into it and a ton of money profit from it. It was great to see the older actors come back for the story and to reprise their roles.

I must admit, I was disappointed when I first saw The Force Awakens. The poor pacing, the plot holes, and lack of originality gnawed at me. I have since taken my kids twice (they love it). But that's the point, 8 year old's don't care about 1977 nostalgia or what's canon. This movie is for the Disney generation, not 40 something Star Wars geeks. I watched the movie for the third time this weekend. This time I loved it. I watched it through my kids eyes. No expectations, no preconceived notions of how I felt the story should go. It is a great science fiction action movie. Star Wars worthy? I will reserve judgement until I see Episode VIII. Three nagging issues still stand out for me: 1) No embrace or acknowledgement between Leia and Chewie after Han is killed. That's just floors me. I blame the director for that. 2) Han and the others seeing the Hosnian system being destroyed by the starkiller weapon from Maz Kanata's planet, and in broad daylight no less. I can overlook the starkiller draining suns and shooting it's beam via "hydra-space", it is science fiction after all. But seeing another solar system being destroyed in real time in the sky like watching the Death Star explode over the Endor moon is just plain insulting. 3) The First Order and the villains are weak and poorly developed. Hux is too young. Snoke is not scary. Phasma is incompetent to say the least. And Kylo Ren's powers appear to be inconsistent. I don't care how injured he was, by the end of the movie he seemed weak and pathetic. If he's the leader of the Knight of Ren. I'm not scared (yet). Thank you for reading.
great movie. Action, The Force, Darth Vader. Even a tiny bit of intrigue. Really enjoyed it.
Sure it's a repeat of the original trilogy, but it'll still be worth the watch.

93% .... how ? The only good thing about this movie is it has star wars in the title... the characters are blah.... the story was blah.... If this didn't have star wars in the name they would have given it about 2%

A couple decades ago we received three Star Wars prequels! Two of them were disappointing and the third one was good but not given the care that was given to the originals. 10 years later we have booted the CGI defecating George Lucas out of the directing chair and replaced it with J.J. Abrams. And let me tell you that Mr. Abrams and Disney have really delivered, I was super impressed by the job they did on this film. Is it a perfect Star Wars film? No, but it was closer to what a Star Wars film should be like. So what did I like and what problems did I have with it.The New Characters are very well written and performed very well; the imagery and effects are spectacular with the use of both practical and computer-generated effects, John Williams score is always on point, and the action scenes are beautifully shot. To my surprise there was a lot of humor in the film, however it is done brilliantly and subtly which is an immense improvement over Jar-Jar Goddamn Binks from the prequels.  So that was the good now on to the flaws, to begin the story while good, borrows way too much from episode IV A New Hope. Both films involve the opposing forces interrogating the protagonists for some important Data, which is given to a droid, which comes into possession of a force sensitive protagonist who ends up helping the rebellion destroy a space station and becoming a hero. Now I am going to excuse this for the fact that this is only the first movie of what is suppose to be a new trilogy, and because the story for the two other films is unknown at this point its not fair to hold this against it.However what I can hold against it is continuity errors. Now there aren't that many of these, but the few that there are, are serious. For example, the character Rey comes in contact with a lightsaber That Luke lost when his hand was severed in Bespin during his duel with Vader in Episode V, which you all know took place on a giant catwalk over a giant pit that leads to the outside of the building which is up in the clouds. Now again maybe they will explain this later in the story, but even then it is a little too convenient that the lightsaber was actually found.With my complaints aside I really enjoyed this movie and am looking forward to watching the next movie when it's released. I rate this film 4.5/5 stars.
Was only made to please fans, not actually tell an interesting story, did not feel emotionally engaged with the characters, I hope boba fett comes back and kills everyone

It was just OK. It was more of a re-hash of the other movies rather than something all new. I didn't think the special effects were as good as they were in the original Star Wars movie. Maybe because this one was filmed in 3D and they developed the special effects to look best in 3D.

Huge fan of the Star Wars universe, so it really couldn't earn anything less than three stars in my book. I think Disney and JJ focused far too intently on bringing Star Wars towards a modern audience and "rebooting" the franchise, largely ignoring what they should have done which is provide a standalone story with the components of a good Star Wars movie. Too much of it was rushed, so much so that most of the film's major plot points (including the Starkiller Base battle) was pretty anti-climactic. In fact everything about it seemed rushed, making it appear like they tried to squeeze everything about what's to come in the newly rebooted series into one "preview movie". Force Awakens was essentially: "Look who we're killing off, look who we're keeping, this desert-dwelling loner girl who already knows how to use the Force is going to be the next super-awesome jedi, and there's this Nazi-like group who scraped up what was left of the Empire. By the way, you won't ever see the fruits of the Rebel Alliance's labor in reforming the Empire into the New Republic. These new guys' sphere of death is so awesome it destroyed EVERY major New Republic population center in ONE shot." Short version: They really need to follow this movie with more than two films; it's just too much of a two-hour long trailer rather than an actual movie.

This next instalment in the Star Wars behemoth is above all a fresh and exciting addition that offers fans new and old an impressive new era. The strengths of the film are certainly the strong cast of new and old, the feeling of nostalgia and frantic pace, all of which keeps the audience stuck to the screen and wanting more. However some elements of the plot have born too heavy a likeness to the original Star Wars screenplay of which most notably the attempted Death Star revival in Star Killer Base is the weakest example. The film does also suffer from its breakneck pace at times, with some of the more poignant and dramatic moments harried over in order to maintain the speed. Overall this does not damage the tone of the film and one can conclude that this while not likely to be the strongest piece in the Star Wars Franchise, has certainly laid down a powerful framework for the remainder Disney produced entries. May the Force be with you.

The latest return of the most iconic space fantasy franchise was anticipated with mixed feelings. Star Wars had returned once before with awful results when George Lucas, the director of the original beloved trilogy of adventure flicks, resurrected his greatest money maker in 1999. That trilogy of prequels has often been called a series of commercials meant to boost toy sales.After this cinematic disaster, the franchise was kept off the silver screen, until Lucas decided to gather his winnings and sell the exclusive SW license to none other than Disney Pictures. The most critical viewers foresaw more toy commercial material, but Disney seemed to know they had something to proof. J.J. Abrams, the guy who managed to resurrect cerebral Star Trek as a goofy slapstick extravaganza in 2009 was assigned to do- financially, at least- the same trick with Star Wars.He succeeded. Not only did "The Force Awakens" make unimaginable amounts of money, it isn't an awful film by any means. It's about the safest bet Abrams could have made, but he managed to concoct a reasonably entertaining piece of harmless entertainment even under overwhelming pressure from a passionate fan base.The approach here is extremely retro. Everything from lighting to framing to sound design is pure late seventies, making "The Force Awakens" feel quite like "A New Hope" all over again. The same is true for the script as well. Abrams was criticized heavily for using too many familiar elements in "Star Trek: Into Darkness," but here he basically remixes "A New Hope" right down to structural detail. The clear nostalgia-over-anything -mentality might have made this film a sort of non-movie, but all the channeling is done with care and precision.Then the problems. Hollywood spectacle scripts are plagued by incongruences and conflicting details, which is more of a crime when the story as a whole doesn't set out to do anything on any deeper level, as seems to be the case here. The second act has some easy emotional moments but kind of falls apart into a sequence of aimless action sequences in familiar Abrams- and, yes, Star Wars- fashion. But the beginning and the ending entertain well enough for me to forgive the lazy writing midway through. Also, the dialogue is okay, which is the clearest improvement to all the previous installments.Another resurrection of the "A New Hope" approach is the decision to use relatively unknown stars in leading roles. All of them do well enough if not excellent. I hope there will be some involved character building in the future, because so far the new characters don't have that much meat around the bones yet. The supporting characters known from previous films still steal the show just because of their history.We begin the saga with Finn (John Boyega), a soldier of the Empire who decides to switch sides as he witnesses military atrocities in the field. There's bound to be some internal conflict here in the future, but not much is seen yet. Boyega doesn't have much to work with as it stands, and that shows a bit.The major hero this time is a more kick-ass version of Luke Skywalker, Rey (Daisy Ridley) who gets caught up in the conflict between the rebels and the Empire and happens to have a natural mastery of The Force bordering on the Deus ex machina. I'm hoping for more nuances here as well- Rey is even more of a Mary Sue than Luke was, and that's too much. Ridley spends a bit too much screen time simply looking astonished, but she fares well in the end. There's a physicality to her that suits the two-dimensional action hero Rey still is.The most tragic character failure is the antagonist. Kylo Ren, played by Adam Driver. He is very difficult to take seriously. His arch has mirrored that of Anakin Skywalker, and there is way too much gothic emo angst and hair products involved in the character design on every level. His scenes came across more parodic than nostalgic.At times, the parody feel is also present because of the music. John Williams returns with a score that nicely plays into the retro feel, but at times the melodramatic strings just make a scene feel like a spoof. The melodies aren't horribly memorable either.In hindsight, the original Star Wars trilogy seems to thematically announce and reflect the Reagan era. Militaristic bravado, religious war romanticism and nave hero myths abound. In 2016 the very same ideology persists in the franchise, but it presents itself as less influential as it just blends in with all the nostalgia. Abrams inserted a same sort of hard values -romanticism into his first star Trek film and it was painfully ill-fitting inside a franchise known for its soft values and logical non-romanticism. Now he gets to do what he wants in a franchise where it all fits, and seems to make the assumed fanboy enthusiasm work in the movie's favor. Now that he's won approval for a remix, he has the opportunity to take risks and take a worshipped mythos further. I hope he will.There are some Daesh similes here to make it all a bit more current, though. And overall the conflict between the Empire and the rebels is presented more as a holy war. The original trilogy- in its time of libertarianism and Reaganomics- presented the Empire vaguely as a communist state, but it is more clearly a church here. The war among the stars might be less about ideology than about scripture.

Star Wars, all in all, is one big hype train fueled by the dollars of loyal fans. Keep in mind, I have almost NO bias here, as I only recently saw the original trilogy, and find it hard to get invested in the universe surrounding these movies. Who knew that the movie that dumped the internet on it's side, the movie that had everybody discussing whether it should or should not happen, the movie that many internet critics are saying is one of the best, if not the best, film of the year, the movie that has people up in each other's throats for saying those 3 dreaded, spoiler-y words, would be the movie I find to be OKAY... but not much else? I did, because I do not buy into hype trains that rely almost entirely on nostalgia. Star Wars has always been an enigma to me: how can something so interesting, but nowhere NEAR perfect have such a major cultural impact? Word of mouth. And that's what got most people interested in this one, word of mouth. I knew I was going to see it, but not at first sight. So, when I went to see this in December, like every other insane person did (those of you who did see it in December, don't be a scumbag, just because it's been out for a month does not give you the right to spoil it!), I had next to no expectations. I walked out almost 3 hours later, with a debate in mind, whether what I saw was worth almost 3 hours of my time. On the cinematography side, yes. The Force Awakens is well shot, and the action scenes are VERY well done, but, this does not excuse the story. Don't get me wrong, this is NOT one of those films where you have hard times holding your suspension of disbelief... it's one of those sequels where you can't help comparing it to it's predecessors. This is basically a newer version of A New Hope, or the OG Star Wars as the Die Hards will often know it as.Without further ado, here's what basically happens. Now, keep in mind, if you have not seen SW:TFA yet, please, by all means, skip this next, overly long paragraph. I will be talking about the main plot, and sideplots that take place here, and what I feel works, and fails. The movie begins decently enough, by jumping right into the action, as a rebel planet is attacked by the Empir- Err, I mean The First Order. Some rebels escape, but the rest of the village is slaughtered by Clone Troopers. However, one of those Clone Troopers refuses to end the village, as he has become traumatized by the death of another, fellow trooper. He and rest escape from the planet, some leader in a suit made of tin barks at him for taking off his helmet (to reveal he's black, but this is only really an issue if you're racist/bigot), and one of the escaping rebels is captured. The black storm trooper frees the rebel, and escape using a ship. The two of them flee to the planet that was used in the beginning of the film, as the rebel is trying to get back his droid, BB-8, who has the map to find Luke Skywalker. It is here that I began to notice the similarities, as the planet could easily be a variable, sent in to replace the ship that A New Hope begins on. Anyways, on the way to the planet, the Storm Trooper gets a name: Fin. The 2 of them crash, and the perspective changes to Ray, a trader who sells all things metal to get weird, slimy cash. She finds BB-8, who tells her everything she needs to know plotwise, and he follows her home. BB-8 is almost sold, but does not give in. Here's where I'm going to get lazy and skip the details: Fin meets Ray, helps steal the Millennium Falcon, which then gets captured by Han Solo and Chewey. They look at the incomplete map, visit the rebel base and learn about the 4th iteration of the death star. At this point, the lazy writing kicked in. For the life of me, I could not understand why going for another death star was worth it, especially considering they've overused the death star so much, to the point where they might as well go ahead and build one on somebodies trousers. Anyhow, they learn about Kylo Ren, Han Solo's goth son, who has the dorkiest face I've seen in a while (despite the actor actually being really good). Anyhow, Fin finds a lightsaber, Ray learns the force somehow, and they go over to the death star planet thing currently being powered by the sun. It is here where the only words to spoil this movie kick in: Han Solo dies. This is one of the strongest parallels to the Episode IV in the entire movie, but is only marginally beaten by the Death Star's 4th appearance. Anyhow, Fin gets injured by Kylo Ren's claymore lightsaber, but Ray gets him. They escape the death star, in it's whole blowy-uppy sequence, Fin begins to get treated, and they find Luke Skywalker. The End.I guess something else that's cool is the performances, which, as expected, are outstanding.All in all, Star Wars is not perfect. If you love it depends on if you won't think about the comparisons while watching it.Now, please, PLEASE don't attack me Star Wars fanboys, this was an honest review about MY thoughts on TFW, not YOUR thoughts.

Return to the galaxy where it all began when the next generation in good vs. evil joins forces with familiar faces to wage an all out war to stop a new rising evil. Set years after the events in "Return of the Jedi"; Han, Luke, and Leia are joined by a new set of Resistance fighters who are determined to bring down a new threat known as the "First Order". Will they be able to win the war or will a unknown secret tear apart the very foundation that binds them together? The seventh chapter in the Star Wars Saga brings new action with a familiar heart at the core of it's story. Though it does not help that this is the first movie in the series to be done by Walt Disney in which it plays it safe by not pushing the boundaries like the six previous films did. However, whether you like it, hate it, or indifferent towards it...The Force has Awaken and it will make you feel nostalgic for the original trilogy all over again!!!

TFA was a great movie that helped bring the Star Wars franchise back to life from the let down that is the prequels trilogy. At times the call backs to previous movies get a bit annoying and the MCU styled jokes seem a bit "forced", but all-in-all this is a great film to expand the Star Wars universe. The film has spectacular action sequences, a happy medium between practical effects and CGI, excellently composed and lit shots, and most importantly this actually FEELS like a Star Wars movie.

At first, I thought this movie was going to be terrible like The Phantom Menace, but it surprised me. The film is kind of a reboot of A New Hope, but it works, and unlike the prequels, less is more. The overall plot is good, the characters are cool or tolerable(My favorite new characters are Kylo Ren, Rey, and Poe), and the pace of the movie is fun, action packed, and at one moment, shocking. Even though there are some things left unexplained and the fact that one character learns something way too quickly, it is a fun film and a worthy Star Wars sequel.

I thought this movie was a colossal fail. While arguably slightly better than its modern day predecessors, its at times glacial pace, often unsubstantiated plot progression, and absurd 'deus ex machina' moments destroyed its unlimited potential. Without getting too much into spoilers, the idea that (a) character(s) in the movie were able to (without training) defeat obviously far more practiced baddies struck me as inane. I understand it was an awakening of the 'force', but there is absolutely no premise to support anyone exercising advanced abilities without training whatsoever. Especially when considering the demonstrably powerful opponent's skills. This along with the film's glossed over and at times completely unexplained plot progression, delivers a film rife with forced tributes to Lucas lore and sporadic, incomplete character development that ultimately begs the question: What exactly just happened?I'll obligingly see the second hopefully more finessed sequel in hopes that it at least somewhat makes good on its promise to elevate the quality of the franchise. Disney purchasing the rights to Star Wars should have provided a clear step forward from the modern Lucas generation tragedies. Unfortunately it was at best, mildly better than its antecedents, and at most partially delivered upon its massive prerelease hype.

This film is profoundly OK. Among critics and fans alike, it seems to be benefiting from a hefty dose of low expectations brought on by the prequels. Half the scenes were lifted straight from A New Hope, the story-line was painfully simplistic, and the main "bad guy," Kylo Ren, is disappointing (he went from intimidating to weak and laughable way too fast). There are some notable bright spots here. The new characters (Finn, Rey, Poe) are good although their dialogue relies a bit too much on cheesy comic relief (so, you're telling me that a guy who was born and bred as a storm trooper from such a young age that he doesn't even have a name--only a number--somehow talks like a wisecracking fanboy on Reddit. Come on!)

This movie was nearly perfect. There were a few mysteries, which I'm sure will be filled in later. Loved the connections with older characters and introduction to new ones. Can't wait to see the next!

The actual plot here constitutes no more than ten minutes of screen time. Only a heroic set of performances from the cast elevate this film into something worth watching. Disappointing but not bad.

So, the Force Awakens sure if fun to watch. I enjoyed it and wouldn't have missed seeing it. Now that some time has passed, I can't get over the fact that it didn't inspire me. The main reason for that is that is was mostly predictable and frankly too much like the original. While I understand the desire to get back to the magic of the first movie, I don't think a slightly different version of the same plot was the way to go. I'm hoping for a few more surprises next movie. I also hope they are not afraid of deeper character development which is what makes "Empire" the best of the entire series.

A hot topic for controversy--especially within hardcore fan circles--and no doubt flawed, Star Wars: The Force Awakens is, nonetheless, a brilliant film on many levels. Memorable characters, brilliant practical effects--though they only make whatever CGI there is in the film stand out more--fast pacing, and gorgeous cinematography are just a few examples of what the film does superbly. Not to mention the fact that the film is absolutely worth seeing numerous times and even somehow manages to get better with subsequent viewings. Though it can feel a bit too similar to Episode IV at many points and though some parts weren't really necessary (Starkiller Base, anyone?), Episode VII still nonetheless succeeds where previous film-based attempts in the franchise failed and manages to take the series back by force.8.6/10

NO SPOILERSLike pretty much everyone else, I love Star Wars and I was so excited to hear that they are going to be making a sequel trilogy. As time went on, I got more and more excited as we were getting to know who was going to be involved in the film. J.J. Abrams did a fantastic job with the new Star Trek films and knowing that he's going to direct the next Star Wars film, there was almost no doubt that this film is going to be good. And I am so glad to say that Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens is a fantastic addition to the saga! It gave me everything I wanted to see in a Star Wars film and more, and I'm not just saying that, it really did!Probably the strongest aspect of the film is the characters. I love virtually every single character in the film; Finn, Poe, Kylo Ren, and especially Rey! They're all so interesting, they are set up in the film very well, you know where they have been, you understand their motivations, you feel for them as well the chemistry between them, and you can relate to them. I love how we also get to see some old favorites like Han, Chewie, and Leia. They aren't there to make pointless cameos just to make you remember them, they have important roles in the film that are supportive to the new characters and give more meaning to the film's story. All the actors deliver very believable performances that help make you care for each character. The special effects in the film are so well done. It's a perfect blend of practical and computer generated effects, along with absolutely beautiful cinematography, that makes the film feel more real. The action scenes are some of the most fun I've had in any Star Wars film, or in any film more that matter. The iconic musical score from John Williams, which is so refreshing to hear again, really adds to the thrill and fun of the action. The film is also hilarious, maybe the funniest out of the entire saga! The humor they throw at you is spot on and it never feels too forced. It's awesome to see the humor incorporated with the villainous characters as well, which I don't think we've seen that in a Star Wars film before. They balance out the humor with a perfect amount of genuine emotion and drama. I was a little worried about the little robot, BB-8. He seemed too cutesy, he had the risk of being very annoying, and I didn't think he would fit with the film's tone. But nope, the little guy is awesome, cute, and funny in just the right ways.That all being said, is it a perfect film? As much as I want to say it is, I do have some complaints. Without giving away any plot points, my main issue is that I thought the story of the film felt a little too familiar and mirrors a lot of plot elements from Episode IV - A New Hope, which I think everyone has that same issue. But I felt like they had to do that because we wanted to see and feel the old magic of Star Wars again, and we missed out on a lot of that with the prequel trilogy. Though the plot felt familiar, they had a new director who created different themes and tones that made it feel like a continuation of the saga. However, it would've been nice if they came up with a more original story, even though the story was told extremely well. I also thought that there wasn't quite enough exposition for me to understand how the film progressed from the original trilogy. But again, maybe that was the point because they probably want to leave us wondering how the rest of the new trilogy would play out. I would rather have a film give little exposition than have a film give too much exposition like what the prequels did. Just like what they say, less is more. One other small complaint is the computer animation done on Supreme Leader Snoke. When comparing the CGI done in the rest of the film, I thought he looked pretty bad. Thankfully, he was in a small portion of the film and maybe the animation on him will improve in the upcoming films.But those flaws never disrupted my enjoyment of the film, I enjoyed every minute of it. I had a huge smile on my face the whole time. It brings us right back to the magic of the original trilogy that we all love and fans of the saga will be more than satisfied. I cannot wait to see Episode VIII. Star Wars is back!
The movie serves the fans but is also innovative, preparing well the following episodes. The biggest disappointment is the Starkiller base which is too close to a Death Star.

This review took me a long time to wrestle with. Mostly being that there's no way I can objectively look at something Star Wars related and not get a bit giddy and feel like a kid, which in fact is the beauty of this franchise and this film. What JJ and co have accomplished wonderfully is the simple fact that they made a movie that feels like you're watching "A New Hope" all over again. It's quirky, a bit odd, exhilarating, and simple. There are still flaws, the story isn't bulletproof, JJ still relies on too many conveniences and the occasional shoddy character motivation to move the plot forward, and perhaps the main plot sticks a bit too close to "A New Hope", but overall this movie feels like a new Star Wars movie should feel. It looks stunning, the practical effects really take it to the next step, and they give the movie a personality that is missing from the prequels. Another thing this movie gets right is the characters. It doesn't focus too much on old faces, and the new characters (Fin, Rey, BB-8, Kylo Ren) are personable, interesting, and engaging. I'm excited to see them grow and progress as humans, which something I haven't felt from these films in a long time. Overall, The Force Awakens may play its cards a bit too safe, and instead of trying to be great, it simply tries not be bad. Which it's not, and for Star Wars, that's more than enough.

Screw nostalgia, the only thing which made the originals good is the time of its release and how revolutionary the trilogy was. The Revenge of the Sith had far much more action and story progression. But The Force Awakens blows it out of the water for action. Humour is a little more grown up and much less cheesy. It does seem like the same old rebels attach the spaceship scene which was the focal point of new hope and empire strikes back. And another lovechild turns bad so for originality its lacking in the plot. It does have a good tone in terms of the legend of the force and all the stories of the great battle. The First Order has emerged welcomingly however and I look forward to a much more grown up series with action like this one.

They are usually feared but he is more of a nobody except for the fact of who he truly is. He can't "sense" where people are and is probably the worst person I've ever seen wield a saber. Speaking of the saber I'm not a fan of this new saber design. Honestly there was a lot I saw wrong with this story but like I said I'm biased so I still love it. The writing was just awful. It just lacked any cohesion. Absolutely nonsensical. It seemed like a Michael Bay movie. That being said there were some good things. Many scenes used special effects like the original films which were clearly more realistic than the prequels. However there were still scenes of pure CGI that had almost no realism. Especially bad -and pointless- was the scene on the falcon with the escaped creatures. Just awful. Death planet - awful. Bad guys - far too weak. Good guys/women - far too strong. The writer clearly has no idea that you actually have to take the time to train to be good at something. A huge change from the originals that focused on teaching and training. The senseless action scenes just ruined it for me. I did like the idea of a stormtrooper becoming good but it could have been done with more realism. I thought this was pretty bad. I hate to say it because I wanted it to be good. I'm not sure there is much potential for the next two given how weak the bad guys are in this movie. I'm just glad Michael Bay and/or JJ Abrams is not directing.

Laughable that this movie has a 93% on this website, sad actually. For all of the flack the prequel trilogy gets they did something right. That was originality, something severely lacking from this movie.Some random thoughts of the movie- Takes place on three planets, Tattooine rip off, Hoth rip off and an endor/naboo rip off.-Technology somehow hasn't progressed in the 30+ years since the OT.-Finn is almost useless, think of him of a less obvious jar jar binks with a slight love story attached to him to make him feel more important to the story.- Poe flat character clearly good at piloting, absent from practically everything with no explanation.-BB8: R2D2 clone although its good to see a different droid in the limelight - Rey is living on a desert planet and seems rather unhappy. (where have we seen this before) somehow can do everything and practically nothing wrong, never has there been a character in Starwars that has been so invincible.- Kylo Ren is probably the most interesting of all the new characters in the movie. Blatantly based off of Anakin but with good reason. Id have to say the best part of this movie is this character i cannot wait to see more of him.- Harrison Ford does his best performance in a long time. A lot of heavy breathing into the microphone though- Any interactions between Leia and Han Solo are cringe worthy and completely detract from the movie. After the first time it happened i found myself wishing for them not to encounter each other for the rest of the film.-Obvious death star clone-Rey: Super pilot and mechanic extraordinaire (ill give that to her she spent her life inside of machines) but knows the millennium falcon better than solo? Ridiculous. Wasn't sure if Jedi were real. 25 minutes later she reads Kylos mind and then uses Jedi mind tricks (which shes never seen anybody do) on a storm trooper. She does this and also defeats Kylo Ren in a duel with absolutely no training whatsoever. Luke trained hard and could barely lift a lightsaber out of the snow 10 feet away from him. Rey accidentally gets the same light saber out of the snow from 20 yards away while at the same time over powering Kylo to get it, again having no idea what shes doing. It took Luke 3 movies of training and he still lost to Darth Vader, she needs none to defeat the master of the knights of ren. I don't want to say it but shes sort of a "Mary Sue" I hope in the next film theres some sort of struggle she goes through. I am happy Star Wars finally has a female lead, this just isn't how it should have been handled.- Maz sort of cheapens the Jedi council from the prequels. She talks and says wise things as Yoda did and thus cheapens Yoda and the rest of the Jedis.- Where does Maz get the light saber? It fell into the abyss in Cloud City. "A story for another time" is all she says about it. Sounds like lazy plot writing. - why is captain phasma on the poster she does nothing the entire movie- get ready for close ups 50% of the movie is character face shots.The movie is not all bad though and if you're not a fan of Star Wars/ havent seen the other movies id recommend it. If you have any prior knowledge to the series particularly the original trilogy that odds are you understand the gripes i have with this film. After seeing it twice, I figured I was finally ready to put The Force Awakens into review form. Taking place 30 years after the events of Return Of The Jedi, The Force Awakens shows that not much has changed since the destruction of the second death star. Before too long, characters old and new are teaming up to once again take down the bad guys. It all feels very........familiar. And that's because The Force Awakens takes a large number of story beats from the original movie, A New Hope. That's not necessarily a bad thing. It's been 10 years since the last movie and 30 since the events that precede this movie. it makes sense, then, that the movie would borrow elements from the others to bring us back into the world of Star Wars. What's more, even with all that borrowing, The Force Awakens is a great movie on it's own. The reliance on practical effects and sets give the movie some much needed weight, something the shiny, clean surfaces of the prequels did not try to do. Even better, the new characters are all fantastic. Adam Driver and John Boyega both play interesting, complex new characters (especially Driver's Kylo Ren who I enjoyed quite a bit) but it's Rey, played with fantastic wide eyes by Daisy Ridley, who steals the entire movie. She is the driving force behind the entire plot and I cannot wait to see what future movies have in store. The movie also introduces a whole host of other new characters but many of them have limited screen time so their impact is not as strongly felt. Besides all the new characters, the movie also does a fine job of bringing back it's old characters, especially Han Solo who, other than Rey, is the main protagonist in the show. The biggest complaint I have about The Force Awakens is it's insistence on borrowing plot elements but I will give it a pass this one time simply because it's looking to set up a whole new chapter of this story. Future installments will not get this same pass because they now have more incentive to make something fresh and unique after the resounding success of The Force Awakens.
The movie has embarrassing moments (mostly with the former stars reprising old roles), but overall it is pretty good. It would be much better if it were 25 minutes shorter.

Predictable unoriginal plot, terrible romance between Han and Leia, ridiculous concept that the COMPLETELY untrained hero/heroine defeat a seasoned Dark Jedi, Luke shows up for 30 sec at the end and says nothing?!?!? Granted, the characters 'Daisy and Finn' were played pretty decently, but I mean, it's not 1990 or 2000... why is it still edgy or groundbreaking that the leads are a woman and a black dude? Like I said, they were the only parts I found decent (and the Rebel Pilot), but what do you think this is, the South in the 1950's? Oh, and if the Rebels won and are now in control... why are they still 'Rebels?' and why is the First order not known as the Rebels? Obviously they had to try and fill some gaps, but how in the hell did Luke lose his nephew to the dark side? And to who? And what?... killing your father is no big deal, but the nephew thing... gotta go into hiding and not face this problem. And how could they think Finn was a Rebel with all his fear and lack of hope towards the First Order? Disney did it though, marketed the heck out of this thing to no end where everyone HAD to see it since they liked the ones before this. Just download this if you haven't seen it, I'm usually against that, but the media hype should be seen as false advertising. Good special effects though. (but that's obvious)

Abrams and Co. had a large task. Make it fresh, but make sure that there's enough nostalgia to make people cheer (or boo, in a good way). People did both cheer and boo in the theater. This was one of my favorite theater experiences ever, right up there with 'Jurassic Park,' 'Independence Day', and 'Toy Story.' It is not perfect. Yes, the plot-line seems a little redundant: good guys sneak into the bad guys' huge base to try and blow it up, and bad guys are looking for plans/maps that the good guys potentially have. Maybe they could have brain-stormed a little more in this regard. But so what? You didn't fall in love with Episodes 4-6 because you loved how the rebels blew up the Death Star... twice. You could argue that the plot-lines are better in Episodes 1-3, but since the screenplays are weak and you dislike many of the characters (and acting), Episodes 4-6 are far superior. You love Star Wars because of the characters and story arc. This is why you'll love the next three episodes. And no, the characters are NOT the same this time around. Is Rey a little like Luke? A little. Other than that, all of the new characters are original, even Kylo Ren. Kylo chooses to wear his mask BECAUSE of Vader. Kylo is unsure of himself. Vader was one of the most confident villains in history, until good overtook evil in 'Return of the Jedi.' Plus, Kylo is only good with the dark side of the force when he fully embraces it. Vader was much, much more powerful than Kylo when comparing Episode 4 with 7. Vader would have chuckled if Finn approached him with a lightsaber. Overall, this movie perfectly blends the new with the old. I do hope the plot takes us to a place we haven't been before. Regardless, I'll stick around to watch because of Rey, Kylo, Finn, Poe, Maz, and Snoke.

A film that only superficially captures the feeling of the originals, but is let down by it's lack of originality, it's predictability and it's poorly written new characters. Motivations are to be presumed as they're never explained and it's hard to feel any threat or attachment to any of the new cast because they're all blank slates, void of personality or individuality. Performances from all actors, Harrison Ford aside, feel hammy, twee and sometimes at odds with the brief backstories we have of these characters. The rehashed plot quickly becomes tiring, as apposed to the nostalgic romp they had aimed for. The positives mainly come from the exceptional design teams, cinematography and score.

The seventh episode of the beloved "Star Wars" saga successfully continues the story of a galaxy far far away that was left unfinished for so many years with a very great story to get involved into, the signature special effects and sound effects of the original six movies, bringing back the characters we all know and love with the original cast returning to reprise their roles while also introducing many great new characters along the way, and the cherry on top, this film successfully manages to do the unexpected and have moments that will leave you breathless and excited all at the same time! I will remember cheering with everyone else in the audience and the excitement from watching this movie. Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens is the best action movie I have seen this year!

Imagine a world where space travel is a way of life, hyperspace is standard in every ship, jedi mind tricks, you can move objects just by thinking. Imagine the infinite possibilities of writing a story in this world.Instead, the writers chose to recycle episode 4 and 5. The same old story, even though they have infinite material at their disposal. Just playing for the popular vote, making a previously successful formula under a new label, benefiting from the sentiments of the fans to make few quick bucks. So many opportunities of writing a good story lost. The many directions a story could have gone. Even the obvious plots of intrigue and suspense remained unexplored (For instance, why does R2D2 magically comes back to life, for no reason? why not let Rey have a key left to her which brings the droid back to life??) There were certainly some high points though. Han Solo character was portrayed masterfully. It was fun to see the millennium falcon again. Generally speaking an entertaining but a very safe movie. Unfortunately, I expected a bit more.

absolutely no character development, and virtually no fantasy element... Star Wars is a sci-fantasy. There were very few aliens and almost no use of the force. The characters are 1 dimensional and everything that happens is excessively implausible.

The movie the real Star Wars fans have been waiting for. The movie that helps you forget those abominations (Prequel Trilogy) existed. JJ Abrams creates the most visually stunning Star Wars film ever made by making what feels like a Greatest Hits of the Original Trilogy and a sequel to Return Of The Jedi in the same film. I personally loved the film as I didn't like the prequels due to the wooden Hayden Christensen, the awful and boring political plot, and last but not least everyone's FAVORITE Jar Jar Binks.You'll be happy to know that none of the negatives of the prequel trilogy are found in this soft reboot of Star Wars, and will also see that Han Solo was easily the most memorable character in this film. The protagonist Rey (Daisy Ridley) was an interesting character, and she did have some moments that felt very Deus Ex Machina or Mary-Sue ish, but was interesting nevertheless. Poe Damron (Oscar Issac) left a lasting impression, that bigger things were to come of the next film as the Rebels push further into battle as they attempt to thwart the evil empire. If you enjoyed the Original Trilogy, you will enjoy this film as it's easily on par with A New Hope. 4 1/2 out of 5

Absolutely brilliant! So much better than I anticipated. Visually lush, but it's the pacing that separates brilliant films from the merely good or great. Daisy Ridley, Joh Boyega and Oscar Isaac give great performances, but it's the writing that gives them the opportunity to make us fall in love with Star Wars again. Sorry, George, but the writing and filming of the prequels, the first three chapters, was so posed and stilted, the sets so flat in their CGI iterations, the performances so green screen stultified, The Force Awakens is a refreshing and exhilarating return to dynamic personalities and corny throwaway jokes and references that helped make A New Hope, The Empire Strikes Back and The Return of the Jedi such touchstones for so many fans. The tone and pacing are just brilliant, the sets so well made, the casting perfect and the writing an amazing balance of reverential and "oh, let's not take this too seriously". Kudos to everyone involved in the film and thank you for not allowing the story to leak out in advance of the film.
Star Wars: The Force Awakens is an outstanding return to formula. This movie captures the magic that the original trilogy did. My hat is off to you J.J Abrams, you made a true piece of art!
My inner child has awakened. Star Wars: The Force Awakens isn't just 2015's best movie, it's the most satisfying blockbuster I've seen in years.

Force Awakens, Looks in Mirror, Goes Back to Bed Again. Seriously.So, I purposefullly did not read anything before seeing this movie. Which is probably why I am so dumbfoundedly disappointed that it was a damn remake of the original. Let's break it down a little:- Disaffected youth in out of the way locale stumbles over rebellion. - Boy meets girl. - Girl kidnapped by Establishment to their planet-sized weapon base. (Again. Seriously?)- Father / Son duel over void. (Again. Seriously??)- Rebels rally and fly in to exploit weakness and blow up mega-weapon just before it can blow up planets. (Again. Seriously???)Come on.Out of a universe of possibilities, we get this slavish rehash? I think they even reused the loading graphic for the big weapon powering up.

Extremely faithful to the originals both in tone and style. Granted, it may seem like a rehash of Episode 4, but considering the way these trilogies progress, I'm not surprised nor am I disappointed. I am very interested in Finn, Rey, and the other new characters that we were introduced to and I look forward to seeing where this leads us!
Definitely not my favorite of 2015 by far, but sure is a enormous ride of fun and joy, and a very pleasant movie to everybody, including non-fans of the franchise.

Well, overall I was happy with this movie! When the first note of the theme blasted out and "Star Wars" popped up on the screen, I darn near jumped outta my seat with joy! And, like everyone who clapped in the theatre, I was super happy when I saw the old characters, and items, from parts 4, 5, and 6! And the action scenes and new characters were top notch! What I didn't love was, in my opinion, the overuse of humor. Some seemed totally out of place for what was happening. I also didn't love that some elements of the story were stories that "should be told at another time". I feel that's just a blatant way of saying, "If you want to know what happened, or how that came to be, you are going to have to buy another ticket." And finally, I just can't understand the plot that the Dark Side has the same basic plan of attach for the THIRD time! What, failing the first two times didn't convince you? Geee whiz! But, if you just watch the movie and don't get all over analytical like I did, it's totally worth it! Sooo much better than parts 1, 2, and 3! SOOOO much better!

Sorry, this new Star Wars episode is horrible, neither credible nor interesting. A sanitation worker can just pick up a light saber and battle a Vader-in-training character? Really? Where's Yoda when you need him most? I guess this generation has no patience for such character development, but it really detracted from the Star Wars magic of the force and all that. Instead you get a bunch of over-eager actors who escape one danger after another. Nothing compels the story along. No good vs. evil here.

I had more problems with it than I anticipated, but taken as simple entertainment it was okay. The effects were decent and it felt like in a galaxy far far away enough. What got me was how it was kind of too slow and too fast at the same time. Reams of exposition thrown into dialog that had a LOT of staring in between, instant plot as vehicle coincidences that seemed super fake, instant force mastery based on nothing, and a villain you might as well call Darth Emo. You can get any number of spoilers somewhere else, I'm not doing that, but a lot of things certainly don't add up. It's almost like a paint-by-number in it's simplistic setup for the next one which hopefully will be better.
Great transition from original trilogy and great kickstart to a new one. Funny and interesting characters, great cast, lots of really funny humor.

Flying in on an unbelievable amount of hype and anticipation, The Force Awakens is surprisingly able to meet and exceed the wildest expectations that fans of the series and general moviegoers could have possibly had. Its villain is genuinely unpredictable and refreshingly three-dimensional, fantastically acted by Adam Driver. Its protagonist is instantly relate-able and worthy to sit alongside the Luke Skywalkers and Obi Wan Kenobis of the Star Wars saga - an instant classic of a character. But most impressive is how the film manages to bring its old characters so seamlessly back to life, keeping them completely true to their old selves while also adding higher stakes to their story - most notably so is Han Solo, who has all the sly one-liners and cockiness of his old self while also being romantic and heartfelt when the situation is appropriate.The film delivers on every aspect a film is expected to. It's funny, often times hilarious. It's cute enough for the kids, but not so much so that the adult audiences are distracted from the story. Its plot reaches a satisfying climax and has many genuinely surprising twists along the way. What most seem to criticize about the film - that it's a "rip off" of the original Star Wars - is unbelievable false. Abrams was essentially rebooting the franchise, and wanted it to both be familiar and something completely new. The elements of the original trilogy that he incorporated in this film were deliberate tributes and homages. He was crafting a film for a new generation that welcomed fans of the old generation, and he did so beautifully and flawlessly. Star Wars: The Force Awakens is not only one of the very best Star Wars films, but it is a wonderfully entertaining and fantastic film in its own right - one of the very best of the year, period.
Not only a fun action adventure movie, but the film that brought my favorite franchise back to life! I'm so happy this was a good as it was.
JJ Abrams returns the magic to the SW Saga, emotional act of Harrison Ford (H.Solo). honor mention to Chewie, fresh apparence of the new characters. THE FORCE IS BACKKKK!!

I know you have to suspend disbelief for movies like this and it is part of the fun - BUT neither a young storm trooper nor a really young untrained girl can take up a light saber and go against an adversary who has trained for it most of his life. Some alternative talent that got them through this might have been appropriate. At least have them run and the bad guy gets his foot caught so he cannot move around giving them some inkling of a chance. There were moments I loved but all in all I an really glad I waited and saw it at a BIG discount, and that I didnt't pay extra for 3 d.

Periodically, the film exposes you to dialogue and events that just don't sit well with even a slightly analytical viewer, but does little to tether down a captivating adventure this film delivers. While certain moments of theatrical promise are shredded by the film's breakneck pace, and there come instances of distasteful CGI and script, The Force Awakens hits enough of the right notes.It's vastly enjoyable, but not nearly iconic nor influential as it provoked many into thinking it aspired to be.

Impossible for anyone not to enjoy. Everything was perfect. Bringing back my childhood heroes hit a lot of emotions. Possibly the best movie I've ever sat through. This is one film that without a doubt, deserves all the media recognition and record breaking achievements that it's been receiving.

I found some time to see this flick and hoped to find out if they got this franchise back on track as one of the most innovative and creative science fiction epics ever. But I was sorely disappointed to see so many great things (you've heard it all by now) developing during the first 40 minutes and then brought to ruins when the old cast enters from the original sequel entered, followed by a rapidly thinning plot and a befuddling conclusion whereby yet another death star is destroyed by the equivalent of a couple of Chinese firecrackers. Seriously, a moon or planet turned into a weapon of unimaginable power, capable of destroying entire worlds had its shield brought down so easily? What? You'd think the "Evil Empire" could think of a better way to protect their assets from the pesky rebels after two previous death stars are brought down by similar methods. Blah. And what about Princess Leia's weird appearance? I found myself wondering about Carrie Fischer's personal life right in the middle of the movie. I understand a StormTrooper could suddenly develop a need to defect, but the way it was done made me think that thousands of others would eventually do the same. So much is missing from this movie. Rottentomatoes critics gave it a 93% rating and this is surprising. What was J.J. Abrams and his Co. thinking? Perhaps they were trying to appease too many different fan groups. This movie had the makings of a great turnaround story, but it fell flat on its face. The true winners are the moviemakers, toymakers and the entire Disney franchise as they cash in on this clunker. The good news is the original cast work and cgi of the first 40 minutes could bode well for a fantastic second film next year. Even so, I will temper my expectations for the next one.

Abrams, Lawrence Kasdan, Michael Arndtwas) was not up to the Lucas/Star Wars standard viewers expect . The movie lacked flow and continuity as it jumped from scene to scene.
