Consistently satisfying return to the Star Wars saga. As someone who grew up with the original, seeing Hans Solo gave me chills. I'm not sure what to think of this but i was interested, cried, and got chills that has to be worth something right?

After seeing the film 3 times in the cinema (and I may yet go a 4th time), the only word to describe the movie is simple: amazing! At last the spirit of the original movies has returned. Not since 'Return of the Jedi' have I seen a Star Wars which felt like a Star Wars film. Not to say the prequels were terrible (which they're not), but they felt too polished. Star Wars is a movie that although is set in space with lightsabers, Jedi's, monsters and laser guns, they still felt real in a weird way. The prequels were too CGI driven... 'The Force Awakens' feels like something you can reach out and touch, similar to the original trilogy. Story wise, yes there are big similarities to 'A New Hope', but that doesn't take away the amazing effort that JJ Abrams did to give the movie that special touch. Star Wars is back in top form, and I can't wait to see what happens next in Episode VIII.

While Star Wars the Force Awakens is not a perfect movie, it is still an entertaining and fun movie that brings us back to the Star Wars universe the way fans deserve. The acting is great as we have some fresh blood by the likes of John Boyega (Finn) and Daisy Ridley (Rey) and not to mention Adam Driver, they did a great job on playing their characters and actually made us care about them, unlike the prequels. Of course Harrison Ford gives a great performance as a mature and wise Han Solo. The special effects are completely out of the charts, it's no surprise it got nominated in the Oscars on that department, and the story is great, though I found starkiller base completely unnecessary. The film is well written and directed and beautifully shot, props to J.J Abrams and his crew. Star Wars the Force Awakens is a great movie that recalls the sagas glory while having a new formula and fresh blood. It's worth seeing on any time of the day and that is why I give it an A

A hollow quotation of "A New Hope." Desert Planet? Check!Droid that has all-secret plans to a super-weapon? Check! Death Star? Nope, because it is a BIGGER DEATH STAR. Get it? This unimaginative trite also is a blatant ripoff of the Jedi Academy Books.

So as far as hype goes, Star Wars: The Force Awakens really takes all the cake and credit, and so it should, considering the hype and fan base it has been rolling with for well over 30 years. With its name being recognized world wide as a creative masterpiece into the futuristic world of Sci-Fi and even benefiting science in many ways by fueling ideas and technologies which could in fact appear in a very near future of our own and not so far far away. But is the latest Star Wars movie really all its hyped up to be? Does it fit with how you'd imagine a present day Star Wars film to be? Does it engage and applaud its predecessors? Does it fill you with excitement?For me I found, not really. Don't get me wrong here, I'm a Star Wars fan, the movie was great! It had great moments with figures like Maz Kanata and even bringing back Han, Leia & Luke to add a strong backbone and familiarity to the movie as well as increase its potency and flow. Some of the planets showcased for example the Resistance based planet of D'Qar with its outer asteroid ring showed the beauty of Star Wars that I loved. Yet after all this hype I've seen the movie receive, I couldn't quite help but feel that my expectations hadn't quite been met, it lacked so much that a true Star Wars film imbued, and no I'm not talking about Jar-Jar Binks. As a child, like most, I grew up watching it and living with it and even experiencing with it the changes and excitement it brought to our senses and to the world. It brought ideas and creation, it in total brought the future to us. Star Wars always had a knack for being far far, but in fact not so very far away. The future they showcased seemed quite believably close indeed, with an exception of force abilities, but then again who knows what the future might hold in that retrospect. With the new movie i felt like it didn't quite capture this at all, with the director choosing to lower the use of CGI and incorporate more realistic stunts and scenery, which i felt gave the movie a more mundane appearance to its predecessors that George Lucas brought to life. It lacked the visuals in which Star Wars used to bring with city gargantuan planets like Coruscant, seeing only remakes of old planets like Tatooine (Jakku), Hoth and the rebels base on D'Qar - Which in turn just looked like a casual country side in England. If Jakku wasn't so similar to Tatooine I would have been impressed, but then it does make sense that Tatooine isn't the only desert planet amongst so many worlds. Might I add that the world at the end was literally our own, yes Iceland got an appearance in our 'futuristic' films with no incorporation of otherworldly creatures or scenery flying past, apart from the Millennium Falcon that is, to give it a Star Wars nostalgia, instead they just cropped a scene from right out of National Geographic's Channel and oddly lacked a voice over by David Attenborough. It gave an impression that the directors lacked new material, and in turn decided to reproduce many things in this movie, one including the large similarities between A New Hope's plot and scripts entirety, not just planets. Many unanswered questions about the might of the Rebel Alliance at the end of Return Of the Jedi, being so powerful and full of capitol ships, with thousands of worlds under their belt and space combat, now being reduced to smaller planet bases, and even less so after the Death Star: Mark III weapon attack. Will the Empire ever learn??The carefree use of Supreme Lord Snoke's name became cringe worthy as the film progressed, using his name frequently throughout, like uttering such words had no consequence to anyone. He wasn't the 'New Emperor shrouded in looming shadow', he was 'SNOKE the well known leader of the First Order'. There was no secrecy, no hidden agenda's, no scary mystery shrouding this new Sith-like figurehead that the late Palpatine had had whom managed to infiltrate the senate amongst other things. Because one thing I'd learnt from practitioners of the Dark Side, is that they like to remain hidden. Even more so the mystery was shattered when they outright showed him in his entirety, face, voice, convictions and all.New characters like Rey, Poe Dameron & Maz Kanata really brought a shine to the new generation of Star Wars and the movie, I must say. Rey literally, with her pleasant acting was a pleasing little ray of sunshine that made you feel like you really wanted to care for her, like you were there in the movie with her. She also showed small psychical appearances to a young Anakin Skywalker from The Phantom Menace, it only gives you ideas of where they are going with her character. Poe with his die hard skills and charming antics that linked a similar resemblance to a young Luke Skywalker with features of Han Solo. Making you wonder if he has any perception of the force with his skills, but probably not considering he fits the bill of the scoundrel. And of course Maz Kanata with her wise mentality and feel like that of a female version of Grand Master Yoda, you could feel the knowledge about her. Disappointment struck to learn that many scenes of Maz Kanata, one in particular showing her using the force to bring down rubble over Storm Troopers, were removed before the movies screen debut, which would have only improved the movies core, but would have potentially brought up questions truthfully as to why she couldn't train Rey in her knowledge as she knew she was force sensitive.Characters like Finn, Kylo Ren, Captain Phasma & even General Hux really let down the movie in more ways than one, whether it was due to the writers or directors their characters really lacked on screen and gave the movie a hindrance more than anything.Finn the young Storm Trooper whom as a child was taken into the First Order displayed too many traits of that of a typical street kid or smuggler, not something you'd expect from a brain washed Storm Trooper trained and conformed into a rigorous society of order and dominance at such a young age where most of his teachings from before being taken would have been wiped clean, yet looking at Captain Phasma that probably explains it.Kylo Ren, the mysterious yet not so mysterious dark padawan and son of Han and Leia Solo who when angry manages to destroy everything around him in anger fits, which for a part was humorous and amusing, was known from the get go, his evil antagonist role had no mystery or backbone to stand up with. His boyish and awkward acting skills really didn't do the character much justice. (And people complained about Hayden Christensen acting as Anakin!?) But I must applaud that he did portray conflict in his mind quite okay. Showing no remorse with the murder of his father Han Solo at his hand gave his character more build and further into the ending battle with him, Finn and Rey finally gave his character the justice it deserved, scarring his face at the end Rey set us up with a meaner potential Sith for Episodes 8 and 9.Captain Phasma was just the saddest of them all, whether it was the directors placements of her character or to her lack of lines in the movie her character had no purpose accept to stand in the background looking shiny and being partly responsible for destroying her own planetary base for the Resistance. Was I not the only one who was expecting her to be a Boba/Jango Fett like character that had a large kill record? She didn't quite fit the bill of bad ass in my opinion, which you'd certainly expect from someone who is classed with the grand title of Captain amongst fellow Storm Troopers. She showed no strength or skill, being just a figurehead that walks around with a gun 24/7 that might I add am under the impression is made of plastic, doesn't seem to have any ammo and is just for show. She has no real purpose other than to tell others to keep their helmets on and fire their weapons. Even the mysterious Storm Trooper that Finn confronted at Maz Kanata's Castle who countered his light saber had more pizzazz!And lastly the young General Hux who's appearance and age didn't quite sit right with me, making me think that maybe all the older more wise Generals and Imperialists were killed back on the Death Star at the Battle of Endor some 30 years beforehand. But he did have skill enough to escape the planet with Kylo's wounded body before explosion, so we have to give him props for that right??I would have loved if they incorporated scenes from The Battle of Jakku, starting instead the movie with the war between the remnants of the Empire and the Rebel Alliance 29 years ago, showcasing the calamities and losses in which both sides received. The idea of seeing Star Destroyers drop out of the sky and large scale planetary combat would have been delicious icing on a beautiful cake and taken me back to the Clone Wars and Revenge of the Sith days.I'm hoping the eighth installment of the Star Wars franchise will improve, with rumors speculating that it will be a much darker film. Slightly worrying me to the point that the script could mirror The Empire Strikes Back, but honestly I just want to see more 'bad assery', space battles with capitol ships and most certainly more Jedi's. And certainly a less predictable script. With a new director helming this movie let us hope his understanding of the Star Wars Galaxy is much more in-depth than the last!

WHAT I LIKED: A film with so much hype rarely lives up to expectations - but the 'The Force Awakens' exceeds them all. It's just truly amazing. Watch brilliant characters in a film that credits the originals whilst moving forward in the most exciting way possible. We've never seen a film that encompasses so much in terms of tone and emotion, that still pulls it off with such continuity and sensitivity. You can really tell everything was beautifully crafted by every hand in it's making; 'Episode 7' is beautifully acted, directed, scored and shot to the most incredible standard. But there's more to this than all those achievements, Abrams pulls off a movie that genuinely makes you feel every emotion. It makes you laugh, cry and despair, gives you chills and makes you grin from ear to ear. And what's more, it FEELS like Star Wars (which is sadly why it's getting the criticism it is.) The visual cues, the score, it all harks back to a long time ago in a galaxy far away. Everything about this, the new characters and the old, is everything I wanted it to be and so much more more. Whether you're a Star Wars fan, or not - this is the must see movie of 2015.WHAT I DIDN'T LIKE: The odd clunky scenes are there, and whilst I don't agree it was too formulaic, the Starkiller ending is a little bit of a rip off of 'Episode 4.'VERDICT: History is made. 'The Force Awakens' is a spine-tinglingly beautiful piece of film that does so much so sensitively. Star Wars is back, crowning Abrams as the new king of film.

Don't believe the hype, don't believe the raving fanboys and by no means believe the blatantly lying, Disney-bought critics. This is a storyless and soulless, stinking POS. It also feels like a sligthly too long (2hrs worth) movie trailer made by hipsters who think that having the old, "genuine" special effects is more important than having a story. 3/10. 1 for the genre, 1 for Harrison Ford and 1 for Chewie.

Star Wars Episode IV the remake: best way to describe this. 80% of this movie is a copy and paste of the original trilogy's first film the New Hope.There are good things with this film; the intro and very end scene are suspenseful with nice payoff: but I feel that they stand out because of their originality. Had the film gone that route: to make clearly original scenes and story, it could stand on its own: this film does have 5 star material. But as I said, overall it's a copy and paste of Episode IV.The main reason why I think this is because of the appearance and clothing along with their role in the story. Rey the hero has Luke's desert-peasant attire, Ren the villain is trying WAY to hard to be a new Vader, Hux the general is Tarkin. These characters look almost identical in many ways.Even the story and settings are painfully obvious; the desert planet, the snow planet, the Deathier Star. The x wings bombing the Death Star, the Yoda teachings of the force, the bar scene, the Falcon shooting about 2 Tie Fighters: all clearly present.The characters I will remember are Snoke (very big and intimidating while still old and frail), Maz, BB 8 and Phasma. But again; Emperor, Yoda (both old and short too!), R2D2 and Boba Fett (cold mysterious masked badass that fans will adore despite doing jack shit in the story).But I will say this; who the hell is FN-2199? 'That guy that shouts "traitor!"' just shows up with a psudo-lightsaber and fights Finn. I want to see more of this dude. Also some of the new aliens are entertaining to look at.But of course there's more things to talk about;Kylo Ren had some big shoes to fill; considering everyone knows that he's this film's Darth Vader. But his execution is that of Anakin Skywalker; in that it fails. His mask and lightsaber are okay but he clearly shares Anakin's tantrums and wimpiness; making him more of an angsty teen than a scary supervillain. He wasn't as terrible as Hayden Christensen, but the similarities exist. Combine this with the 'daddy issue plot' stolen from IV and being a Vader fanboy, and it makes things worse.Also there are times where the film is either rushed or elements of the film have no buildup; Death Star 3.0 and the planets it destroyed are good examples of this; if I knew about these things I would be preparing myself for the fireworks instead of having them gloss over so quickly.I have no idea who Rey is as a character; in that the film keeps on changing her personality. This isn't character evolution; it's sloppy inconsistency. She starts out as a poor hardworking badass genius, and then is suddenly constantly panicking like a headless chicken, then she becomes Luke. If she evolved, she would still show the traits of her past self, but that is never implied.Han Solo and his sidekick Chewie played their roles fine, afterall they are directly relevant to the backbone of this plot. And it made sense to have Luke have such importance in the plot. However everyone else felt shoehorned in; oh hi Ackbar! Hey R2D2, want to see your replacement?Finn was a breath of fresh air: his character was unique for his normalcy and flaws and his despair in his introduction was very emotional, but he was quite annoying at times. Also the sudden implied romance between him and Rey didn't feel subtitle. Infact the comedy of the film was quite hit or miss, some moments felt so stupid and hammy that they broke the flow of the film sometimes. Though you did have good things as well; like BB's lighter thumbsup.I would say that while this film was entertaining, it was a remake more than it was a sequel. The film was too self conflicted in what it really wanted to be: something new or something stuck in the past.

???? 1/2Thtien Sota -tarinana mielenkiintoinen, joskin lainaa aivan selvsti alkuperisest trilogiasta, hiukan liikaakin. esim. autiomaaplaneetta Tatoiine -> Jakku; Empire-Rebellion -> First Order-Resistance; Emperor-Vader -> Snoke-Ren; Vader-Luke -> Solo-Ren; ja lopputaistelu on Death Star- klooni. Onhan tss kloonattu muutenkin aika hurjasti originaalista trilogiasta, jo ihan se idea ett droidi tuo kartan phenkillle (ekassa leffassahan R2-D2 vie Kuolonthden kartan Leia Organalle) ja Luke muuten mys etsii erakkona elv Obi-Wan Kenobia kuten Rey tss uudessa leffassa erakkona elv Lukea. Mutta tosiaan, good artists copy, great artists steal...Lavasteet, planeetat ja maisemat ovat onnistuneita, musiikin vaisuus ylltti (onhan kuitenkin John Williams kyseess). Erikoisefektit ovat hienoja yleisesti ottaen, mik toki oli odotettavissa, olivathan Abramsin Star Trek-leffatkin aivan ensiluokkaisia niilt osin. Leffana ihan jnn, ei pitkveteinen, tarina etenee tasaisesti.Plussaa olivat mys Han Solo salakuljettajana, Chewbacca, monstereita, palkkionmetsstji, tmpuoli jnyt jopa hiukan liian vhlle alkuperisess trilogiassa (paitsi Imperiumin vastaiskussa toki). Idea tosi lupaava ja legendaariset hahmot palaavat ja tm viritt suuria odotuksia thtien sota fanissa. Mutta.. sitten kauhea jrkytys ja pettymys, ett tm ei toteudukaan, koskaan. Ilke yhtkkinen temppu leffan tekijilt, menemtt tarkemmin yksityiskohtiin. Toki luova oikeus taiteilijoilla mutta silti.Henkilt, joita toki paljon, jvt hiukan pinnallisiksi. Esim. Solo ja Leia, jotka sentn antavat helpoimmalla tavalla leffan tekijille emotionaalisen syvyyden tunnun mahdollisuutta. Monesti ihmetteli, mist tllainen tyyppi on tullut? Ei nit kerrota katsojalle. Nit henkilit on ksitelty Extended Universumin kirjallisuudessa, mutta ei voida olettaa joka katsojan tuntevan ko. legendariumia. Prinsessa Leia nytt liian monessa kohtauksessa ilmeettmlt. First Orderin ijt vain kornit ja hassut, siin miss vaikkapa Terence Fischerin esittm Tarkin oli originaalin trilogian 1. leffassa aivan uniikki hahmo. Tss sellaisia hiukan pahveja iji vaahtoaa.Leffojen jlkeen on kehittynyt kirjallisuuteen ns. expanded universe / laajennettu maailmankaikkeus, jossa henkiliden tarinat ovat kehittyneet pitklle. Jaina, Han Solon ja Prinsessa Leian tytr oli Jedi, leffassa Kylon kanssa samanikisest Reyst tulee mys Jedi. Olisiko Rey siis Luken tytr.. ?Jedihommat onnistuneet muuten, mutta jokin tuossa Reyn Jedi-hommassa hiritsee. Toki jonkin intuition piikkiin voi tss kohden panna aika paljon; eli miten Rey osaa tehd jotain Jedi Mind Trickej ilman koulutusta ja voittaa koulutetun Sithin? Jediytt olisi voinut koittaa ehti hiukan enemmn sivuamaan dialogissa, jotta avautuisi asiaa tietmttmille katsojille. Tosin osasihan Lukekin posauttaa protonitorpedon ilman thtystietokonetta metrin mittaisesta ilmastointiluukusta sislle satojen kilometrien tuntinopeudella ajomoottoreilla kapeassa huoltovylss lentvss X-Wing hvittjssn, Vaderin & co. samaan aikaan hengittess niskaan, melkein lonkalta tuhoten Kuolonthden, ilman minknlaista koulutusta. Kylo Ren on jotenkin lapsipuolimaisen avuton ja kolhon oloinen, mik vhn hiritsi, tosin mestarinsahan totesi leffassa ett hn ei ole viel "Dark Jedi" eli koulutus on viel kesken. (Lukehan oli Imperiumin vastaiskussa ihan avuton lhtiessn kohtaamaan Vaderia kesken koulutuksen ja koko homma meni ihan mnkn - ptyi roikkumaan p ylsalaisin Bespinin pilvikerroksiin ilman toista kttn, henkisesti traumatisoituneena) Reyt ajatellen voihan olla, ett ispapan valomiekan (jolla yllttvn voimakas efekti Reyhin) kyttminen antaa liskykyj, jos kyse Luken tyttrest - muistattehan, ett tm odotti kadonneita iti ja isns. Luke Skywalkerkin tulee kuvaan lopussa, ahavoituneena. Ihan hyv, ettei puhu mitn, saa fani tytt tuskaisen kasvojen ilmeen Dark Empiren ja muiden legendaaristen tarinoiden muistoilla. Jedihomma, vaikka hiukan horjuukin, silti toimii, vaikkei mitn leffassa mainittua jeditemppeli varsinaisesti esitellkn. ps. tm Luken tuskainen ilmekin selittyisi, jos Rey olisi tytr. Saapas nhd miten asia on, sitten joskus jatko-osassa VIII. Kivasti nkyi nit aiemmista leffoista tuttuja juttuja jotka Star Wars fani tunnistaa:Tatoiinen cantinaa muistuttava erilaisine galaksia asuttavine olioineen (jopa monikulttuurinen Cantina-Bndi lytyy soittamasta!); "Bantha"-laumat laiduntamassa hiekkadyyneill; Romunkerj-"Jawat"; Jedien paluu ja muutenkin uskollisesti toteutettu; Millenium Falconin "vanha romu ylltt"-meininki; Amiraali Ackbar (se joka sanoo Jedin Paluussa "It's a trap!"); Star Destroyerit ja AT-AT romut autiomaassa Imperiumin jljilt, joitakin mainitakseni. Ei Abrams minusta liikaa panosta aiempaan ja liehittele faneja (ajatelkaa vain Jar Jar Binksi), vaan tt voi pit sopivana "kunnianosoituksena" Star Wars-trilogialle (sille oikealle ja ainoalle). Solon tarina olisi voitu hienommin ksitell tss kyll, ja se kirpaisi tosiaan ikvsti, mutta ei siit nyt oikein miinusta voi antaa, kun se on kerran Lucasin hyvksym "Virallinen totuus".Ihan hieno leffa, ja ehdottomasti parempi kuin Lucasin prequel leffat, joskaan ei ihan missn tapauksessa eeppinen ole kuitenkaan. Tie Fightereista tulee se viimeinen plussa, joka kohottaa tmn sellaiselle tasolle, ett voin sanoa tykkvni leffasta. Tie pilottien kyprien kimallus Tien ohjaamossa, Tien ohjaamon lyhyt esittely kun loikkari-Stormtrooper 'Finn' ja Poe Dameron varastavat sellaisen, ja Falconin takaa-ajo hiekkadyyneille pudonneen Star Destroyerin oikeanpuoleisen pmoottorin suuttimeen ja ilmeisesti apumoottorin rjhdyksess syntyneen aukon kautta ulos rungosta ovat hienosti toteutettuja. Aika huonoja nm Imperium-wannabe pilotit ovat. Star Wars Eeppisyys nkyy, joka hiukan tosin krsii erst jrkytyksest johtuen. Tykksin kyll, mutta tprll oli (Auringonlaskua vasten nkyvt Tie Fighterit ratkaisivat tmn asian). 4,5 / 5 Plussat ja miinukset+ erikoisefektit, rjhdykset, valomiekat yms. hienosti tehty+ tarinankerronta etenee mielenkiintoisella tavalla, vaikkakin kopioitu hiukan liikaa aiemmista leffoista. Riittvsti toimintaa.- hahmojen mahdollisuuksia ei hydynnet, taustat hmrt+ maisemat, nkymt, planeetat ja musiikki keskitasoa parempia.+ Jedit onnistuneet, toisin kuin Lucasin uudemmissa leffoissa. Transsendentin elementin lsnolo.+ Hollywoodin rasismin tydellinen puuttuminen! Pakko antaa tst erillinen plussa. Pparikin on mustavalkoinen. On niin monikulttuurista ja -kokoista sakkia, ett tuli ihan Frasierin Noelin lausahdus mieleen: "A man called Gene Roddenberry had a vision!". + Tie hvittjt ovat yllttvn suuressa osassa, ja toteutus onnistunut poikkeuksellisen hyvin. (Ainoastaan Tie Interceptoreita jin kaipailemaan, mutta se olisi kai ollut liikaa vaadittu)+ Pienet detaljit, puvustus, alienit nauttimassa virvokkeita, droidit piipittelemss vanhaan malliin+ Han Solo, Millenium Falcon ja Chewie! Tss kolmikossa nyt vain on jotain ihan legendaarista.

I've now seen Star Wars: The Force Awakens twice. I have to admit that I, a Star Wars fan since 1977, felt a bit let down after my first viewing. It was a very good movie, but I wasn't sure if it was a good _Star Wars_ movie. I felt much more positive after the second viewing, when I tried harder to just experience the film instead of analyzing it for its Star Wars-ness. It's not perfect, but I think the franchise is moving in a new and exciting direction.The negatives: the film is just a bit too long. The climactic battle drags on longer than it needs to. The plot is a bit too reminiscent of the first Star Wars. The film is full of dialogue, music, and images that evoke the first film. It's fun in a nostalgic sort of way, but becomes a bit distracting and overdone. Finally, the astrophysics of the movie don't add up. I know this is space fantasy, not science fiction, but planets seem to be too close together and travelling between them seems to take no time at all. Hyperspace travel in Star Wars has always been inconsistently presented, but The Force Awakens takes it to a new level of improbability.The positives: the cast is fantastic. It was great to see the familiar faces blending with new and interesting characters. Although the music and the visuals sometimes harken back too much to the original films, there are still many moments that are fresh, yet still feel like Star Wars. The special effects are astounding. Finally, this movie is just _fun_.Star Wars has been giving me fun for almost 40 years, and it looks like the fun is going to continue for at least a few years more. Impressive! Most impressive!

The first Star Wars movie I got to watch at the cinema,and my God was it spectacular!It never felt so powerful,real and amazing before!I enjoyed every new aspect of the movie and I loved the new characters in comparison to the ones that I had to get used to in the prequels.I have bittersweet feelings about how this movie is about the new generation and not that much about the old one.I loved how I got to meet my beloved characters anew.This movie felt more like an introduction to the new storyline and the new series,it had its amazing moments,and there were plenty of them,but still it didn't manage to make me fully and deeply blown out.I have to say I was expecting that turn in the story and still it managed to break my heart.I don't know.I suppose I liked it,but I didn't love it.Still a very good start to the sequel series and a very good addition to the original franchise!One is for certain:Star Wars is surely a family affair! PS:Watched it a second time.I loved it now!I can't wait for the nest episode!

Star Wars: The Force Awakens, a direct sequel to the original Star Wars trilogy, revitalizes the franchise, delivering an exciting and action-packed space adventure. In the wake of the disappearance of Luke Skywalker, the last Jedi Knight, two rival factions, the Resistance and the First Order, chase after a driod that contains a map to Skywalker's secret location. The plot is quite similar to that of the first Star Wars; changing out the Death Star plans for a map, Darth Vader for Kylo Ren, and a nave farm boy for a scavenger. Yet it still has its own style and tone that both homages the original trilogy and does its own thing. Additionally, newcomer Daisy Ridley has great screen presence and gives a strong performance. Also, the special effects are incredibly well-done, as are the sets and costumes. With Star Wars: The Force Awakens, J.J. Abrams has returned the series back to its roots.

This could have gone so badly wrong. After making such a huge success of reclaiming the characters of Star Trek (along with the complexity of adding in Spock Prime), Abrahms was probably less daunted by reigniting the ensemble cast than how to move on the look of the Star Wars universe without lampooning it in the same way the prequels had. Anyone who reads the concept art book of the Force Awakens will be able to see the fine levels of what might have been, much of which feels familiar but could have quickly gotten out of control. On that basis, the film is closely aligned to the spirit of the original trilogy - close on story - but gets over the establishment of characters and egos in the first film of the new trio. This was an important aspect in the success of the film - unmasking Kylo Ren in the first film and establishing the vulnerability in each characters back pocket. Solo, Leia, Luke, Chewbacca - all perfectly placed and riffing on their original sensibilities. Rey and Finn well matched and strongly diversified from the original cast in tone, banter and acting ability. This was a strong showing from Disney and Abrahms and relights the flame after it was sourly put out by the prequel era. The real world effects and seamless blending of technologies need to produce such a visual spectacle earn it the 5 star treatment and put J.J. into the stratosphere as the successor to Lucas and Spielberg in the craft of big budget story telling for the masses. Bring on VIII

O filme realmente  bem interesante: destaque para a ateno dada s cenas (efeitos especiais, som, cenas de ao, etc.) e s atuaes, que realmente foram boas, especialmente as de Daisy Ridley e John Boyega, os dois novos protagonistas, Rey e Finn, e a do Adam Driver, o Kylo Ren. Contudo, para mim, pecou em um nico aspecto: as motivaes de dois personagens, que considero muito importantes para todo o enredo. Achei muito superficiais e ilgicas as motivaes de Kylo Ren, para aderir ao lado negro, bem como as de Luke para se ixolar. De um lado um vilo que  uma criana mimada e que  incapaz de entender as motivaes de Darth Vader, e do outro um grande mito, um heri, que se espelha em seu primeiro mestre (Obi Wan Kenobi) ao se ixolar, mas que no o faz por razes realmente importantes e fortes. Obi Wan se ixola para proteger o prprio Luke e a princesa Leia de Darth Vader, assim como, podemos at dizer, pelo remorso de que seu discipulo tenha acabado com toda a ordem jedi. Luke o faz porque seu sobrinho destruiu o ressurgimento da ordem jedi, o que at parece um pouco com uma das razes de Obi Wan, mas a diferena est em como  apresentado no decorrer do filme esse fato. Parece que Luke  muito, mas muito froxo. Obi Wan ao menos tenta deter o que Anaquim est fazendo, o que fica claro logo no espisdio I (fica claro que Obi Wan se opoz e tentou deter o que estava ocorrendo, no diz como ele se ope, mas fica evidente que ele tentou lutar), e alm disso ele no desiste simplesmente, sua recluso est fundamentada na esperana de que Luke se tornar o jedi que vencer aos sits (o que tambm fica claro em seu reencontro com Luke, j que fica no mesmo planeta em que o rapaz est). Luke, do modo como  abordado no episdio VII, parece simplesmente ter abandonado todo mundo porque ficou chatiadinho com o que o sobrinho fez. Nesse segundo caso, ento, o problema no est tanto na motivao, mas na forma como ela  transmitida. Espero que Luke o tenha feito aguardando o momento certo e no somente por ter ficado deprimido. E sim estou dando uma avaliao de 7.5 de 10 s por isso, pois para mim no existe nada mais importante num filme do que a histria, ainda mais quando so aspectos relacionados a dois personagens to importantes para a trama.

The Force Awakens is better than all of the prequels and better than most of the originals. The characters are amazing and so is the director, J.J. Abrams who gave Star Wars fans everything they wanted and more.

I felt the best thing about The Force Awakens was Abrams' direction. It was confident, and he was able to successfully create a film that stands as a great film on its own, while also paying homage to the Star Wars films that came before it. Now aside from the cinematography which was quite top-notch, nothing else was really that outstanding. I personally didn't find the film very funny, but at least it did have a light-hearted tone and wasn't completely melodramatic like the prequels, the acting was good but not amazing, the plot was good but seemed too similar to A New Hope and was therefore not really unique, the effects were good aside from the big alien bad guy (which I felt was the least realistic and worst part of the film), and so forth. So yes, I very much enjoyed the film, and it's perhaps even the most entertaining film of the entire saga, and probably the one with the best cinematography, but the fact that none of it was incredible can't let me give the film anything higher than an 8/10.

**SPOILERS**To begin, I am a fan of the original series. Big time. I grew up with those movies. Great story telling with purpose. I was hesitant to see TFA, but went in with a clear opinion. I mean it couldn't have been worse than the recent prequels, could it? Well, the first 20 minutes had some promise, the actors were excellent, the effects were decent, but the rest of the movie? Simply put, when I left, the theatre I was angry and ranted on the way to the car(waited til I was outside - away from people). The movie lacked soul.I'm just going to rant in paragraph points...Another Death Star - guess the rebels didn't bother to keep tabs on the Empire, they just keep building them. Oh yes, and like the other DS this one could be blown up with X-wings, even easier this time. High five everyone, we did the same thing we've seen in the other movies.Rebels - somehow they went from freeing the Galaxy to hiding on a planet again, while, somehow everyone let the Empire build itself back up to the army it was before.Han Solo and Chewie - though nice to see, why are they smuggling again? Han had a child with Leia, so clearly they had a life for a while. When Han needed "a break", did Chewie just sit in a closet to wait for them to resume the life of smuggling they left all those years ago? Chewie never met anyone? Non-sense.Main Villian - somehow, he got his hands on Vaders burned helmet after Luke performed the funeral ritual decades before he was even born. So...who was able to find the Vader helmet in the ashes and why? Anyhoo, so the main villian is Han and Leia's child. Not surprised. The movie says he was under the tutoring of Luke (who was now a master Jedi), but like Vader was turned to the dark side. You mean to tell me, Luke couldn't sense this happening? AND even if he couldn't sense it, wouldn't he be extra paranoid given the history of his own father? Vader wanna be threw two tantrums in the movie, which looked ridiculous. The 2nd tantrum, he was beating up a room, and in the hallway some storm troopers (who were on patrol - to protect the building, you know like their job). Not knowing who or what was going on in the room ahead, one taps the other to walk away from...the noise. Made no sense. Makes me sick to talk about the rest, but here we go. So they show (Vader wanna be) stopping a laser blast with the force early in the movie, but later he has difficulty fighting Quinn and the girl. Neither of them were fighters (heck Quinn was the janitor). Instead of using the force to push them both off the cliff or crush them with some trees, they get away. Oh wait! Sorry Quinn gets stabbed in the spine with the sabre. But don't worry...it was only a light sabre, we see later, he's going to be fine. What else? Oh the (Vader wanna be) wears a respirator type mask (like Vader) most of the movie, but not for health reasons...maybe just for fun? Boring....character.....So later in the movie Han confronts his son on a skinny bridge with no railings, and (Vader wanna be) kills him. I saw Han fall of the bridge dead, Chewie screams, and I just sat in the theatre not giving a crap.C3PO - has a brief appearance, where for laughs I guess, he says to Han Solo. "You might not remember me because of my one red arm, and then reminds Han of who he is. I guess Han has a poor memory or something. Purely tossed in their for a laugh , as I heard some chuckling behind me. WTF?R2D2 - supposedly powered himself off for decades because Luke vanished. No comment...ridiculous.Map to Luke - The rebels find the pieces to complete the map to Luke, and for the morons, they show the maps coming together like puzzle pieces. I did not understand the straight yellow lines drawn on the space map. Is that how space travel works? Forget the girls name.... (lead character). I liked her charisma and acting, but the character itself was lame. She went from not knowing how to fly a ship to flying like an expert when some tie-fighters show up. She later finds Luke's old sabre in the basement of a saloon. Not sure what it was doing there, and don't care. Lame. Also, she keeps going on about getting back home to wait for her parents. I have news for her...THEY LEFT YOU WHEN YOU WERE A KID!! YOU ARE NOW A TEENAGER, THEY AREN"T COMING BACK!!!!End of movie - The girl (main character) arrives at the point on the map where Luke now resides. Instead of meeting her ship (because he should have known she was coming, Force or no Force (hard to miss a ship flying your way, when you live on an island). Nope, instead he's standing on a cliff, his back to the girl with a hooded cloak on. When she approaches him, he turns, almost surprised and then stares at the sabre she holds out to him for what seemed like 15 minutes, just her holding it and him staring at it. You mean, a Master Jedi could'nt have built another sabre in that time? Did it really mean that much to him? And....roll end credits....and begin my hot rage.I will not be seeing the other movies. This was a pure marketing machine, which sucked people in to see piece of garbage. When all was said and done, there was nothing new, no characters I cared for (go ahead, kill them all), no thrills, no new revelations, no new story arcs, no suspense. Yep, it was another rehash, almost a remake attempt. Sucked so bad. I'm sticking with the original three as the entire story. It was solid. Nuff said.
Does this movie have some flaws? sure, but overall, this movie is really really good! and I highly recommend it to anyone

J.J. Abrams has faithfully stewarded the most important film in the history of the Star Wars franchise. The Force Awakens uses familiar echoes from the original saga to carry us forward into a story that is as thrilling as it is compelling. A true passing of the torch if ever there was one, The Force Awakens uses the strong performances of the original cast to warm our hearts while simultaneously using the exciting and fresh performances of its new cast to blow our minds. The original cast reminded us of where we are, but the new cast made us excited about where we are going, and I, for one, no longer have a bad feeling about this.

JJ has done a fantastic job with the force awakens. It's as near to the greats as we're going to get. After counting down the days to this film for years I'm relieved I wasn't disappointed. For me The force awakens ranks a very worthy 3rd place behind hope in 1st followed by empire.For the first time since the originals I genuinely felt I was watching a true Star Wars movie. It was all good fun, a great adventure, with both despair and hope reigning side by side. Force Awakens has some truly memorable and classic Star Wars moments.Visuals were stunning, successfully merging new CGI with practical old school effects creating a beautiful piece of art.At its heart the force awakens is a simple story about our new characters who come together to go on an epic journey which allows us to catch up with our beloved Star Wars legends.While a great film it wasn't without its flaws. But the difference here, compared to the prequels, is that it's flaws weren't game changes; they didn't ruin the film. Namely the biggest flaw for me was the rehashing of plots and elements from the old films. The mysteries it introduced, while fun and wet our appetite for future films, meant the film lacked (in places) meaning and context.

Excitement is too small of a word to sum up the level of enthusiasme this movie was anticipated for, and it delivered with flying colours. The Force Awakens is not only a good Star Wars movie, it is a good movie period. The characters are very likable especially Daisy Ridley's character Rey. The humor is very well placed and absolutely brilliant, it's probably the funniest Star Wars movie without it lessening the tension from the more dramatic moments, the return to practical effects adds a layer of authenticity which unfortunately was forgotten in this age of CGI and digital effects, while some may criticise the derivative story or it's simplicity, i say that Star Wars was so compeling to a great number of people because it's so easy to follow do i regret the way too familiar plotline YES, does it ruin the movie completely ABSOLUTELY NOT. Astonishing performances, thrilling action sequences, tense dramatic moments, interesting old characters, nostalgic old characters, Star Wars The Force Awakens hits on every level and it brought the magic of the saga into the silver screen once more.

4.5/5 Stars. Let's be honest - this was an impossible task thrust on J.J. Abrams. Revive a franchise who's last 3 films made a lot of people very angry and do it without input from the original creator while also setting up a new trilogy that also pays homage to the original trilogy. Most director's would turn it down and he did initially. Thank God he changed his mind. Many will argue that the plot is too familiar to the original Star Wars. But why shouldn't it be? This isn't so much a formulaic plot as much as it is proof that there's a formula that works. Daisy Ridley and Harrison Ford shine as new and old heroes respectively as well as Carrie Fisher and Peter Mayhew who turn in their best performances for Leia and Chewbacca. The way Luke is handled in this episode is perfect. We've followed his journey as the hero already so seeing in the capacity is a breath of fresh air. While not always given the best dialogue, John Boyega is a welcome addition to the roster as Stormtrooper-turned-hero, Finn. The real standout of the film is still the powerful, moving score by John Williams. I could go on and on about the stunning visuals and the rest of the cast works well with one notable exception which seems to have fans split right down the middle - new villain Kylo Ren played by Adam Driver. I've never seen Driver in anything prior to this but went in with an open mind. The result? When the mask is on, we get an interesting villain shrouded in mystery - the key component that made Darth Vader so intimidating and fun to watch in the originals. However, this intrigue is shattered as soon as the mask is removed to reveal a long-haired pretty boy/spoiled brat with a temper. Now I understand why the mask was removed when it was to give us the battle of wills between Rey and Ren but here's my change: Kylo Ren should have remained unmasked until THAT scene (you know the one if you've seen the film). This would have also been the perfect moment to reveal Ren's history instead of a throw away line earlier in the film (You wouldn't want to learn Vader was Luke's father from a stormtrooper). This scene was also when Driver seemed to really bring nuance to the role, but by that point I was so removed from the character that the performance fell flat in comparison with the other actor in the scene. That's my one big complaint and that's about it. Others will argue that the third act is full of plot holes but they're forgetting one thing: this is the first of three new films. We don't know everything nor should we. How does Phasma play into the larger story? Who is Rey? What about the other Knights of Ren? For me the biggest looming question is who was the old man in the beginning (played by Max von Sydow) who knew Ren, his family history and Leia as a princess ("to me she's royalty")? I'm sure all will be revealed in Episodes VIII and IX and it's more exciting to wait and speculate rather than be given quick and easy answers. So is this a perfect film? Not by a long shot. But it's the best we could've hoped for given every requirement Disney and Abrams had to meet. And now we wait in anticipation for May 2017 for the story to continue in a galaxy far far away...
Star Wars is back, and it's wonderful!

I'll be the first to admit, I'm not a huge Star Wars fans. I liked the original 3 films, but I wasn't crazy about any of them. I hated the new trilogy, but only because they were awful movies, not because they tarnished a great legacy, since I didn't care enough about Episodes IV-VI to get offended. As a result, I went into this film simply hoping to be entertained, and I was, very much so in fact. It's unfortunately true what many have said about it being rather derivative, and existing as more of a homage to the original movie than as its own entity. The plot is over-familiar, the new villains aren't particularly interesting, and some of the writing stinks of Lucas circa 1999. There were a handful of things that didn't make a lot of sense, and while in the original trilogy the Stormtroopers were famously hopeless at shooting accurately, in this film they're also completely incapable of hiding from opposing gunfire.But with all that said, it's a notable improvement on the prequel trilogy. The acting is better, as are the special effects, and the action scenes are genuinely exciting, definitely the highlights of the film. It may include one too many nods to the older movies, but it's clear that the people who made it have a deep respect for the films that came before, and have done their damndest to honour them. It's not a masterpiece, but if you're just looking to have fun, it's well worth the price of admission.

The Force Jumps the SharkJJ Abrams is a great action director, but his new super mega hyped film is a crashing disappointment and is downright stupid throughout. So much praise has been heaped on this film, it is hard to take a shot at it, but here goes.No one can doubt that this film looks great, is wonderfully exciting and well paced, etc. But it suffers from two central problems. The first is that it is a crude re-make of the original story in nearly all of its major plot points. That is, a band of rebels have some vital information about a super weapon, and one of it's leaders hides it in a droid for safekeeping. Then a young person gets personally involved in the rebellion and is revealed to have secret powers they don't understand. That young person is helped by Hans Solo and Chewbacca and together, they confront the evil empire and destroy the super weapon. The difference is the young person is a young woman, rather than a young man. This is where my second criticism comes in.Rey, this episode's Luke, is a typical feminist trope ('a Mary Sue'. I believe they are called) who can do anything without struggle. Fix and fly the Millennium Falcon without any experience of being a pilot? No problem. Use the Force with no Jedi training? No Yoda carrying required. Wield a lightsaber to defeat a much larger man in black who has spent 25 years learning how to use the Force and fighting with a Lightsaber? Piece of cake. There is no struggle in this heroine, she can do anything without any explanation - and the audience buys it - because they have become used to 'Mary Sue' and swallow it all whole.Well, I don't. Luke had to train, Anakin had to train, Yoda had to train, Obi Wan had to train - all had to try and fail to become powerful. But Rey? Nothing at all. This undermines the film's credibility at its core - drama comes from struggle and conflict. There is action a plenty, and there is a character journey for Rey, but not one that requires anything other than being a woman doing all these amazing things without any explanation.While Lucas got himself mired in explanation, especially in the much derided prequel trilogy, Abrams doesn't give a damn for reasons why this is all happening. There is no context to his story - there is no Star Wars world, just events. dear viewer.Now of course, Episode VIII will reveal that Rey is Luke's daughter, that she is, of course, Jedi trained, that Kylo and her fought before, that the attempt to revive the Jedi Order by Luke failed disastrously when the cousins competed and Rey won. That is why Kylo turned to the dark side. Or some such nonsense. And defenders of this film will go 'See, it all made sense all along.' Afraid not.Star Wars made sense because it told the story of Anakin, his tragedy, his fall from greatness, his eventual redemption by his son. This is NOT in that classic hero story tragic structure. Rey is really a Disney vehicle - another Princess - I expect her clothes to be for sale in Disneyworld next year. Maybe in Episode VIII she will sing, and we'll have The Force Frozen. So George, you did sell your kids into slavery - Disney has turned Star Wars away from classic myth and into Pirates of the Caribbean. Or Beuaty and the Beast. You can tell it's wrong from the title - the Force cannot sleep and they awaken. The Force is eternal, and people use it if they can.Disney Star Wars - nah!

its star wars as you would expect, simple story line a few over paid stars, bit of action and loads of effects. saddly it falls flat on what it should of been. star wars should wow us, leave us brethless and exited as we walk out the cinima. instead you walk out chatting about the weather and the only thing that really stands out is just how slow the fight sceens where.

The Force Awakens combines old school fun with new school technology and brings out a fantastic film that lives up to the hype.

Finally, a Star Wars movie that feels like a Star wars movie. Great Characters, good story, and a nice mix of new and nostalgia. ***Slight Spoilers*****What I liked: The Characters. I loved the two characters Rye (Daisy Ridley) and Kylo Ren (Adam Driver). What's even more amazing is how well each did with not too many large roles in their filmography beforehand (especially for Daisy). Daisy brought with her a much needed female presence to a large blockbuster like this. Her heroine status never seemed forced but instead, seemed to grow along with the character. She also added charm and light humor to the character that helped the viewer connect to her. The other character, Kylo, was nothing close to being a villain like Darth Vader, which is a very good thing. The worst thing that could have happened would have been for them to try and create a copycat of one of the most iconic villains in film history. Instead, we got an emotionally conflicted, tantrum-throwing, violent brat; everything Anakin Skywalker from the prequels should have been. The difference between Kylo and Anakin was that we actually believed Kylo's struggle. We actually feel that this guy is dangerous, both physically and mentally. We also see how vulnerable he is without being told that flat out (see contrasting case in Episodes I-III with Anakin).  Finn (John Boyega) was a surprise for me. I went into the movie not expecting much from the character; that he would most likely be someone just hanging out in the background and "just there." I also had a fear, once into the movie, that they would try to make him into another Han Solo-type character. But he really came into his own and his scenes with Rye showed that they both had great Chemistry together. Oscar Isaac (portraying Poe) seems to always play an intriguing character no matter what film he is in, so I expected nothing less from him here, and he ended up delivering impressively. General Hux (Domhall Gleeson) could have been utilized just a bit more in my opinion, but was still a solid performance and I expect to see more of him in the next episode.  I was glad to see Harrison Ford and Carrie Fisher back and utilized in a suitable way. They weren't over used to the point where they drowned out the new faces, but they also weren't just tossed in there as a means to appease fanboys and fangirls. It was great to see Harrison Ford bring back the charisma and cockiness that epitomized the character Han Solo.  Better use of CGI: The special effects were pretty amazing, but what impressed me most, was the restraint in using CGI. What made the first Star Wars films so relatable and made them feel so real was the use of props and real sets, not a banquet of computer images that the audience is force-fed. People can tell when a movie is overstuffed with that kind of thing and it really show through the actors/actresses; especially when you have a sub par director at the helm.  There were a few scenes that really stood out for me in this movie that really pushed me over the line of liking to loving this film. The first one was when Rye is being interrogated by Kylo Ren and takes off his mask. At this point, my mind is filled with all kinds of images of a powerful, possibly mangled, beastly sith lord. The mask comes off though to reveal...just a kid; a punk kid. As he begins to terrorize Rye, you can see he's overflowing with confidence. But then there's a quick moment where he changes from confident to panicked as Rye fights back. Then she turns it back on him and you can actually see his "oh shit" moment when he realizes who/what he is dealing with.  The other scene that I loved was, of course, the lightsaber fight scene. It was simple, yet engrossing. Instead of displaying all sorts of ridiculous acrobatics and showy saber swings, the characters focused on one thing, beating the other guy. No jumping through absurd changes in the landscape, no cheesy dialog, no ludicrous surprises. It was a display of effort, struggle, and will and I couldn't help myself getting imbued with a feeling of excitement from it.What I didn't like: One of the few cons I had with the film was the use of yet another Death Star-like object. Although this was a minor negative, it was still enough to make me sigh just a bit.  Captain Phasma seemed like she was built up so much through trailers and marketing that the character really fell flat and it was quite disappointing that she really didn't play any big part of the story. Many will point out how much the movie plot resembles A New Hope. While this is undeniable, I felt that this was perhaps intentional. A way bring together the old fans with the new fans. Besides, the story from a New Hope isn't exactly novel itself. It's the same story that has been told many many times in many many forms. Star Wars' true magic comes from its characters and its worlds. That is why Star Wars has endured for generations.

Some have complained about the "recycled" story concepts found in Star Wars: The Force Awakens. They argue the film lifts too much from the original trilogy and lives in the shadow of 1983. Not only did I have no problem with this, but I would argue it was a necessity. Thanks to the disappointing prequel trilogy, the Star Wars franchise was deemed terminally ill and many fans, including me, had thought it time to pull the plug. Then along comes The Force Awakens, which takes place some 30 years after the events of Return of the Jedi. In order to take us someplace new, the new trilogy must first remind us of where we have been. The film's familiar story and visuals - and, of course, the presence of the original cast - sparks feelings of joyous nostalgia for the original Star Wars films. The Force Awakens succeeds in reminding us of why we loved Star Wars in the first place. It introduces us to a brilliant new score by John Williams - I dare say it may even be his best ever. It also lets loose at least a half dozen new heroes to love and villains to hate. You'll find yourself cheering on Rey, Finn, Poe and BB-8 as loudly as you ever did for Luke, Leia, Han and Chewie. The legacy of Darth Vader also lives on in Adam Driver's Kylo Ren, who's performance as the surprisingly complex dark-side villain was one of the film's best. With the stage now set and the pieces firmly in place, the Star Wars saga is ready to take us someplace new. As a longtime fan, it feels good to come home. Bring on Episode VIII!
Boring - a rehash of the original star wars. Loved the original, but even great movies get dull after you've seen them several times.

We waited for years, and it's finally here. At 3 o'clock this morning I entered the cinema wide-eyed, full of hope. As was with many people's childhoods, Star Wars was a staple of mine, and to this day the original trilogy still stand as some of my favourite films. J.J. Abrams famously managed to reignite the Star Trek franchise with two fantastic films, so when tasked with doing similar to Star Wars, some people were sceptical, but nonetheless excited. The main questions is: did he deliver? Yes he damn well did!You know that tight throat feeling you get when you have a sudden urge of adrenaline, for the last hour of the film, I had that feeling, sitting there on the edge of my seat, heart pounding fast. What I was watching was exhilarating to say the least.Let's look more at the film (don't worry, there will be no spoilers featured). First off, the opening - the classic text followed by the panning shot to a planet (or death star) with a Star Destroyer emerging into the frame, it all features, as does the use of practical effects and puppets / robots over the extensive use of CGI that was utilised in the prequel trilogy, thus giving fans the old school style of Star Wars they wanted oh so much. The film is fast-paced, with stunning action scenes and spectacles, but not rushed, the shots linger and the camera moves gracefully, giving us a spectacular view of the situation at hand.The prequel trilogy shunted the franchise on a downward spiral, the overuse of CGI and the introduction of some of the most annoying characters in film (a-hem Jar Jar Binks), but Abrams, the finest choice of a director to reignite the franchise, did nothing more than show pure love for the films and has created a sequel that definitely exceeded my expectations. A film that features endless nostalgia with appearances from Ford (who is beyond fantastic), Fisher, Hamill even Peter Mayhew as Chewbacca and constant references to the original trilogy.The only partial negative aspect is its somewhat lack of originality, it acts more as an homage to 'A New Hope' than an original tale. But if you overthink points like this when viewing it, you won't enjoy it, so just empty your head of that and watch the film for what it is: a space opera that acts as nothing more than a sheer piece of movie magic!
Great, fun and entertaing

We all have a duality in us. A moral compass with a needle that wavers between good and evil, right and wrong. It's been in us all along and is part of what makes us what we are. No one is completely good and no one is completely bad, though for many of us our needles spend far more time on one side than the other. This compass, along with our longing to know where we came from and why we're here, has led our species to create policing, governments and religion in an attempt to protect us from ourselves, to govern us and to explain our purpose, to give us a purpose. George Lucas tapped into this very basic slice of our human makeup when he created Star Wars in 1977. Star Wars is essentially a bible story in space. Good vs. evil, light vs. darkness, miracles and magic and murder and sacrifice. With the consequences of this galactic soap opera affecting an entire universe. It was an incredibly simple story on an incredibly large scale. And like a good bible story, it connected with people in a massive and fundamental way and went on to create a phenomenon that has permeated the lives and cultures of nearly every corner of the globe. If that's not religion, I don't know what is.So you could consider the announcement of Episode VII in the Star cannon akin to an announcement from the Catholic church that they will be releasing a new book of the bible during the Christmas 2015 season.Now I'm personally not a very religious person. I like the Star Wars films, I grew up, along with most of the modern world, on the films and their subsequent pop cultural dominance. But they don't represent any particular touchstones in my life and I doubt I would even consider them hallmarks in cinematic history, as far as my list is concerned. I also hated Episode's I, II and the first half of III. But I can get caught up in hype as easily as the next person and my curiosity at the initial announcement of Episode VII two years ago eventually transformed into higher and higher levels of excitement as the release date drew nearer.So now I've seen it. And what do I think? Well, the short of it is, although I haven't compiled my best of list for 2015 yet, I don't think it will be on it. That doesn't mean it's a bad film or that I didn't like it. It's about as good a film as you would hope it to be. I just think I had, or will have had, ten better movie related experiences by the end of the year.Overall there are lots of things I loved about this movie and really only a couple of things I hated. The thing I loved most about it was its aesthetic. This looks and feels like a Star Wars film. Like an original trilogy Star Wars film. Where the prequels screwed up by making themselves look too advanced and too slick, thereby confusing the timeline and making for an awkward marathon, The Force Awakens strikes the perfect balance between a film that looks and feels like a film made in the late 70's/early 80's, while taking full advantage of modern movie magic techniques. Another thing I loved was the tone. This movie isn't afraid to get very dark. And a lot of people die in it, on screen and off. I'm impressed with Disney on this front as the studio is known for shying away from abject noir in an effort to appeal to the widest possible audience. The cast (and casting) is also very good. It's nice to see familiar faces and even nicer to see new ones. Oscar Isaac can do no wrong as far as I'm concerned, but he's really great in this. As are relative newcomers Daisy Ridley and John Boyega (both television actors previously). The Star universe is also peppered with a lot of great new alien and robotic characters, both cuddly and horrific.In fact it is one of these characters that I didn't like about the film. In Episode VII the new evil regime is called the First Order and it's run by a large, wrinkly bastard called The Supreme Commander. Now aside from being the most fake, CGI looking thing in a film filled with otherwise photo realistic special effects, we're given absolutely no backstory on this Supreme Commander whatsoever. Where did he come from? What's his relation to the dark side and why is he in charge of it now? There is also a lot of plot side stepped involving Han Solo and Princess Leia. Given the amount of time that has passed between Return of the Jedi and The Force Awakens, not much is said about the interim. But those issues may be resolved in Episode VIII, which is already in preproduction, or Episode IX, which is sure to follow. All in all The Force Awakens is a great movie and will prove to be a real treat for fans of the series. And the bigger a fan you are, the more you will get out of it, I'm sure. ...I wanted to avoid being superfluous, but to hell with it. I can't think of a better way to end this review, so here you go: Verdict: The Force is strong with this one.

It's been ages since i had so much fun at a movie. Nostalgic effect? Yeah, of course, but that's what we want from a Star Wars movie! Some will find a bad thing the "deja vu" effect of some scenes or the coming back of familiar faces, but i liked it a lot. Perhaps this will begin a new saga, with new characters and i'm totally fine with it, but watching it made me the effect to pay a visit to a bunch of good old true friends. In this, the movie found the perfect balance between the past and the future of the series. I liked a lot the new characters, the visuals are stunning and the special effects are simply amazing. FX and nice landscapes alone don't do a good movie, but together with good acting and good story it's a killer combo! Of course we are talking about a movie which is pure entertaiment, pure adventure, pure amusement, there's some reference to nazism but more for the visual point of view (this is something Star Wars Imperial soldiers have always had, since the beginning) than other. So, don't look for some inner meaning, metaphors and all that stuff here. This is to entertain old fans and new ones and it does it perfectly. And with all those boring mediocre movies that try in every way to be deep, a fun adventure to watch and rewatch is more than welcome!

Wow, this episode of Star Wars almost feels more original than the originals. How is that possible? Chewbacca is the same as always, the Millennium Falcon rises from the dust, and Hans Solo is back to his old trade. The dusty desert planet where it begins looks and feels familiar. Several gigantic monsters make a dramatic entrance and exit. Our favorite droids make a brief appearance, although even they are getting replaced by an adorable younger model. The Dark Side is back at it with a bigger badder planet killing device. Star Wars episode VII even had the requisite bar full of goofy looking aliens.Star Wars seems to be unendingly about the struggle between the forces of light and dark, good and evil. It's variations of the same story, over and over. That being said, it works. Somehow, the force of light has chosen Rae and Finn to be its next champions against the champions for the force of dark. Sadly, the force of dark has chosen the only child of the heroic duo Hans Solo and General Leia Organa to be its champion. How tragic!This is perfectly set up for the next episode, where we will possibly find out more on the new heroine Rey's mysterious backstory. We will also surely see the training of Rey as the new Jedi by the long lost Luke Skywalker, and no doubt see Finn develop as well. I'm concerned, however, that Solo's and Organa's son Kylo Ren will be further destroyed by the dark side. He already made a terrible choice. What else is in store?

A welcome return to a galaxy far, far away. The Force Awakens delivers in spades, with strong acting and visuals that remain fresh, despite paying serious homage to the original trilogy, drawing comments that "we've seen all this before". Nonetheless, there is enough fresh and original content here that we can anticipate future entries to stand more on their own. Ultimately, The Force Awakens is a promise of even greater things to come.

Director J.J, Abrams takes over the mantel from George Lucas and, with a generation of expectation, pulls off something extraordinary with the most eagerly awaited movie release of the century.Once again it's "A long time ago... " There's a new evil, fascist empire, this time called the First Order, commanded by a shadowy giant, Supreme Leader Snoke (a Voldermortish looking Andy Serkis) and his villainous Dark Vader like lieutenant, Kylo Ren (Adam Driver) and captain of the Stormtroopers, Captain Phasma (Gwendoline Christie). The baddies are out to destroy the freedom-loving Resistance but are worried about where in the galaxy is Luke Skywalker (Mark Hamill) who has disappeared, although there's a map to his secret hideaway.Abrams has also brought back original cast members Carrie Fisher as Princess Leia now in charge of the Resistance, Harrison Ford as grizzled but charismatic Han Solo at the controls of the Millennium Falcon and of course there's Chewie and droids C-3PO and R2-D2.He has moved with the times with the new, relatively unknown, young leads, one is black and the other is a woman who is neither a princess waiting to be rescued nor a token female character. John Boyega (Finn) plays a stormtrooper with a conscious who goes rogue and Daisy Ridley (Rey), is the film's heroine, beginning as a scavenger on a remote plane but then becoming the one in whom the force awakens.Whilst talk about the newcomers has all been about Ridley and Boyega, who are both very good, the best of the new generation of actors is Oscar Isaac, who plays smooth talking rebel fighter Poe Dameron. As the self professed "Greatest pilot in the entire galaxy" he has naturally drawn comparison to Han Solo because of his one liners, old school charm and unflappable demeanour.Abrams knows what devotees really want and he gives us a cracking space opera packed with iconic glisteningly white and plastically stormtroopers (still with remarkable poor aim), X-wing and TIE figures whizzing round the sky blasting away at each other and lightsabers clashing in a battle of good versus evil.Critics have complained about all the nostalgia of the film. It's all too familiar. The presence of the old crew and even the new script, plot and visuals, all echo A New Hope. Adhering closely to the structure of the original trilogy, refurbished and freshened up, the film serves the older and younger audiences alike.As with his Star Trek reboot, Abrams has done a marvellous job injecting new life into the sci-fi franchise. He has made a film that the kids of today will love as much as we loved the first one. One we always imagined a new Star Wars film would be, the galactic classic fans wanted.

Old movies: A burst of creativity; Tatooine, Darth Vader, R2 D2's sounds, the Death Star, the Millenium Falcon design, Hoth, X-Wing-Fighters, Yoda, Rancor, the Force, and thousand other ideas.This one: Zero; another desert planet, another droid getting a secret message, another Darth Vader (and a ridiculous one!), the same Falcon, an alien that has glasses like Geri from Pixar, a *bigger* Death Star, ...To repeat; not a *single* new idea!
Just like the others but worse

This Star Wars was pretty weak. "SPOILER ALERT" There is very little originality: Good young Jedi person lives in the desert & likes to tinker with stuff, Bad guy runs around in a mask breathing deeply, Lost droid has the info to save the good guys, Death Star is now Death Planet, A father/son confrontation ends in tragedy with one of them falling to their death down a huge vertical space(Empire). I also have a problem with the fact that Rey can fly the Millennium Falcon when it has been sitting for 5 years(no maintenance) and she has no training on it. In the first movie Luke(Son of Vader) has to practice with the light saber and in this movie people just pick it up and miraculously know how to fight with it. I also felt the dialog was not as good as it should be and there were some pieces where the actors should have done more takes.

Maybe I'm just old and jaded but this felt like somewhat of a retread to me. I don't dislike the new characters but I don't really love them either. Darth Vader made for a truly iconic villain but there are none of that caliber to be found here. In many ways, I think the less well regarded episodes I-III had more "zest" and intrigue and I'm a bit puzzled as to why this installment has become such a chart topper.

If I rate this using Aristotle's 6 elements of tragedy, I'd give a 5 to the soundtrack. The spectacle is near 5. Thought/ideas are interesting here: the meeting of magic and science, intuition and intelligence, faith and reason. The rest is mediocre. Plot is a redo of an earlier Star Wars. Characters are uneven. The diction (or dialogue these days) was pedestrian. I wanted to like this movie much more than I did.

Meh Way too much hype surrounding every aspect of this film. Even after a week, I'm still trying to process the film...Well, not really process it--just figure out why I still don't like it. I'd see it again if someone pays for my ticket.

I know it's not just me when I observe that the seventh episode of Star Wars felt flat, contrived and, frankly, not very interesting. "The Force Awakens" was, of course, nothing but a re-imagining of Episode 4, with basically the same motivation, same scenes, same dialogue, and same (identical) ending as "A New Hope"... but without the thrills. I never thought I'd say this, but even Harrison Ford (with his hefty $34 Million role as Han Solo) failed to inspire. Seriously, I DID NOT CARE about this cast of characters, including those of the original cast members. And THIS is the best that the golden boy J.J. Abrams can do? Fortunately, I take consolation in knowing that not one thin dime of my money went to Disney on this one.

Of all the movies I've had he opportunity to watch this year, not a single film has managed to make me swear off social media, reviews, spoilers of any kind, and even fan reaction like Star Wars: The Force Awakens has. It was well worth the patience and the wait to finally sit in the theater and let the good times roll! I'll keep this short (and spoiler free) so most of you can go out and enjoy the film for yourselves. The film is good. Better than good; and it feels every bit a Star Wars film as the originals did, something the prequels sorely lacked. The new characters are all great to watch and introduces a menacing and fresh villain in Kylo Ren and his master of sorts, Supreme Leader Snoak. We also get the head strong Rey, the courageous (and often hilarious) Finn, and the dashing Poe Dameron as well as a scene stealing BB-8 and a wise Maz Kanata. Canon favorites Leia, Han, Chewie, and C3PO tug on fans heart strings as they appear one by one, with more many more that follow. The plot itself is simple enough and gives us a few twists and turns and some pretty interesting surprises that most fans will deliberate over the course of the next two years until 2017's Episode VIII. The few flaws of the film's plot: it doesn't elaborate on a few key points that would make the story gel better and it is a pretty solid retread of A New Hope (which isn't so much a flaw as it is a nitpick).  In a time when films are following the 'Cinematic universe formula,' it may or may not hurt potential franchises from flourishing into wonderful story phenomenon. In the case of Force Awakens, we are spared due to the rich universe that precedes it, fantastic pacing, a powerful score, and an intriguing idea of where the saga will go from here. So, is it worth your time and money and everything you would have (finally) hoped for in a Star Wars film? Oh yes. And then some.

Pretty fun, just go to enjoy a good adventure movie and don't think to in depth about the plot or you will find issues. If you liked the originals you will like this one. You should at least see the originals for this to all make sense for you or this won't completely stand on its own. This is on par with a bond or mission impossible movie as far as quality but has a lot of nostalgia going for it.

Ok my thoughts are pretty succinct at this point; for the record, do yourself a favor and see it in IMAX. That really clarified a lot of my thoughts from the basic projection I saw opening night.That being said: I fucking love The Force Awakens. Characterization is so important in a film to me, sometimes even above plotting, and I'd hazard to say that this film being the INSANE commercial success it is will have at least some effect on the way films from now on are cast. More female leads, more leads of color, and more interesting stories being told.Now, the problem everyone seems to have is that we have a re-hash of A New Hope. Which would concern me... if TFA wasn't BETTER than New Hope. This film is so much more balanced in terms of character backgrounds, dialogue being relatable (thank god they left all the clunky techobabble from Ep 4 out of this script), action (such acrobatic on-planet X-wing fighting and actually sensible lightsaber fighting), and blend of nostalgia with unknowns. The film is thick with referencing to the original films that whiz by so fast you have to watch it multiple times to catch them; it's crazy. It's a thrill ride that not only rewards lifelong fans, but sucks in people who've never seen anything Star Wars before - the double threat!That's the majority of what I have to say about the film and I think once the wave of it being brand new subsides, folks will come to love it and younger crowds will cherish it just like we cherish the original trilogy. Effects have finally caught up to what the Star Wars universe deserves and we've got a great blend of practical and visual effects in TFA: another card in its favor.After catching IMAX last night, I also have to say it's incredible how lodged in my brain the soundtrack is. Not only are the original themes there (and more neck-prickling than ever) but the new themes for Rey and the First Order are also totally incredible. Bravo, John Williams, for continuing to push the envelope when returning to familiar material.Don't miss it on the big screen if you haven't seen it already. That would be quite foolish indeed.

Boy was I excited. The last film I'd seen at the cinema was the Deathly Hallows Part Deux in 2011. I'm not a big fan of popcorn, or almost any situation where I have to spend more than two hours without the internet. I'd just finished work for the holidays and was walking back to the station when I noticed that one of my friends had changed her profile pic to one of her with a lightsaber beam in it. I stopped, lent against a pillar and got a ticket to a screening that started in a couple of hours, which would be enough time to get to Marble Arch and eat a pizza.It's difficult reviewing a film when you can't really remember it. It's not that it was boring or anything, I just have a sucky memory.Kylo Ren doesn't have Vader's majesty, only his fashion sense. He's like some futuristic hipster. It's not because he hasn't matured into his totally evil self yet, it's just who he is. Anakin was seriously charming even when he was younger. How did Han and Leia manage to produce such a wretch of a being? He makes me nautious. This wouldn't necessarily be a bad thing but I'm struggling to find a character in the whole film that has the type of quality that he lacks.Rey seems very strong but she hasn't fully found her power yet. Plus she's a workaholic. It's understandable because she has always been impoverished but it's unfortunate because neither her, not that noob of a Stormtrooper have any sexual orientation whatsoever. I mean I get it, the film is about the force awakening and probably in the next film, it'll be a bit more awake. My problem is that I can't see any of the characters turning into someone that I could see myself going for a beer with and that bothers me.Don't get me started on the droid that is basically a football, he even ended up in a net at one point, which is enough to keep the majority of Britons entertained for at least 90 minutes.I'm not saying it was a bad movie. It was dark and gritty although part of that might be because I watched it in an old cinema. Sometimes in life, two hours pass and you don't meet anyone you really like. That's realistic. I generally enjoyed it because I was eager throughout, to find out what would happen next, even though it all occurred a long time ago in a galaxy far far away. I'm looking forward to the next one.A lot of my enthusiasm comes from the fact that I love StarWars in general. I'd probably give it eight out of ten. For context, I wouldn't have given Episode One less than seven.
