The film fails because it creates extremely similar situations from all the other films, prequels and sequels alike. The biggest flaw is with the villain who is nothing but an ersatz of Darth Vader. Overall the entire acting is good, but some comedy aimed pointlessly for the sake of cracking jokes, especially by Oscar Issac stands out like a sore thumb and the romance between Ford and Carrie Fisher seems bad and rather unnecessary. One other main problem I felt is that the film series simply tries to keep the story centered on succeeding generations of it's original characters wherein almost all pivotal characters in here are mostly descendants of the original characters. A new entry to Star Wars has a lot to live up to, and does it? Perhaps to some. I can see why a LOT of people love it. It has quite a few components similar to the previous films, namely episode I and VI, that can hit a certain nostalgia yet freshness factor to many. The whole thing had what seemed like an unhealthy dependence on story and plot components faaaar too identical to that of episode I (poor, loner on desert planet, force-sensitive)and VI (again, desert planet, droid with precious information, finding a long lost jedi, Death Star [basically]). It's things like this that leave me heavily disappointed. The only thing I love about this movie is the breath of fresh air that is the new leads to the series coupled with some of the more loveable old cast members, and the hopes that episode VIII will be the new "Empire Strikes Back" of this trilogy (in other words, awesome). The theatrical John Williams's score hits its familiar (and welcoming) cords while being accompanied with an infamous title crawl. When two simple words shoot past us on a black, spacy, backdrop-Star Wars-it will have been a ten-year gap between iterations (the last of which was 2005s Revenge of the Sith) and while the previous film was focused on closing (and linking) two sets of trilogies that were made in a twenty-eight-year span, 2015s The Force Awakens looks in the other direction to where the saga will venture towards-the future-and succeeds in breathing new (nostalgic-infused) air to kick start future episodes. Blending the action, high-intensity style of modern big budget filmmaking with the stylistic aesthetic from that of the original trilogy, co-writer/producer/director J.J. Abrams niftily expands the Star Wars mythos for a new generation of movie-goer while also harkening back to many of the sights, sounds and originality that captivated audiences back in 1977. Abrams and co-writer Lawrence Kasden (back after penning both 1980s The Empire Strikes Back and 1983s Return of the Jedi) recycle tried and true plot beats (coupled with reused shots) that will instantly have one remember the past films. 2015 is an exemplary year with this trend with big-budget reboots/sequels (I'm looking at you Terminator: Genysis and Jurassic World) but The Force Awakens achieved the desired outcome in a tasteful way that serves the overarching story rather than easy reminiscent "cash" grab moments. Abrams, Kasden and producer Kathleen Kenedy do an admirable effort in treating the source material with respect and it shows all over the product in the story, the "feel" of the film and the characters. And what is Star Wars without the characters? The people (or creatures) we root for-the Luke's, the Han's, Leia's, Chewie's-are ultimately what make each adventure worth going on and what Abrams and Kasden exceeded in is bringing fresh faces to that Galaxy Far, Far Away who we want to see more of (which was the opposite outcome with Lucas's Prequel Trilogy where we didn't really like anyone). As a film that is to entice the past, present and (hopefully) future audiences, Star Wars: The Force Awakens succeeds in bringing an easily consumable adventure that packs the required weight to appeal to many. As a film that is to live up to the namesake, Star Wars: The Force Awakens doesn't hit the bravado heights of both A New Hope and The Empire Strikes Back but it was never meant to. As a film that is meant to encompass the joys of cinema-even if it is a familiar one-J.J. Abrams' Star Wars: The Force Awakens is a worthy entry in the famed saga and is a great stepping stone for the future.

Overall, I thought this was fine, and certainly an improvement over all of the prequels. Fine, though, is not exactly a glowing recommendation. I can understand why some people love this film. For one, this FELT like a Star Wars film; no political discourse, classic good vs evil story, spectacular visuals, no horrible speeches about love, and some really nice action set pieces that fit with the plot instead of distracting from it, and on a more minor point it was mostly lacking JJ's signature lens flares. However, I can also understand why some people will hate this: the dialog is still quite bad in places, it falls on some horribly overused cliches and conveniences, and while it seems strange to complain about physics in a sci-fi film this does exceed the usual suspension of disbelief in at least a couple of areas. Still, for me, the acting and direction was good enough to overcome these deficiencies, as they still somehow managed to say those bits of bad dialog with enough emotion that it felt genuine, and a lot of the credit for that goes to Harrison, who was wonderful in this. So all that out of the way, there's enough problems here that I can't give this a glowing recommendation, but there's enough good that I still have to say I had fun watching it. I feel pretty much the same about this film as the year's current biggest blockbuster, and therefore it gets the same score.

he worst thing is that its a BAD rip off of E4. The movie has so many plot holes and examples of convenient writing that even it's similarity to E4 couldn't save it. I hated the prequels, but this is a low on a completely different level. *****SPOILERS*******1. Can ANYONE explain to me please why did Han Solo take the droid that THE WHOLE GALAXY is looking for into the most public place possible - the cantina where EVERYONE can see it?? The movie doesn't explain why, Maz Kanata didn't need to see the droid, there is litteraly NO REASON for the droid being there except for the spy in the cantina to see that droid and call the First Order. They even left Chewie with the Millenium Falcon who could have taken care of the droid until they come back... /facepalm2. Can ANYONE explain to me why didn't Kylo Ren use his force powers on Finn when he fights him??? He used the force to freeze Poe in the beginning of the movie, he used the same force ability on Ray in the middle of the movie when he captures her, and then he even knocks Ray out by force pushing her into a tree at the end of the movie! That is 3 times we have seen him use his force powers. But, then when he is wounded and not at his 100%, when using the force would be the most logical option, he decides to engage Finn in melee combat??? Are you fucking kidding me?! If the movie had any logic, Kylo Ren would force freeze Finn and cut his head off in 2 seconds. But fuck logic! We need to have a cool lightsabre fight so the kids are happy!3. Can anyone explain to me WHY does Finn, a storm trooper, who - direct quote: "has been programmed since childhood to do one thing" betray the first order and starts shooting at other storm troopers 5 minutes into the movie? I can buy that storm troopers can go rogue, but I cannot buy they would go rogue so easy and so fast! You dont go through 20 years of brainwashing within 5 minutes of the movie! I dont care you just saw a genocide! Where is Finn's moral struggle? Where is his hesitation when he needs to start shooting at people who were part of his life since his childhood? Let me tell you that it doesnt exist! He litterally sees a genocide, breaths like a moron for 2 scenes, and all of a sudden he is rescuing Poe and is just like any other dude in the galaxy. That is COMPLETELY contradictive to the lore they were setting up for the storm troopers!! 4. Can anyone explain to me why did Captain Phasma lower the shields so easily? Or why didnt the command send a batallion of storm troopers to raise the shields again once they noticed the shields were down? 5. Why does the resistance and everyone else just trust Finn??? Nobody ever raises the question if he is a spy, and if that is not bad enough, they send him on a crucial mission to take down the shields just because he says he knows how to bring them down - only to discover he has NO CLUE how to do it!! Wow, the resistance seem to be complete morons who want to destroy a planetsized superweapon just by "winging it". ARE YOU FUCKING KIDDDING ME???And i could go on for hours pointing out all the things that dont make sense, but i wasted enough time on this piece of shit movie. Litteraly every scene is a plot hole or doesn't make sense in some way... So, not only did they COPY E4, but they did a BAD copy. Needless to say i am disappointed, but what is even more disappointing are the rabid fanbois who praise this shit as the best thing since sliced bread! 94% on rotten tomatoes????? Are you fucking kidding me????

Force Awakens is kind of movie which makes you miss James Cameron. The visionary director who actually understands the need and desire of the audience. Force Awaken even lacks the philosophy offered by original movie. It's a product which is made with only one intention, 'Feed the hungry fans and cash the cow'.Starting with the story, it was like watching A New Hope's mesh up with Jurassic World. All elements of the Original movie were present. The Trio of young characters, the good turned bad antagonist and his relationship with the protagonist. Even the death star and some old stars were there. There absolutely is no real goal in the movie. We movie from securing the map to preparing the Jedi to destroying the death star. And story itself has holes big enough to swallow a galaxy which is far far away. It seems that in last 30 years only earth have progressed in technology and biological domain, the galaxy which was so advance 40 years ago, now seems be living the same. Like the original series, antagonists are not killed and neither the family of protagonist is revealed. I wonder if they have any idea about DNA and biology. Also it's not clear that how come antagonist know a lot of technology. From a 30 years old spaceship to a newly built death star. She knows the right circuits to pull out. Characters seemed to be very distant throughout the movie. There absolutely was no chemistry between Han Solo and Princess/General Lea. Who unexpectedly is never mentioned to be from Jedi family. Although after recent success of female protagonist oriented film series, they did pass the torch to a girl.Moving to visual effects and cinematography, perhaps the focus really was to add unnecessary and blunt action sequence. Much like prequels directed by George Lucas, colors were blurred and not so bright. There was no need to watch the movie in Imax or 3d, the worst a director can do to a 3d movie. J J Abrams really lacked a vision here. It is just like watching a 2d film.Acting is okie, Although I did not understand some of the wits. Daisy Ridley is great in her role. She wore the role over and is the best thing in movie crossover. Harrison Ford is good and easy in his role. Carrie Fisher is alright. She did not have much to do that explains more than enough make up even at crucial times. John Boyega and Oscar Isaac played split up of Han Solo's character with not much required jokes.One goes with high expectation but returns very disappointed.

No Star Wars feel at all, rather a generic dumb SF with some SW-elements thrown in. Absolutely not worthy of the SW name. Poorly written, badly directed and badly edited. Poor action choreography with way too fast cuts. Jarring camerawork (too close placing, unnecessary movement and "flashy angles") that breaks with the established visual style of the saga, and pulls the audience out of a galaxy far away. Inconsistencies, abandoned characters, unfocused storytelling, unimaginative settings, poor performances. In no logical way a sequel to ROTJ.

Horrible character development, completely implausible situations and a glaring lack of chemistry define this PC reboot of the original Star Wars. We have the Stormtrooper who inexplicably develops a conscience, but no explanation as to why we have Stormtroopers sans Empire. One of our heroes, Poe, is...wait, who is he? We're supposed to care about him...why? And, of course, we have our main hero, a girl who's a junk dealer/ scavenger. At the drop of a hat, she becomes an ace pilot, master mechanic and Bruce Lee Jedi all rolled into one. Then we have our villain, who delivers all the menace and malevolence of Leave it to Beaver's Eddie Haskell while wearing a mask for no reason. Throw in a giant Area 51 alien to replace the Emperor, the First Order to replace the Empire and the Resistance to replace the Rebellion and it's time to search for Luke Skywalker. You see, Luke ran away to hide after one of his Jedi pupils turned out to be a bad boy. In the end, we can only hope that our new hero, Rey, will inform Luke that all this Jedi training is unnecessary in the first place- after all, she had only to pick up a light saber in order to make Darth Maul look like Pee Wee Herman. In the end, this film's only redeeming quality is the opportunity to see Han Solo and Chewbacca on the big screen for the first time in over thirty years, and even this left something to be desired.

Initially upon first viewing I was disappointed as its just a re-hash of parts of episodes 4-6. There's almost nothing original here. In fact, everything that seemed most interesting was only described in passing like anything that apparently happened since Return of the Jedi and this movie. All that said, upon 2nd viewing I was trying to look past the recycled plot and sit back and try to enjoy it for what it was. The characters/acting and dialog were all solid which was refreshing considering the disaster of episodes 1-3 in this department. The special effects were spot on as you would expect. I am hopeful this is just a little reboot to kick things off and we really get into some seriously interesting plot devices moving forward. If that happens then this film is perfectly acceptable. I'm giving it a pass for now.

What a complete and utter waste of time and money, and a total erasure of the excitement I had to revisit and enjoy even part of the magic from my childhood experience.Garbage story. Bad character development. A couple of absolutely horrible casting choices and stilted performances. Loaded with clichs. Entirely derivative from A New Hope - except without any of the charm, mystery, and intrigue. I'm not going to waste time talking about droids with hidden information, hiding under Falcon floor plates, or Death Star channel runs and destruction. It's all far too apparent when you see the film.Want to care about the characters and their stories? Impossible. Even the ones you used to are less than shadows of what they were. Sorry, Harrison, I love you. But aside from a couple of cool moments, Han Solo - one of the most beloved characters of all time - was just completely BLAH. It's an unforgivable insult that this is the drivel that was given to you.Finn. Rey. Poe. Phasma. Ren. Why care about any of them? They are all ridiculously underdeveloped and utterly uninteresting. They are either too perfect (Rey), too pathetic (Finn), disappear and reappear inexplicably and in the most superficial way (Poe), or just not fleshed out whatsoever (Phasma, who really looked cool and could have been built up to something really bad ass - a new Boba Fett. But she was rendered completely insignificant and glossed-over).Kylo Ren. This is our new villain? Seriously? Could he have been any less interesting or weak? He turned out to be nothing more than a tempestuous, troubled teenager. There was no compelling setup or background for his battle with dark and light. He even beared no resemblance to his parents, Han and Leia. And if you want to build any interest over a character with a hidden face and intimidating appearance, you do not unmask him in the first film, let alone have it be that kind of anti-climactic reveal.General Hux. The worst casting of the entire film. The worst acting. And the Nazi reference was just gag-inducing.The movie was ridden with non-sensical stuff. Star Wars used to make sense. There was a sensible lore. Force users needed intense training, or they stood zero chance. How about some scavenger - unrealised force powers or not - able to fly a totally unknown ship with such efficacy and impossible skill? She resisted powerful force mind probes. She could out force-grab a light saber. Rey was all but victorious over a trained and 'powerful' Sith apprentice? Flinn - a SPACE JANITOR and rookie Storm Trooper - virtually holds his own against this trained Sith with a Jedi weapon he's never used before? Seriously?And the incongruencies abound. Ren can deflect point blank blaster shots behind his back, but can't detect and defend himself from a distant shot from a wookie who screams and reveals his position? We're supposed to be impressed or scared of this guy? He displays awesome initial powers, but ends up almost totally inept, and little more than a tantrum-throwing teenager?Han solo, one of the baddest and coolest good characters gets murdered over a touchy-feeling family moment and thrown into an abyss? What a fitting end. (rollseyes)There are so many negative things to say about this movie. And the only positives are a few moments of wonderful cinematography and VFX. Even the score was sub-par, which is a shocker from the greatest of all time. Almost everything about TFA was abysmal. Some of the tone was there. But this was light years from the Star Wars we knew and loved thirty-plus years ago.No wonder. No mystery. No lore. No build up. NO SIGNIFICANT, BELIEVABLE OR INTERESTING DRAMA. A complete failure to set up the most basic emotive themes like the first movies explored so successfully.By the time I was halfway through the movie, I was repeatedly throwing my hands in the air. This is a horrid re-entry for a franchise that was supposed to be resurrected and freed from the incapable clutches of a next-to-incompetent George Lucas.Well, we found out there are more incapable movie makers and IP owners. 4 billion dollars bought what we knew and loved, and the most bland product was funneled through the bowels of idiocy and incompetence. Yet it appears they are going to end up recouping it all and actually profiting. Such is the current state of modern cinema.Shameful.30 years we waited for this. I had so much hope this would be good with no Lucas. It would have been so hard for it to fall further from my expectations. I am absolutely gob smacked it's being received so well.Has the bar been set this low?

While not as imaginative and surprisingly less visually spectacular than its predecessors (both old and new) Star Wars Episode VII provides proper fan service to seasoned star wars fans and creates intriguing new character plots to follow in future films.
Great movie that follows the Star Wars formula and ACTUALLY FEELS LIKE A STAR WARS MOVIE! (unlike those dreaded prequels). Good job JJ.

Just so much fun! Brings back the flavour of the original series and erases the pain caused by the other unfortunate series. A little slow during the nostalgic moments but a really nice set up for what is to come, so many questions and great new characters to take us forward.

Great reboot of the original episode 4. Appearances from the first film made the best parts of this one. Daisy Ridley was outstanding and very easy on the eyes. Hopefully there is more depth to Finn and not entirely sure where Captain Phasma fit in. Seemed like a dead end character. I think they blew it casting Adam Driver as Kylo Ren. He made me think the 70s version could have cast John Travolta as Darth Vader. Vinnie Barbarino, I am your father.

The Force Awakens does not disappoint and perhaps surpasses 4 of its predecessor movies as the number 3 or higher best Star Wars movie out there. Kylo Ren instead of trying to make him better than Darth Vader makes him ask that question for you. A character that will grow and have vulnerability and something more to his resisting of the light than we may be led to believe. You buy the instant friendship of Finn and Poe and love it with a "we're going to do this" Rey is a great hero who you instantly love, the world setting with her is done very well. She's strong willed, yet fragile in her own way and scared with abandonment issues. BB-8 is everything you hoped he'd be. Phasma is just like Boba Fett. Does nothing, but I think we'll see more of her in the next one. The humor is very Star Wars and laugh out loud. The nastalgia gets a little pandering. The chess table was a bit too much. Maybe bring in more new ships. Not the old x-wing and millenium falcon. The familiarity insures us that though changing hands, will still be Star Wars, repeating events and themes intentionally (like SPOILER death of a mentor in the first movie, not a jedi you will be until you confront your father) like a song or poem repeats rhythm and chorus. John Williams has not lost his touch (Rey's theme is great). We've had a Nazi theme with the empire and well-executed, we got something new and yet familiar with the Nazi speech never seen but perfectly in line with Lucas. Some good mysteries left unknown.Highly recommend. A great addition to the Star Wars universe. Most the rotten ratings are just a backlash to its popularity. I don't like it because it's popular type stuff or they don't understand the cyclical nature of Star Wars.

I was very skeptical from the new Star Wars, with that said, hear my rant on what I think of the new movie....Star Wars: Force Awakens was a movie that if you were skeptical, a movie that if you don't like Sci-fi, a movie that simply looked mediocre to you, well, your wrong and you should see it. It was the magic that the first trilogy captured audiences around the globe. Maybe more so this time. There were so many moments that mesmerized me begging me for more. This is the Star Wars movie we have been waiting for. I as a huge skeptic who waited this long to see it, am excited to see the next one in the series. Rey is now my favorite character in all of the Star Wars universe. Fin pulls a strong second. The development on these characters are so well written that the only disappointment I walked away with was the movie ending. I want more, nay I Demand more! Pony up the cash to go see this movie, do not let it slip by. It will be the best movie you see in the theaters for years to come.
It is a fun show. Probably the 2nd will be better.
I fell in love with this movie. AMAZING!!

Overall, the movie was great, no "in your face" CGI like the prequels, and better video quality than the originals, in mu opinion the second best star wars movie, first being the Empire Strikes Back. One criticism is that there wasn't any memorable music that was original.

Lots of cameos from the old crew still acting the same like hans solo owing ppl money. Action-packed, good acting, some humor, nice effects, but nothing new. The only surprise was that a girl was the heroine and that a storm trooper turned good. Yawn they played it too safe to the original franchise. I sincerely hope they up their game for the next one.

(8.5/10)Ah yes, The Force Awakens! The Force Awakens is an absolute delight of a film. It is packed with great action, it has an wonderful cast (Daisy Ridley and Oscar Isaac being the stand-outs), and is very high in entertainment value. With the story, half of the film is basically A New Hope, understandably so to make the series feel like Star Wars again, but I felt that this was a bit distracting, despite the film doing a great job balancing old Star Wars with a new fresh blood. There were also things that happened in the film were pretty convenient, the under-use of certain characters, and questionable decisions made in the script. Otherwise, The Force Awakens successfully reclaims the former glory of the Star Wars saga. The force is still strong with the franchise.

This movie had no memorable characters that made past episodes interesting like Yoda, Darth Vader, Jabba the Hut. No super actors like Alec Guinness . It wasn't particularly amusing just tired and corny like a rusty light saber.

A decade after the last Star Wars movie, J.J. Abrams did a great job bringing back the galaxy far far away. The Force Awakens had a very interesting plot that kept me on the edge of my seat. Harrison Ford did a great job returning as Han Solo. Also I thought having Daniel Craig as a Stormtrooper in the movie was pretty cool. Kylo Ren will make a good villain in the future movies, and Rey will make a fantastic Jedi. I really liked Finn and his decision to do what is right. Abrams did a nice job in his character development and I hope there is more to come on the story of Rey. The First Order will be a good successor to the Empire. The battles in the movie were exciting and looked amazing in 3D. The acting overall was pretty decent. The Force Awakens was without a doubt in my mind one of the better movies of 2015, and definitely deserves future sequels that hopefully build on its strong foundation.
Very exciting and nostalgic sequel! The best movie of 2015, hands down!

Star Wars: Episode VII-The Force Awakens was an excellent movie in my opinion. One thing that I really liked about it was that they brought back the original actors from the first trilogy. Right when they announced that there would be a seventh one, I instantly feared that they would get some random, awful actors to play Luke, Han, Leia, etc... BUT....they didn't do that, and they brought back Harrison Ford, Mark Hamill, and the rest of the crew. Another thing I liked about the movie was the acting jobs of the main actors and actresses. I thought they did a phenomenal job and definitely surpassed my expectations. The last thing I really liked about it was that it did have some similarities to the original movie. I actually don't think it was that similar to the first one but the ways that it was more similar made it continue the story well and gave it a little bit of the original trilogy feel. Overall, great movie, would definitely watch again, solid 8.5/10.
Exciting, moving, funny, and really cool special effects! ...And great music!

(spoilers) A disappointing number of questionable scenes top off by the scene where a newbie force user defeats a trained force user in her first light saber duel. The better scenes were the death of Hans Solo and parts of the new bar scene. Notable characters were General Hux and SL Snoke. There are some interesting mysteries for the next episode. Who will carry the movie after the death of Hans Solo? Has Luke been training Jedi in his hideout? Is SL Snoke really Darth Plagus?The saddest part of the movie was the plot. Couldn't they think of something besides the good guys saving the rebellion at the last minute by blowing up a planet/solar system killing machine?Speaking of which, didn't any science advisor point out that when you start draining a sun in a solar system you immediately allow all the planets to fly out of their orbits killing the populations within hours if not minutes?These defects turn this sci-fi fantasy into a sci-fi farce.
In an epic that takes place far, far away, it was far, far away from epic.

3/4More than respectable continuation of the sci-fi legacy. Three decades after RETURN OF THE JEDI, where another attempt to rule the galaxy emerges a few new heroes (and a few familiar ones) to aid the resistance to prevent the First Order from surfacing. Glossy, brisk action/adventure tale is no classic, but provides solid entertainment as it brings the series' story arc further. Storyline may be best described as "conventional", but the actors are so slick, and the action so slam-bang, it's hard to complain. Harrison Ford reprises his role with terrific ease, who by now can do this in his sleep (yet Carrie Fisher feels shoddy, underneath such obvious makeup).

Might be that the force is not that stronger with this one and definitely not upto expectations. It borrows a lot from its predecessors and leaves enough details to be filled out supposedly for future sequels. Though there is enough homages and reminders that would be enough to please any fan of the franchise and mind-blowing action sequences to keep the others entertained.

Ho hum. Lots of explosions, the usual chases and CGI special effects. Trite dialogue. Nothing new or fresh to see here folks, other than the introduction of a female character to replace Harrison Ford and ensure that Disney can turn out a new movie every year for the next 20 years -- ala James Bond -- and mile the Star Wars franchise for every penny it can.

-This review is spoiler-free- Even though this movie isn't called "A New Hope", that's what it's all about. I hoped to love this movie - to think about it for the rest of the day, and smile when I did. I hoped I'd love it so much I'd want to buy a poster that I could look at and remember how much I enjoyed it. But I've hoped to love a lot of movies and it doesn't always happen. I loved The Force Awakens.It respected what came before and used plots and ideas as backbone and inspiration, but it didn't rely on them. The Force Awakens calls back to the past, but doesn't copy it. It's funnier than the Star Wars movies of the past (and they could be quite funny). The filmmakers know that humor is what saves you from tripping over your own seriousness. And things do get serious, as a Star Wars movie should.But what really struck me about The Force Awakens was the pacing. Many action/adventure movies tumble through their own plots, never stopping long enough to let either action or emotion land - the movie's already on to the next scene. The Force Awakens never does this. Important conversations and contests of wills get the number of minutes they deserve. Moments land, and the whole audience is completely caught in the moment. It was all exactly what I was hoping for.
Bad story telling. Rushed. Wrong actors for the main characters (other than the usual).

Whilst changes to the saga were always going to happen, Star Wars feels like it's been shrunk down to planetary skirmishes.Although some plot items have been increased in size, the sense of scale that battles previously had has been lost, which is disappointing.When coupled to the hit and miss with the new characters, this feels like a film lacking the charm of either IV, V and VI or the updated wow factor which I, II and III had.

A big steaming pile of derivative garbage. This film does not stand on it's own two feet, relying heavily on nostalgia to prop up this un-original and labored plot. Screenwriter was the easiest job on this project by far, basically just changing the names on the storyline from the original (Episode IV). This was a pointless exercise in re-hashing, and its a shame the fanboys and fangirls seem to be giving it a free pass.

I wasn't sure about JJ directing this one, but I have to say he made it work. The movie itself is really fun to watch, although a bit on the predictable side (maybe it's because there have already been 6 movies before this one?). I recommend it to anyone, but don't watch without having watched the other 6 first!

Just saw the movie last night for the first time. I opted for the 3D version, and took the family. First, the good. Visuals and quality of the scenes was excellent, and Disney (and Abrams) experience at making films and worlds that are easy on the eye was apparent. Abrams also did a nice job with lighting and angles on most of the shots which accentuated the characters and definition of each scene. The 3D was mostly spectacular, with not too much and not too little, but just the right amount of depth (with a few in your face "coolness" moments) to make the extra $ worth it. Resolution and clarity was excellent, although with all 3D movies due to the technology, brightness of the scenes continues to suffer somewhat.However, beyond the big budget quality of the film, there was not much more to like. The story line was dull, there was little suspense, portions of the acting seemed amateurish (Fin in particular), and I felt like I was watching a copy of the original movies. There were at least 3 moments in the film where I was visibly shaking my head back and forth and rolling my eyes over the predictable and downright plagiarist nature of the film (I won't spoil it).If you are expecting a seat of your pants, action thriller with new creative elements, and storylines that make you care about the characters, this movie is not for you. If you want to be mildly entertained for a few hrs by good 3D and pretty scenes, you won't be disappointed.

While the mass hysteria, expectations born 40 years ago and uber-hype surrounding Episode 7 may brainwash the millions of lemmings out there (and I realize I now risk incurring their wrath), the Force does not awaken, but rather slumbers through what is essentially a bloated remake of the beloved 1977 classic. A very good film for the new Star Wars generation without question, but for us old-school aficionados to which the original trilogy is cinematic scripture, it fails to deliver any lasting emotion, excitement or resonance. Another resistance, another Empire (now called The First Order), another Cantina, even a planet revamped and masquerading as a pseudo Death Star??? Seriously!?!?! I'm not being overly critical, really I'm not. I'm just being true to Lucas' original vision and trilogy and I know there must be other intelligent, genuine cinephiles out there in their 40s who agree with me and know exactly what I'm talking about. Make no mistake, this is not a terrible film. It's passable in every regard. But for those of us who remember the magic and majesty of the original trilogy, it's like having a sip of Coke from an open can that's been sitting on a counter for a month and has long lost its fizzle and taste.
I have never been more entertained! Great job updating the series!

There are a lot of the old (and I mean a lot) and very little of the new. The parallels and similarities to Episode 4 are not that subtle ? plot lines, action sequences and dialogue. It is more than a tribute or ode to ?A New Hope? as it is about repeating the same elements. That?s too bad. I was afraid of this considering what Abrams also did with the ?Star Trek? series in which the latest installment is now under the helm of a new director.This is probably the best move for Disney though, in order to protect its $4 billion investment. No doubt it will satisfy fans of the series. But those looking for something fresh and new may have to look elsewhere.

Extraordinarily faithful to the tone and style of the originals, The Force Awakens brings back the Old Trilogy's heart, humor, mystery, and fun. Asked granddaughter if she thought that Mom and Dad would want her back on their side if she were a mass murderer. She said, "Don't know." Daughter said, "We'd want to visit you in jail." Trust issues and human nature seem more true to life to me than this rather contrived climax...

So here it is after all the build-up and hype. The Force Awakens has been more anticipated than the second coming....Would it be as rubbish as The Phantom Menace? Could it possibly match The Empire Strikes Back? You'll note my personal biases there. My answers in the simplest forms would be "No" and "No". I don't want to be the one who breaks the unwritten code and gives away elements of the plot for those yet to see the movie but The Force Awakens is a grand Space Opera type movie, spanning numerous worlds on a breathtaking scale. It does deliver in terms of scope, grandeur and styling, fitting neatly into the Star Wars universe as it is established and adding significantly to it. Indeed I was torn by the revelry in the nods to "A New Hope"-"Return of the Jedi" in terms of recurring tech, ships and characters and an excitement to see how J.J. Abrams would carry the franchise forwards. As with his revisionist of Star Trek, Abrams has done a superb job and clearly loves the subject. The care, craft and dedication to the established vision of George Lucas is clear. I loved the fact that the effects seemed gritty and real, wiping away some of my own disappointment at the plasticky CGI that plagued "The Phantom Menace"-"Attack of the Clones". Everything looked convincing and solid. Abrams has avoiding the jokey and childish aspects of parts I-III which drew so much criticism, instead he's given us proper characters with real personality and convincing relationships. However, for me, the plot of "The Force Awakens" did bear far too many similarities to "A New Hope". There are just too many parallels. There's a similar role for a cute droid, a masked baddie with a family connection to major characters, a bar sequence featuring a band and various outlandish alien creatures and a pivotal raid on a super weapon by a squadron of X-Wing fighters. The list goes on. I was also a little unconvinced by the performances of two of the returning actors from the older movies. I think it is fair to say that this is not one of Harrison Ford's best performances. Maybe the pain from his broken ankle was distracting him but he just didn't seem able to recapture the spirit of Han Solo. I missed the twinkle he used to have in his eye and the genuine camaraderie he portrayed with Chewie was missing. However, the biggest problem for me was with Carrie Fisher. She delivers her lines as though she's just been dragged out of a local bar after partaking in a drinking game. She's lost all the regal air of Princess Leia and has none of the gravitas a rebel general would need. She really didn't work for me. A shame as she's such a great character and has been so good in the past. The new characters are well portrayed and I'm really looking forward to seeing how both Daisy Ridley and John Boyega develop as the next movies come along. Indeed, the film ends on a perfect, though completely guessable, cliff-hanger with which to lead into the next film in the saga. Shortcomings aside, this film comes as a huge relief to those of us who queued around the block in 1977 in order to see the first Star Wars movie. I am genuinely looking forward to seeing where the adventure leads us over the coming year and it is great to have such a well loved, admired and cherished franchise back on winning form.

"The Force Awakens" is a strong returns to form for the franchise after an absolutely horrible trilogy. Too bad that the movie have too much similarities with the fourth episode of the saga despites introducing new elements.

My O my. OK the rebel forces might be destroyed by a large weapon unless can shut down defenses to allow an attack to destroy it. Is this the first one or the third one or the 4th one...and the Jedis who can move stuff and kick ass....and can see the future sometimes....well..didn't/don't. This movie is a victim of hype that was a little too much, at least in my case. I found the plot to be unoriginal, treading no new ground in the Star Wars Universe. I wasn't really intrigued with anything that was going on. THAT SAID, wonderful visuals, likeable characters old and new, well acted, great soundtrack, many laugh out loud moments, and of course, a nostalgia that really lifts you up. This movie wasn't perfect to me, but it was great, and a sign for good things to come. I'm happy we're going to be getting more Star Wars tales, I only hope they change things up a bit.
WORST MOVIE EVER!!!!! 0 STARS!!!!!

The bottom line for why this movie worked is because it did exactly what it needed to do; Reestablish Star Wars as it was before Lucas' prequels.Yeah, some of the people who are hating on this movie have valid points, but they forget the fact that we just got a movie far better than Episode I-III and maybe even better than Return of the Jedi. Most people who are giving this move a '0-4' unrealistically bought into the hype as if it was some portal into the future as what this movie has to be. It sets an expectation that not even The Empire Strikes Back could achieve.Sorry, I just had to get that out of the way.Anyway, I'm just going to get the flaws out of the way first, because they're not the point of this review. First off, yes, this film can feel a bit too familiar at several points. A lot of the basic plot, characters, and scenes are strait ripped out of (mostly) A New Hope. The little 'wink wink' and nods to the originals were really the ones that took me at out at some moments, but fortunately, there are few of them, and they are over within seconds. These problems do get a pass for me, because they're more so homages rather than reminders. Second, the Starkiller Base was the line for me. Not only is it absurdly impractical, but it really is just another Death Star. I do appreciate when the film recognizes this, but it was still just a bit too much for my liking.And that's it. Everything else was, well, pretty much perfect.Not only is the start of the film ingenious, but so is (mostly) the rest of the movie. From the opening scene we are given everything we need to know, and how to feel throughout it. Our main characters aren't only incredibly handled, but also human, which is something we haven't seen in Star Wars for a really long time. Something that has to be understood is that these characters are the main focus of this plot, unlike in A New Hope where everything revolved around a planet-destroying ball. Something that can't be unnoticed is the new roles, not only are Rey, Finn, Po and Kylo Ren great characters, but evenly comparable to icons such as Luke, Han, Leia, and Darth Vader. The new roles didn't only have great actors behind them, but actors that wanted to be there, putting in all that they had. When I see an actor like Harrison Ford after thirty years, I didn't see Harrison Ford on screen, I saw Han Solo. The same goes for the other returning cast, with I'll be it, limited screen time. It is also intriguing how fast it is, this is the fastest moving Star Wars since Episode 5, for nearly all scenes have no time for relaxing, which is actually a good thing here. Other misc. things include how technically impressive it is, the music old and new, and how well it sets up this new trilogy. Anything that I didn't mention I probably loved anyway.Overall, Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens is exactly what this franchise needs. Yes it is mostly Disney playing it safe with a retro style, but if it went too different, then you have a mistake made by the prequels. This film feels like the Star Wars we've known to love, and I can't wait to see where it takes us.
It was a good nostalgic passing of the torch but I was hoping for a lot more innovation and creativity. It leaves some hope for 8 and 9 though.

Though it borrows a few too many elements from the original, The Force Awakens is a return to form for the franchise and brings back the things we love, fun characters, practical effects, humor, and joseph campbell's story structures.

I loved to see Harrison Ford cast into this incredible movie. I'll say one thing about it though, it didn't fit all the criteria of my star wars expectations, I had a lot to be fair. I still loved the movie and will hope to see it again.The characters were lovable and creative. Han Solo's death was predicted but I still felt some sort of astonishment when he had a fateful encounter with Kylo Ren. BB-8 was actually very different then R2D2 in many ways. Finn had a great backstory and had character and heart. along with comedy; which I respect in any kind of movie. C3PO didn't change a bit, (which I particularly like), and Rey didn't feel like a star wars kind of character but it was interesting to see her become pretty tough even with her backstory. Best 2015 Movie hands down, sorry Inside Out.

Moving constantly forward at breakneck speed, at times I wanted it to just let the characters speak to one another and have Fin and Rey's bond be formed through something other than just plain old battlefield trauma. Nevertheless, when you sit in the cinema watching the X-Wing fighters roar across the ocean, silhouetted by the sun in a futuristic Ride of the Valkyries, you cannot help but be awestruck as the familiar score begins and you are once again turned into a child by the magic of the Star Wars universe.

Its watchable but not as good as a Lucas film. The good bits: as a little walk down memory lane reminiscing of the old magic, the old crew (specifically Harrison Ford), Daisy Ridley, a lot of action. Daisy Ridley does one of the best jobs I've ever seen of portraying a powerful yet still feminine and human female role model.The bad bits: there's no heart or magic to this film (as there was in every Lucas film). Its just a rehash of old stuff with little character development or pause for atmosphere (something Lucas was great at). He made you feel. Feel part of the story. This is just a series of excitements occurring one after another. If Solo and Chewbacca were not in it, this would be nothing more than a so-so TV B-movie. Maybe this is what American teenagers want to pay to see. If thats the case, they're in for an exciting future because there's a promise of endless of these without Harrison Ford in them. A notable point of failure in the nostalgia - the Millennium Falcon, even having sat in a scrap yard and left rotting for decages, in this film worked better than it ever had.

Overall the movie was a joy to watch! The acting, practical effects, special effects, and sound were phenomenal. I saw the movie twice, and the IMAX experience was out of this world. IMAX 3D is definitely the best way to go watch it. My only gripe is that I wish a few parts of the storyline were just a tad bit more unique. At times it felt like some of the homages to the original trilogy were excessive and not enough was done to expand the Star Wars universe. You'll understand what I mean after you watch the film. I hope Disney takes more risks in the next two trilogy films. I am fully confident that they are capable of making rockstar films that feel like Star Wars but are also completely unique to the series. Most importantly though, Star Wars is back and for at least the next 5 years to come!

After seeing it twice, I don't like it.First, the movie is a medley of sorts of the original trilogy (particularly ep. IV), only the plot is way more confusing. I keep reading additional content (like that Aftermath) and I still can't fully grasp what's the situation of the galaxy. It's a mess, and this should have been explained in the movie (having to dig information elsewhere is frustrating). Also, a new Death Star? Really?Second, the pacing is weird. The first half of the movie is somewhat stronger than the second. The ending feels like it doesn't fit and it doesn't feel much like Star Wars.Third, the villains are weak. You can't stop comparing Gen. "Mux" with Tarkin, "KillO'Ben" with Vader, and "Supreme Leader Snarf" with Palpatine - and they all fail to deliver (and it's not the actor's fault...). That Kylo Ren is the stupidest character since Jar Jar Binks. Nothing he says makes sense. "I'll finish what you started..." What did Vader start to begin with? Palpatine founded the Empire, Palpatine started hunting down the jedi, Palpatine started every war in both the classical and prequel trilogies... so what the heck is this kid talking about? Finally, having a loving father and mother, being son of two of the greatest heroes of the galaxy wasn't enough... Having the strongest force user as uncle and master is not enough... Somehow he bounded to Supreme Leader Snarf will and - then they repeat the plot again? At least we had 3 movies to try to understand Anakin's fall. By the way, nobody told this stupid kid that the grandfather he worships so much came back to the light before he died? Oh, but that's not enough. The stupid kid had to lose the lightsaber fight so we could grasp how dumb and weak he is. Kylo Ren is like "Cartman with Authoritah fell to the dark side" - but dumber.Forth, why wasn't the big imperial ships protecting the big bad base as well? Why that stupid name, "First Order"? Why captain Phasma lowered the shield (the price for such treason should be surely death or worse... oh, forget it). Why make lots of puppets and then make Maz Kanata CGI? The movie kept reminding me it was just a movie!Also, that dialogue between Han and Leia. So much of it was unnecessary... Which brings me to what I hated the most about the movie, and the main reason I'm giving it such a low score: it erases anything good and fulfilling we had at the end of Return of the Jedi. Every single one of the original heroes failed miserably in every aspects of their lives. Where is the reward for being good, just and do heroic deeds?So... Han failed as a husband, as a father, as a member of the resistance and overall as a man (a bitter one it seems)... same goes for Leia (oh, she is a general of a sidekick cell that's supported by the republic... great). Luke is the worse of them all: failed as a jedi master, failed as a protector of the galaxy, as uncle, as friend, as brother, as the owner of R2D2... the plot seemed to be around finding Luke, but the movie ends and he's done nothing and you get to wonder: why? Why do they need him? What do they need him for? The resistance certainly can handle any new Death Star that appears, and it seems the plumber trooper and junkyard girl can surely handle the stupid angry kid. All that, and R2D2 being in a coma because he's sad sounds so absurd... Didn't the little droid survived the killing of younglings by Anakin Skywalker? Didn't he watch the purge of the jedi and the founding of the Empire?Well, I guess that's it. I had to watch it 2 times to be sure I didn't like it, but the more I think about it, the worse it gets. I was going to keep it to myself, but after seeing how angry "the real fans" are getting at anyone that disagree with them, I felt I had to come and share with you, that also didn't like the movie, that you are not alone. I can only hope the next one will end up being so good it's going to redeem this one.

This episode/ movies is a nostalgic "care package". It does everything a Star Wars born and breed fan wanted. But I'm sorry to say, for me, that wasn't enough. The new line-up of characters are not so spectacular at all, nor convincing. Also, the script isn't ambitious enough, but that's understandable for such a great leap for Disney in reviving the franchise- play it safe. While Rey is indeed an interesting yet repetitive addition, as well as BB-8 is. Flinn fails to capture the real drama of being a rogue stormtrooper.Poe was one of the most promising, an his acting and character is good, but heavily under used. As far as the Dark side is concerned, Kylo Ren and the Knights of Ren, for me, where really a highlight.A new Death Star... Almost lost me there, even more when the attack plan was the same cliche like in the previous ones. Overall, I guess the nostalgia and the experience of seeing it in IMAX guarantees you a memorable trip into a Galaxy far far away...

A good start to getting the beleaguered series back on track. A good start, but not without some minor issues. Adam Driver is weird looking (shame on people for going after Carrie Fisher when this guy is a much easier target). The hamfisted "LOOK! NOSTALGIA" was a little distracting at times. Some elements were naturally predictable. But as a whole, it's still so much better than the 1997 special editions, and the prequels. No Galactic Senate hearings, no unnecessarily bizarre alien species, all the action sequences and heroic explosions that make the series fun.

J.J. Abrams maintains a style that helps us pick up from the 1st Trilogy that was released in '77, '80, & '83. Star Wars: The Force Awakens is easily the fourth best movie of the franchise. It fits in just below the original series, but it is definitely better than any of the prequels. The acting is well done (unlike the prequels), and it offers a good mix of practical effects and CGI. This film isn't without its faults, but it continues the story in a compelling way that feels like a natural continuation of the saga. I would happily watch this movie again and I would gladly add it to my movie collection.

This "Star Wars" movie does stay true to the original format of the old Star Wars movies of the '70's, from beginning with the typed epilogue to set up the story, to the quirky and simple minded dialogue, to lame attempts at humor with little quips which failed to earn an "out-loud" laugh in the well attended theater. No earth shaking visual new technologies were to be found. But it did feel like watching a continuation of the old Star Wars flicks, which I am sure was its intended purpose. There were some exciting scenes to be sure, but not of the caliber I was expecting, based on the rave reviews this movie has garnered. It was enjoyable to watch, I will admit. But I think it is being a tad bit overrated by the critics. It is a good movie; but not a great movie. "May the Force be with you!"

Without a doubt this was the film I most waited, I most created expectations, and more carried away to see because as a child I dreamed of seeing a new Star Wars in the theater, and now finally my wish came true and to my happiness my expectations were met and perhaps even exceeded. I have always supported the choice of JJ Abrams as director of the film as it has great films in the curriculum as "Super 8" and yet reborn another franchise also science fiction and also very famous "Star Trek," and not regretted it because it He held the desire of every fan of the saga, which is to make a new story with great new characters, adding relevance to the familiar characters from previous films and introduce new worlds and knowledge about the universe. In terms of performances this definitely is the best film in the franchise, Harrison Ford returns as "Han Solo" and not only back to make the character we know as also adds more layers to it, Oscar Isaac as "Poe Dameron" is excellent and could appear a little more than he is, John Boyega like "Finn" is amazing it has a lot of energy to the role you see he is really happy to be in the movie, and Adam Driver as "Kylo-Ren" managed to create a new villain very different than "Darth Vader" as he has much more emotional conflicts and does not come as a total master of the force since it shows that it is still inexperienced. More most certainly surprise is Daisy Ridley as "Rey", she is the star of the film, her performance is quiet but very talented, I've really fallen in love with her and I'm coming to see anything she is now. Technically then I already think unnecessary talk, after all who is going to see "Star Wars" already know what to expect from this question that is a visual spectacle, and again yes it is, especially for this film using more practical effects and scenarios real than the last film made by giving more reality to the film and leaving the CGI much smoother and cleaner time to be used, and already on the 3D that was the best 3D EXPERIENCE I have ever had at the movies, no kidding . Of course, John Williams as always hands us another fantastic, engaging and relevant soundtrack in time to thrill even in the most exciting scenes. Look I can even be a little too excited, but the impression I got those two times I went to the cinema to see "Star Wars: Episode VII" is that this is possibly the best movie of all franchise next to "The Empire Strikes Back, "and honestly I know there are many good films in 2015, more for me not to hear a more rewarding film than that this year, so for me" The Force Awakens "is the best 2015 movie no doubt.

This movie is not a remake or rehash of ANH any more than Ep 1 was, and it is MUCH less similar to ANH than Ep 6 was. It has more differences than similarities to ANH and takes the familiar elements that it does use and turns them inside out and backwards, resulting in a deeper, better film. Rey is no Mary Sue. Luke was knocked out by sand people but that's his only failure in ANH. Rey fared worse; she is paralyzed by Kylo Ren, rendered unconscious and captured. She accidentally causes the deaths of 8 characters, causes Han to lose his giant freighter ship, and is unable to prevent one friend from dying and another from going into a coma. If you go on a space adventure, you definitely do NOT want Rey watching your back! Also, you have to wonder how the haters can simultaneously believe Rey is a Mary Sue and that TFA is a remake of ANH, unless Luke was a Mary Sue! Regarding that final fight, complainers overlook that Kylo was twice injured before he started fighting Rey. First by Chewbacca. The movie took great pains to show how powerful Chewie's crossbow is. Recall when Han asked if he could use it? He blew a stormtrooper sky high then said, "I like this thing." That was to let you know later, when Kylo is struck by a bolt from the same weapon, of just how powerful a shot Kylo took. He was bleeding all over the ground before they started their duel. And he took another hit from Finn before Rey took over. The haters ignore this. Rey's victory was not as impressive as Luke knocking out a stormtrooper, donning his uniform, shooting up a bunch of guards, rescuing Leia, and going from farm boy to the Rebellion's best pilot in 2 hours, destroying the death star - without his targeting computer! but using "The Force" after a total of 5 minutes' of training from Obi Wan. And how about Rey's partially successful attempt to resist Kylo's mind probe? Ridiculous? "Her resistance to the mind probe is considerable." Who said that? Darth Vader of Leia in ANH -- Leia, a Skywalker with no force training! Vader could not pull the location of the Rebel base out of her, even though he was the baddest sith going.Besides, this movie drops so many hints of Rey's prior training it could not be more obvious. This will be made express in Episode 8, but this movie intentionally planted the seed for that. The haters are just very slow on the uptake. When you consider that groups of men are actually boycotting TFA because a woman is the protagonist, you understand where at least some of this is coming from. "How dare a woman pick up the light saber and defeat the bad guy after her male comrade is defeated!" Welcome to the 19th Century! I didn't think that's what "A long long time ago" meant LOL! Fact is, this movie is an improbable gift! 25 years ago, if anyone had told me one of the very best Star Wars films, in which Han Solo would figure prominently, would be released in 2015, I would have suggested they lay off the sauce. For me, One element that makes this film work so well is the instinctive empathy and compassion of Rey, it permeates everything she does even while she is at the same time as hard as nails, and the moral determination of Finn. Finn for all his bumbling machismo, is someone you admire for his unerring and moral compass. Even Solo, wizened by years, is driven to his own best moment by compassion. And it is all delivered in the context of a thrill ride of an action movie that never stops. There's nothing message-like about it. It is baked into the characters and drama. They all embody the light side by their actions more than Obi Wan ever did by talking about it. Even though in trying to measure objectively I place this behind The Empire Strikes Back, I have actually enjoyed it personally more than any other Star Wars film - maybe because its very existence seems so improbable, maybe because it is heartening in late middle age to see Han Solo roughing up aliens and pirates in his mid-70s, maybe because Daisy Ridley is just such an excellent actress, or maybe because I know this is just the start and that there are at least 5 more films to come. It is like the Star Wars universe was dead and gone and has now been brought gloriously back to life. I've seen The Force Awakens twice. The first time in 2D. Second time in 3D. My recommendation. See it in 3D! There was one moment when the tip of a star destroyer hovering in space seemed to be about to bump my nose! Han Solo and Rey dominate this movie. Together they are the engine that makes it go. They hold it on their shoulders. Finn and Poe are great, but in this installment, they took a bit of a back seat. Harrison Ford kicks azz and Daisy Ridley is amazing, versatile, sympathetic. She tears at your heart. Whoever cast her deserves a bonus, and Daisy deserves to be a major star. Most importantly the characters interplay excellently. Rey's major moment brought tears to my eyes literally. The audience cheered. It was just magnificent.

Re: Star Wars: The Force Awakens --I have been a Star Wars fan since I went to the theater to see the first movie (Ep.4). I've read most of the books that follow Ep.6. .I had heard that Disney did not want George Lucas involved (somewhat understandable after Ep.1), but they have obviously decided that they also could care less about long-time Star Wars fans & the existing Star Wars storyline. The one thing that Lucas did right is that he insured that the books, TV series, etc. were all consistent re: the long-term storyline. Disney obviously decided that this was no longer necessary & COMPLETELY changed what occurs in the future of the original characters. For example: in the books, Leia & Han have a really good marriage & have 3 children: twins Jacen & Jaina & younger son Anakin. Luke does not disappear, but instead marries & has a son Ben. Various things happen to all of them, but nothing like this movie. Han doesn't die in the books. The children & the names of the kids have been changed. (Han's son "Ben" does not even remotely look like he could be the son of Han & Leia btw.) The 3 main characters have dire things happen to them, but nothing like this movie. I own all of the previous dvd's. I own almost every Star Wars book made .(I read many books, but especially science fiction.) I HATED this movie. I will not buy this dvd, nor will I go to the movies to see the next 2 episodes or buy those dvd's. I'm not sure if I will ever go to a theater to see another Disney movie after what they've done with this movie. I resent the fact that they felt that long-term fans are irrelevant & could be disregarded in this way. Disney (& JJ Abrams) really screwed up the Star Wars franchise (IMO obviously) far worse than George Lucas ever did.PS- 2 dimensional characters & minimal plot didn't help the movie either.
