I have seen all Star Wars movies and unfortunately including this one.When J.J Abrams did a reboot of Star Trek, I was pleasantly surprised even as I was dismayed that Star Trek was turned into something it was not--a low brow action flick. But I also enjoyed the sequel--Star Trek: Into Darkness--with some reservation.Back to Star Wars: I did not like this movie and I did not understand what it's intent was. The story telling was poor, the acting was poor, the animation was poor , the use of 3D was poor and it did not have the largess of a typical Star Wars movie. It lacked polish through and through and it turned the force into a side joke. It might be fair to say that it destroyed Star Wars for any loyal fan. I am not sure of the impact it will have for younger viewers who have never seen Star Wars before this one.My expectations might have been too high, but the only person who has done Star Wars right so far has been George Lucas.I can suspect that the challenge of rebooting a franchise can be a daunting task. I am sure that the was work was hard and it is easy to be a critic, but this was a poorly done movie.

It is simply a marvel to witness the over hyping of a Hollywood blockbuster. The Force Awakens is a pretty good movie but Academy Award good as its critics rating would suggest? Not according to this discerning eye. Some basic observations.*Spoilers ahead*The positives: - Top notch CGI and engaging action sequences, as expected of Star Wars films.- Solid casting and strong performances by Daisy Ridley as well as Harrison Ford. It would not be a stretch to say that Rey effectively carried the film until Solo showed up. BB-8 was also pretty amusing for a non-human role. - The adequate use of humor without it becoming distracting or overbearing. Star Wars isn't a comedy so the sprinkling of humor was just the right amount.- No Jar Jar Binks like character. Let's face it, this alone was worth 1 star due to the pain that amphibian inflicted on the audience in the prequels. The negatives: - Far too many plot holes and fallacies. Why is the Resistance called such and why is it a separate entity from the Republic? If the Republic gained the upper hand after the battle of Endor, why would it feel the need to create a proxy militia to fight the Imperial remnants? Geo-politically it makes absolutely no sense. Also, why is the is the Republic only a handful of planets? Next, how was Finn able to reverse his life long brainwashing due to one single event that he was certainly to have been trained to endure? Most psychologists would be baffled by that I imagine. - Irritating and unconvincing villain. Kylo Ren was far too emotionally unstable and teenage like. That is hardly menacing by any stretch of the imagination. - While the casting for the main characters were mostly on point, there were simply too many minor characters. Phasma was basically a non-factor for the entire film despite the heavy marketing. And who was that storm trooper that called Finn a traitor before fighting him with the electro-baton thingy. It would have been nice to dive a little deeper into Finn's past as a First Order trainee and the relationships he built which may have served to explain why he abandoned it so readily. Missed opportunity. As a whole The Force Awakens works as a film and was entertaining. It certainly had its sentimental moments such as the Solo and Kylo scene but once you get over the nostalgia, the inherent flaws makes it rather difficult to rate this as anything but a 70% effort.

The ideas in this screenplay must have come from a fear of failure rather than an opportunity to create a new fresh path that would add to the Star Wars franchise. They take the "Luke I am your Father" idea from "Empire" and transfer it to Harrison Ford this time. Then they take the Death Star idea and from the original Star Wars and just give it the ability to kill multiple planets at the same time. And the protagonists are not real. The Daisy Ridley character is an expert at everything! In the original Star Wars we hear that Luke is an excellent pilot but he must spend time training with Obi Wan to gain skills with the light sabre -- then when he fights its believable! Not Rey -- she's an expert pilot, mechanic, and an instantaneous expert at with the light sabre with no training at all -- she defeats the main antagonist who has ostensibly spent his life training with the light sabre for the dark side. When we go into a film like this we know of course it's not real -- and so its the job of the writers to draw us in by making the characters feel real human which means they all have certain strengths and weaknesses -- They really need to let George write theses stories as he's a very creative writer -- this is his baby and he knows where it needs to go.

This review is rated SPOILERIFIC by Fly Casual Podcast. Virgin eyes and ears have been warned.The Force Awakens is here! FINALLY! After a year and a half of all the news, rumors and outright wackiness (at least from the crew at Fly Casual Podcast), we have our first taste of the new age of Star Wars. JJ Abrams and Disney deliver on the most anticipated movie of the year in a BIG way. As I write, The Force Awakens has been crowned king of the domestic box office $770 Million in gross receipts and has broken a myriad of records. Worldwide, the film is currently at $1.5 Billion with the movie opening in China today. The movie is at 93% Fresh on Rotten Tomatoes. What's not to like about this movie?There are a million different angles you can take on this, so instead of me trying to rationalize each and show how smart I think I am for having such a broad view, I am just going to give you my background with Star Wars to set the stage for this review so you get the sense of where I am coming from. I am a forty-something who has seen all of the films in the theater, albeit A New Hope was at the 1979 re-release. I grew up in the 80's with my Kenner Star Wars toys and have been there since the beginning. I avidly partook in what was called the Star Wars Expanded Universe (EU) which is all the books, games, and extra-movie material that came out almost from day one. I am what you would call an uber-fan of Star Wars. Not only is The Empire Strikes Back my favorite of the movies, I think it is one of the greatest films of all time. I love John Williams's scores for the films. I love Ben Burt's sound production. When people think of how a laser bolt sounds, they are actually hearing Ben Burt hitting a ground wire on a telephone pole with a wrench and the resulting vibrations. I am deeply entrenched in this stuff to the point that I co-host a Star Wars podcast with other Uber nerds and debate this stuff. I appreciate George Lucas's vision, but I am not an apologist. The man has flaws and they were on full display in the prequels. But don't get me wrong; I don't hate the prequels. Like most people leading up to this movie I had fun debating what we would see with the Disney/JJ Abrams incarnation. Listeners of Fly Casual over the last year and a half know how deeply we delved into these discussions. It's been lots and lots of fun. BUT, would the movie live up to the hype?As regular listeners of the show know, I was "not available" on December 17 when the rest of the Fly Casual crew went to see the movie and recorded Episode 70 live immediately after the movie. Following is my addendum to that episode.I have now seen the movie 4 times. Believe it or not, I saw it 3 times in the first 24 hours! I didn't realize this until a friend pointed it out. The first was by myself the evening of the 17th. I couldn't see it with the guys, but made it happen later at the 11:15 showing at our local theater. This was by far, my least favorite of the four times due in part to my criticisms of the film, a bladder FULL of Diet Coke, and over 3 hours of run time when you include trailers! My second viewing was the next day with my business partner. We skipped out and saw the film at the same theater at the 11 AM showing. My criticisms remained, but my "under-control-bladder" situation helped immensely with increased enjoyment levels. Later the same evening, my kids begged me to take them, so what's a dad to do? I felt pretty much the same at this viewing that I did at the viewing earlier in the day, but we were in a different theater that had the volumes MUCH higher and at a far more enjoyable level for me.My final viewing was in IMAX 3D. Now, our local "IMAX" theaters aren't true 70mm, but I am not a fan of 3D to begin with and this viewing did little to change that. I am not sure that seeing the film in 70mm would have helped, BUT the sound was even better with the demonstrably superior sound system in the theater.So let's just get this out there now. I am not "gaga" over the film as most people are and the way that most of my cohorts on Fly Casual are. I don't dislike the film. It was good! It has some very strong points. But the movie is not the home run I had hoped for leading up to its release. So let's get into the nitty gritty.The GoodGoing into the film, EVERYONE was buzzing about the "practical effects" that JJ Abrams planned to employ in the film. For the most part, he did not disappoint. Many felt like one of the things that made the original trilogy great was Lucas's limitations with special effects that forced him to rely on landscapes and well-conceived camera angles to deliver his film. When the effects-heavy prequels rolled around, Lucas seemingly forgot what made the originals great and embraced what many feel were lifeless performances by his actors due to lack of directing and nothing but green-screen sets to play off while delivering their performances. Abrams seems to have found the right balance of special effects and live sets. The film certainly felt more grounded, even if some of the sets and landscapes were too reminiscent of past films. If it looks like Tatooine and sounds like Tatooine and smells like Tatooine then why are we on Jakku???? In my opinion, Daisy Ridley stole the show. The character Rey was the right amount of everything: vulnerable, strong, gorgeous, expressive, funny, and "Roberta Badass." Some are actually criticizing the character as being a "Mary Sue," but I am all about it. She is definitely the new Luke in the series and I am excited about having an intriguing female character like this being the new lead in Star Wars.Lupita Nyong'o's character, Maz Kanata, almost, stole the show from Rey... almost. By far she had my favorite line in the movie, "Where's my boyfriend? I love that Wookie." The character is a Yoda analogue; a character that has been around for a millennia and has seen it all. With lines like, "I have lived long enough to see the same eyes in different people. I see your eyes. I know your eyes" one would think that in order to portray such a deep character you would need a wizened sage of an actor. Well look no further than barely-30-something Nyong'o. Her performance was brilliant. Han Solo is one of those iconic characters you don't want to screw up. Everyone is thankful for Harrison Ford and his $23 million return to the role. Han and Chewie are definitely a highlight of the film. There were a few times that Ford showed his age (running away from rathtars) and one time that Abrams skated dangerously close to the absurd (no-look shooting). But he represented the old guard well going toe to toe with Ridley and Boyega. He brilliantly portrayed a still brash and reckless Han Solo who IS 30 years older AND wiser. He will be missed from the franchise. I don't want to say that John Boyega's character Finn was the "surprise" hit of the film, but it felt that way to me. By all accounts leading up to the film, he was a talented actor and was expected to be the next Luke Skywalker in the series. I shouldn't have been surprised, but I was because going in, our only real exposure to him was one or two lines in the trailers and a lot of desert sweating. A LOT of sweating. To my delight, I loved Finn's character, who, by the way, is closer to a Han Solo than a Luke Skywalker. Finn is a loner who wants to run away as far as he can from the First Order. He does this to the point that he is lying to EVERYONE around him about his true intentions. If not for his affinity for Rey, he would have been long gone, much like Han's affinity for Leia in the original trilogy and desire to have nothing to do with the Rebellion. He was certainly a heavy part of the comic relief. I am interested to see where this character goes. I think I know where just about everyone else is going. Finn is up in the air.Adam Driver's character Kylo Ren has received mixed reviews from the people with whom I have spoken. Most critics are saying that he is not "evil" enough to be the new trilogy's villain. He is whiny and out of control. To me, these are the things I LOVE about him. Here is a darkside Force user who is being tempted by the LIGHT! He is a Skywalker! I am actually glad that we have a villain that isn't a scarred-beyond-recognition-amputee! I want to know more about him. Why did he betray Luke and the Jedi? What happened during the rebellion? Why is he so obsessed with Vader? How does Snoke play into his betrayal. I also thought that despite having to set up this character very fast to get to the payoff of the Solo death scene, both he and Ford played it as well as it could be played. From the tear shedding by Ren that had us believing for a moment that he was going to go with his father to the final touch of Solo's hand on Ren's face. Kudos on the performance. I am a fan. The BadAnyone who knows me understands that Luke was my hero growing up. The day I heard we were getting Ep VII and that the original cast was back I started conjuring images in my mind of Luke's return to the silver screen and the badassery that must ensue. Fast forward to December 18. Saying I was a little disappointed would be an understatement. I get it. The movie turned into the quest for Luke. Rumors early on were suggesting a very limited role for Mark Hamill in the film. I was somewhat prepared, but I really didn't think we wouldn't even be getting a single line from Luke. Listeners of Fly Casual know about what we call the "Fan Boy Wet Dream." In said "dream" scenario our hope was more along the lines of Luke being found and participating in the final battle sequences. Instead we get a robed figure turning around and pulling down his hood. Que music. I am taking this as well as I can and hoping for previously mentioned badassery to commence in VIII AND IX. Don't let me down Rian!John Williams is THE MAN! He has written every major movie score throughout my youth, formative years, and adulthood. The man is a genius with scores like Star Wars, ET, Indiana Jones, Jaws, Harry Potter, and a million others. The man is also 83 years old. The score for this film felt like an 83 year old man wrote it. What I mean is that it is not very memorable, with the exception of classic trilogy themes, I really don't remember the soundtrack at all. Even though Attack of the Clones is my least favorite of the films, I still remember the Anakin/Padme love theme which was brilliant. The best I can say about the new score is that I remember hearing the Rey theme and remember liking it, but please don't ask me to hum it. This is more than a little disappointing. Part of the problem is that the sound track in general is mixed poorly in my opinion (see The Ugly below). It feels like JJ called up Williams, and in his head was like, "What?! Another one?" They paid him a bajillion dollars and he futzed his way through it. I will be frankly surprised if he returns for VIII at 85 years old. I think they should have thought more long term, ripped off the Band-Aid, and made the change now.I remember our very first cast of Fly Casual in the summer of 2014 and talking about Disney choosing JJ Abrams to direct. We saw JJ's involvement as a double edged sword. We all knew what he could do with "look and feel" through "Super 8" and the Star Trek reboots. But one of our earliest criticisms of him was that he tended to sacrifice story and originality for said "look and feel." The more the rumors and images poured in over the next year and a half. The more concerned we became. Unfortunately he did not prove us wrong. In many many ways, this film is almost a complete replica of A New Hope complete with desert dwellers, a young idealistic kid, a sage old man, a rogue, droid carrying secret data, a masked villain, and on and on and on. After seeing The Force Awakens, I am happy that JJ was involved, but I am somewhat relieved he won't be back for snow planets, metal walking tanks, and a city in the clouds called "Jackee" in Ep VIII. Can anyone explain who or what is the Republic? I thought there should be more exposition there. Now I do realize that the "Empire" was pretty vague at the time of A New Hope, but I think that was out of necessity at that time. I think they could have been clearer about the status of Coruscant and the New Republic. Captain Phasma: wait, what? Rathtars: Unnecessary. Didn't feel like Star Wars.The UglyAlluded to above, my biggest complaint with this film, by FAR, is the sound track. By "soundtrack," I don't mean the just the music. The music was only the tip of the ice berg. I mean the sound effects, the music, and the mix. Why they felt like they had to completely recreate the sound of laser bolts is beyond my comprehension. When they purchased Lucasfilm, they inherited Ben Burt's sound library complete with the most recognizable laser sound effects in existence. When someone describes a laser blast, I would argue that most people hear Ben Burt's version. Suddenly laser rifles sound like crappy 1970's sci-fi. I was stunned. Even light sabers were changed. HOW ON EARTH DO YOU SCREW UP LIGHT SABERS?! I'll even give them a pass on Kylo Ren's lightsaber since it is "unique." But Skywalker's light saber sounded more like a jet engine! Part of the reason none of the music was memorable to me is that I couldn't hear it most of the time. Foreign Correspondent Steve Potter in the UK shares many of my criticisms of the film. He has told me that he has purchased the musical score and after listening to it, isolated from the film, he actually likes it. If that is the case, if there really is good music to present, why the hell is it tucked so deep into the sound track? After my first viewing of the film, I was downright mad. Now part of that was because of previously said full bladder. But even after my second and third viewing, that criticism remained. I will admit that at my 4th viewing at the IMAX Theater, I was able to hear many of the classic and familiar sounds I missed in previous viewings, BUT I still had to concentrate to hear them. I felt like the soundtrack was REALLY rushed on this film... almost to the point that the film was unrecognizable and unenjoyable to me. Call me an uber-nerd if you want and you're probably right that most people don't care or recognize this as a problem, but I do. With JJ Abrams reputation for look and feel, this was an unexpected misstep in my opinion. As previously discussed, JJ's "return to the well" of A New Hope was a noticeable problem. The icing on the cake is Deathstar 3, aka Starkiller Base. This was an absolute eye roller to me. There HAD to be another way to bring the film to a climatic end. That was just damn poor writing, Mr. Kasdan. When the Resistance was in the war room and Poe pulled up the side-by-side of the Deathstar and Starkiler base, I thought I was going to lose it. JJ is getting a LOT of flack right now from Lucas and other critics for making a "nostalgia film." Had there not been a Deathstar 3, I would stand in defense of him. He honestly deserves all the criticism he gets for that one. This is a total lack of creativity in my opinion.My final criticism of the film will only be relatable to fans of the EU. Many of us waited eagerly to see if beloved EU characters Jacen & Jaina (Han and Leia's twin children) would make their big screen debut in The Force Awakens in the form of Kylo Ren and Rey. We knew there was at best a 50/50 chance these characters would transition over to the New Canon (or Disney's newly established Star Wars timeline which renders most of the prior EU irrelevant). But not only did they tell us that Jacen and Jaina will not exist, but they also flipped us the bird when they revealed Kylo Ren's birth name to be "Ben" Solo. You see, in the old EU, Luke's son's name was Ben. I know some in my circle of friends are patiently waiting and hoping for revelations/explanations or even other EU characters to end up in the movies. In my mind this is a clear sign that the EU will have no place in the new movies, and frankly, this disappoints me. I will still enjoy the films. I enjoyed this film. But it would have been nice to feel like the filmmakers threw the uber-fans a bone. The LowdownStar Wars films evolve over time with me. Right now, I can't give this film more than 3 out of 5 stars. Good movie. I really enjoyed it. My kids enjoyed it. The film will become part of my collection. But it just doesn't have the classic feel with me yet. I am not certain about the staying power. I will say that I am glad that there is mystery returning to the saga. With the prequels, you always knew where they were headed. That is an inherent problem with prequels. With these new sequels, anything is possible again and THAT is exciting!My Star Wars order of favorite movies:1. The Empire Strikes Back2. A New Hope3. Return of the Jedi4. The Force Awakens5. Revenge of the Sith6. The Phantom Menace7. Attack of the Clones

The gangs all here, reunited in the galactic adventures of the Force awakening to rid the galaxy of evil. J.J. Abrams does a fine job in the continuation of Geo Lucas' visionary cosmic fable. Political correctness has visited that galaxy far, far away as now our heroine is Rey (Daisy Ridley) a space scavenger just getting by in the dusty outer planets and her hero of color Finn (John Boyega) who has deserted the First Order after a moment of conscience where he could not act as a deadly Storm Trooper and execute the innocent. You see, it's the 27th century or such and we have evolved! That aside, both do fine jobs and there are tongue in cheek moments with the wink, wink, nod, nod cuteness that really works as it's sprinkled in dashs. Stealing the show is BB-8, the new droid that is a whirling sphere with a frisbee hat that swirls, rotates, slides, glides and does all manner of mystical adherence to its first master, resistance pilot played by Oscar Isaac, who is a superb actor and feels a bit out of his sartorial element here. Nevertheless, the pursuit of truth, justice and the galactic way must continue. Darth Vader is the grandfather of the newest cosmic sadist with a saber, now played by Adam Driver as Kylo Rey and boy is he pissed. You see the force is with him, sort of. He just can't seem to wrap his light saber completely around being the lost, forgotten progeny of Hans Solo and Princess Leia. No matter, the cosmic sword play, planetary explosions and just damn fine CGI is terrific. The film is worthy of seeing in IMAX 3D and visually it does not disappoint. Minimal CGI as best as could be hoped appears and of course there are the signature Lucas space odd balls, galactic miscreants and shape shifting wierdos that you would expect. Max Von Sydow plays the long gone Alec Guiness and Carrie Fisher reprises and now General Leia sadly resigned to the impossibility of knotted hair and a meteoric turn in a bikini. The Wookie Chewbacca grunts in his dog suit to great effect. All in all a great ride, but in the grand scheme of worthy best picture 2015 offers, this film should not be nominated nor awarded. Far, far more worthy are Brooklyn, Sicario, Room, Spotlight, The Big Short and The Revenant. Most curious of all is how that centuries from now, in those galaxies far, far away, is it that the young heroine Rey has traversed the galaxy yet has a strong English accent as strong as if she'd just had afternoon tea with Her Majestiy. Go figure...but do go enjoy...

a brand new villian, a SUPER startling surprise as to who the villain is related to, LOTS of sci fi action, the good old fashioned "i have a bad feeling about this" line, a new lovable droid, familiar faces, lots of amazing special effects, and some VERY good acting made this movie SO enjoyable!!! i loved just about everything about this movie!!! and considering that a guy who is supposed to be a bad guy turns into a good guy, you just never expected that to happen!!! this should be getting awards for the Special Effects, and some of the acting was just awe inspiring!!!

When it was first announced that Disney bought Lucasfilm and that a new Star Wars trilogy would start development, I couldn't help but feel skeptical and not just because of the bad taste the prequels left in my mouth. Once the trailers started coming out for The Force Awakens, I started to feel a bit better about it. Then I finally saw the movie, and boy did I LOVE IT! Abrams did an amazing job at capturing what was so good about the original trilogy while combining it with other amazing new elements. The characters, both old and new, are fantastic and funny in this and the Star Wars style action will turn you back into that giddy kid you were when you when you first saw the originals. Sure the story is pretty similar to Episode IV's, but it still has enough new stuff to make it stand on its own. A Fantastic return to the galaxy far, far away. Sorry I once doubted you. Overall Score: 10/10 (Film of the Year 2015)
Star Wars is back full time!

The Force is strong in this movie. With a star making performance from Daisy Ridley, some other strong performances from John Boyega, Harrison Ford, and Adam Driver, the FA is a tour-d-force when it comes to even movies. The plot is a bit like A New Hope, but there are enough differences to the story, Harrison Ford shines as Han Solo, when he cracks that crocked smile with his silver hair. You are thrown into a time warp that doesn't feel dated at all. The other great editions (but the people who are not in it long enough) are Snoke, Maz, captain Phasma and Poe. Hopefully, the next few installments will fix this. The action scenes are great, (especially the big light fight saber fight at the end), so this movie has a lot of good going for it. The real strength of the movie is the two main young leads. John Voyega, and the luminous new comer Daisy Ridley, who runs through every scene in the movie like Donald Trump would burn a lie detector test up. She steals every scene with a wonderful mix of strength, vulnerability, and innocence. Her performance is worthy of an Oscar nod. Princess Leia shows up later in the movie, and it is good to see Carrie again, strong, intelligent and feisty as ever! The best moments involve Rey sliding down on her sled in the Jakku sun, Fin and Poe with their awesome bromance, Solo when he tries to talk to someone not to go to the dark side and Snoke telling Ren that he wants him to finish a task to see if he he ready to make the next move. The pacing is really good, and the movie has JJ Abraham's trademarks like the lens flair, the fast moving edits and the dark colors mixed with bring lines. They are used to great effect in this movie and JJ knows the force every inside and out. He knows what fans want and he delivers in spades.

Good acting, horrible plot. The lack of originality is massive, the screewriters and Abrams should be ashamed of the amount of plagiarism they put here. Copycat planets, copycat characters, copicat story. The movie is not a bad one, but with all the resources they had the results are embarassing.
it had flaws but everyone needs to stop hating on it for no reason

With a stunning cast of both returning and new characters and a clever use of recurring themes in the plot, The Force Awakens exceeds expectations. This spectacular film restores the franchise to what the Original Trilogy had established nearly 40 years ago. The plot that The Force Awakens hearkens back to that of A New Hope and Empire Strikes Back, revealing surprising new twists and turns, but JJ Abrams pulls it off by effectively using familiar themes that tie this new trilogy and the original trilogy together. But this repetition of material is made possible with the outstanding cast. Harrison Ford and Carrie Fisher jump into their roles with ease and it is a real treat to catch up with these beloved characters as the film progresses. Of course, Daisy Ridley, John Boyega, and Oscar Isaac help to rejuvenate the franchise and are welcome additions to the Star Wars universe. As always, John Williams creates a phenomenal soundtrack composed of familiar melodies and new scores. The Force Awakens is a welcome sequel to the Star Wars franchise and I cannot wait to see what the next film has to offer.

I wish I could give it less than half a star. Standalone, this movie would probably not be so bad. It would simply be another Disney movie. But it's not a standalone movie. and.. it was not supposed to be a Disney production.. (thank you Lucas.. hope you enjoy your millions). It's supposed to be a Star Wars sequel!After watching it opening night.. it was simply another disaster in a long line of disasters perpetrated by mega corporations on people's fond memories of films past. At least Jurassic World tried some to preserve the continuity of the original trilogy. Barring a few goofy missteps with raptors fighting alongside humans, it was a fairly entertaining remake. I had no hard feelings... but Star Wars is special.. It's our childhood. This movie made me appreciate the prequels! Have no desire to watch what happens next.. How can anyone want to see more? What's the "Empire Strikes Back" to this? The inept first order who only possessed one weapon requiring hours of charging and ignored buying some extra fleets of tie-fighters for good measure if they were swarmed? A goofy post-pubescent villain who evoked laughter rather than instill fear when he removed his mask. I was reminded of the time Dark Helmet in Space Balls removed his.. at least that movie was funny!How was the "force" the underdogs in this plot? Why go through the entire movie trying to find a lost Luke? Is he unreachable via the force? More importantly what's his role? We already have our Mary Sue to the rescue. She could very well have conjured a petronus charm and waved off all evil from the galaxy. I understand the need to provide a strong role model for 10 year old girls; movie seems to be targeted at the Frozen audience in that way..but seriously, even 10 year old girls know better and will hate this movie! Viewers are being misled. I am highly skeptical of the unusually large number of positive reviewers showered at this movie so close to release. It just rubs the cynical in me the wrong way. No way so many people liked it..anyone I run across who's watched it has mixed feelings or disliked it totally. But I guess studios have to create the hype for box-office ratings.I think this movie was riding on the success of the earlier movies. A true measure of success for this movie will be the second one.. which will have to stand on the shoulders of this disaster. Let's see how that goes. Will buy used dvd's for the next two to see what happens.. no way am I going to throw good money at this corporatized ideological nonsense. Maybe they hand it over to Michael Bay.. at least the action scenes would have some life.. cuz the rest of it is just one big black hole.
An amazing start to a new trilogy. Cool, interesting and likable characters with a cool story and great dialogue.

Having grown up under the loving embrace of a huge Star Wars fan, this movie far surpassed my pessimistic expectations. While it certainly wasn't without flaws, it used those flaws to its advantage and filled viewers with nostalgia and good feelings.Marketing wise, I feel like work could have been done. Some scenes that I believe would have made for incredible trailer fodder were glazed over completely. However, it wasn't as if the film needed a ton of hype to begin with. You could have just put a blank screen with "Star Wars" and a release date written in comic sans and people would still be writing blog essays on their theories on what possibilities such a deep trailer could possess. Good use of that wondersome man, Harrison Ford.Music was flawless, right on point with incredible timing and rhythm. It held quite a bit of the appeal of the original films' soundtracks, and each track suited it's scene. The only improvement I can see is not to change anything there, but to add something that I felt was neglected. You remember Vader's awesome theme that played every time his intimidating form stepped onto the screen? Yeah... this film's main villain lacks such an iconic measure. Maybe next time guys?Visuals were very impressive. 3D however did not enhance the experience whatsoever. But I have a disdain for 3D anyway. CGI was mostly convincing, and I did not see any clipping or blurring issues that would make it less realistic. PRACTICAL EFFECTS, I was so pleased with the costumes, puppets, and animatronics. LOVE. LOVE. LOVE.Characterization and writing was pretty spot on. Though some characters were obviously weaker than others (one of the main characters needs work) it is obvious that care was taken to the source material as well as the fact we get a bajillion sequels for characters to grow and develop. This kept the pacing under control, and the story flowed pretty nicely as well. Very satisfied.Highest Pros- Ship battles, camera work, strong but realistic female charactersLowest Cons- Villain actor choices all across the board. I'm not intimidated by anyone on the enemy side thus-far. The characters themselves have shock and power, but the actors chosen may be lacking. Sequels will tell us if its totally so.
Loved the characters but the ending was dissapointing
Amazing! The only part I would change was to see more of certain characters. But it was great and already can't wait for episode VIII!!!

STAR WARS EPISODIO VII "EL DESPERTAR DE LOS NOSTLGICOS"Ya tuve la oportunidad de apreciar tres veces el nuevo filme de J. J. Abrams. La primera vez, siendo tajante, no me gust. La segunda, me termin conquistando (posiblemente gracias a la experiencia inmersiva de la tecnologa IMAX). Y la tercera ya fue para establecer mis conclusiones entre el lado oscuro del "no me gusta para nada" y el luminoso de "soy muy friki, me gusta todo de Star Wars". El filme cumpli claramente su objetivo: entretiene. No obstante, parece que la industria a cargo de esta nueva franquicia tena un objetivo mucho ms grande, el cual fue "entretener a los fans de la triloga original que llevaban un mal sabor de boca por las precuelas". Y as fue. Disney hizo una dedicatoria muy explcita a todos estos fans, entre los que se encontraban crticos, quienes finalmente terminaron alabando el filme. Pero es realmente el mrito merecido? Pues no. The Avengers, otra pelcula de la misma productora que tena ms o menos la misma misin con los fans (con la pequea diferencia que no cargaba una generacin resentida), logr igual su objetivo similar. Y entonces cul es la razn para que dos pelculas, que quedan relegadas en la categora blockbuster, tengan una aprobacin abismal de la crtica? Bueno, sin fundamento para mi propia crtica existe la teora de que Disney paga a los crticos cuando lanza algo potencialmente peligroso a las butacas de cine. Pero aun as, lo ms probable es que todo est relacionado a encontrar al nio interior de las personas. Y es as como naci la nueva estrategia de marketing cinematogrfico denominado "nostalgia", responsable de las infinitas secuelas, reboots y dems productos en las que Hollywood ha cado porque lo peor que puede pasarles es perder dinero, dejando fuera de lugar el amor al arte.Y "El Despertar de la Fuerza" es un producto de ese tipo. De forma insistente, se merece el mrito de ser considerada una excelente pelcula? No, porque en realidad no lo es. Es un mrito conseguido mediante la subjetividad, aunque cabe la pena destacar que la pelcula tampoco es mala. Por eso, se haba afirmado al comienzo que cumple su objetivo, y s entretiene, lo cual es un punto a favor. Pero no trasciende. Ni los propios personajes de Rey o Finn van a trascender. Son disfrutables para la pelcula, claro, pero no lo sern para la cultura pop porque son estereotipos de humor y drama yankees. Un argumento para afirmar esto es el decepcionante guion de Lawrence Kasdan, a quien se le tena fe, y por ende las lneas que se le da a Finn. Aunque la culpa en s es del director, porque donde manda capitn no manda marinero. Abrams desde que fue elegido por Lucasfilm como capitn del barco de esta bomba de tiempo no ha hecho otra cosa que confesar su miedo por defraudar a los miles de fans (divididos en los bandos "hpsters de la nostalgia" y "s, apoyo las precuelas, crec con ellas, y no son malas"). Pero el Maestro Yoda ya lo dijo: el miedo lleva al lado oscuro. Y ese miedo fue responsable de la pobreza argumental de esta quinta entrega. Muchos afirman que no existen tantas similitudes entre este filme y "A New Hope", pero curiosamente son los mismos que deprecian las precuelas, los "objetivos fans de la saga". Sin embargo, s existen y son demasiadas! De hecho, cualquier persona en un nivel de fanatismo cero se dara cuenta que prcticamente todo el arco argumental de "El Despertar de la Fuerza" es un calco de la primera pelcula lanzada en 1977. Esta carencia de innovacin ha funcionado porque es fruto del marketing de la nostalgia. Supuestamente, el filme tambin incluye lo que las precuelas carecan: humor y desarrollo de personajes. De lo segundo no se puede discutir, pues realmente se not el esfuerzo a toda costa de traer personajes sometidos a toda clase de pruebas de fe muy obvias. Pero el humor... Es importante considerar una cosa como humor y otra cosa como chistes flojos y sin sentido. Por ejemplo, Finn le dice a Rey "Quieres volver a Jakku? Tienes un novio guapo ah?". Esa sola lnea puede disputarle el lugar a Jar Jar Binks. La pregunta es realmente eso es lo que queran los fans? Esa clase de chistes? Realmente son fans de la triloga original y la conocen tan bien como ostentan decirlo? El director de "El Imperio contraataca", Irvin Kershner, debiera estar revolcndose en su tumba. Personalmente, muchos de esos pasajes a lo largo de la pelcula me dieron vergenza ajena. Incluso as se afirma que el personaje de Finn tendr potencial. Finalizando, el filme cumple, aunque se siente por dems e innecesario. Los personajes son agradables. Tuvieron que crearse nuevos villanos para el nuevo argumento de esta pelcula, los cuales denotan que estn fuera de lugar para la antigua saga de seis episodios, donde quien majeaba los hilos era Palpatine. Por otro lado, el filme crea muchas dudas o da por explicado varios acontecimientos, lo cual se siente como arma de doble filo. Se insiste: el filme prometi lo que iba a ser, y lo logr con creces. Ha satisfecho a una horda de fans sedientos de la sangre de Jar Jar, sin destacar en innovacin o pruebas de trama... temas que George Lucas s explor en las tan odiadas precuelas.
The Force has awoken!
The absolute worst film of 2015! This is a paint by numbers retread of A New Hope. And it completely betrays the original characters, and everything it stands for!

Adequate movie to bring in the new era of Star Wars. Not the best film and nothing we haven't already seen before. This was a starter film that leaves you happy enough at the end. It follows the old story enough to keep as many of the old fans happy while still adding new characters for the next generation of Star Wars family.

Big fan of the first three, and it was good to find this one was done in the old school style with the necessary updates. Also, keeping over the top CGI and the cast of the Muppet Show out of the movie was a big plus. Kylo Ren is a weak villain however, and lost any intimidation power when he removed his mask. Two armatures that never heard of the "Force" took you down? Vader would never take crap from some metrosexual General, like Ren does. The battle scenes are fantastic and leave you wanting more. The new band of heroes introduced, seemed to gel together nicely, although Poe & Fin's "buddy" dialog seems a bit forced. Even with it's flaws, and rewarmed plot, it's still a great film, worthy of the franchise.
Just, incredible, the feelings, the emotions, i want to watch it 30 times more, but it gave us more questions than answers we had before, thats why i give it a 4.5

Finally an enjoyable Star Wars movie again. Although it reminds a bit too much of episodes IV and V and its pace is a bit too fast, this movie succeeds in entertaining the audience with some solid acting and decent - though not always convincing - plot. The proof of its success is that it makes you want more. Still I wished a bit more time spent with the main characters to learn about them. A special mention for Daisy Ridley who was fresh and excellent.

***Spoilers***Just as the first seven words in the film says "This will begin to make things right" The Force Awakens does just that. It completely wrights the capsized ship of Star Wars the prequels gave us.Some complaints that the plots of the movie follow the original trilogy are understandable, but this didn't bother me personally. Some complained that Ray learned aspects of the force to quickly as it took Luke a long time to learn. This also didn't bother me as well because Luke had no knowledge of the Force or Jedi where Ray knew the legend of Luke and she probably heard the fantastical things he could do. So once she accepted that she had this power she started trying it out, I mean would you? One of the biggest complaint was that she was able to fight toe to toe with Kylo with no training to the point of even beating him in the end. That as well didn't bother me because of the aforementioned knowledge of Force she had, also the fact that at best Luke only had 3 weeks of formal training between Yoda and Ben and he fought Vader and eventually beat him and Vader wasn't even injured like Kylo was. So training isn't as important as trusting in the force and letting it guide you.My only issue was nitpicky and it's that JJ doesn't have any sense of spacial distances, as you cannot stand on a planet and watch other planets blow up in your own solar system much less planets in a completely other solar system. Just like in star trek where they stood on that moon that wasn't orbiting Vulcan but yet they where able to watch Vulcan be sucked into a black hole. As well as the fact that Star Killer base makes itself useless by draining it's own sun. This would also kill everyone one that planet if you removed it's sun. I know this is not Star Trek and science isn't one of the major things you look for but you still need to keep some things grounded in realty to keep the suspension of disbelief.This film is a must see for Star Wars fans or even new people who haven't seen Star Wars before.

As a fan, I was completely disgusted. Complete lack of originality and just a tired reprise of the same old story line. Lackluster acting and poor continuity detracts from enjoyment of the film. I'm glad I only paid the matinee price.

I?m NOT a ?Star Wars? fan. Never have been, fortunately. But always loved watching action/science fiction movies. When I checked the internet, everywhere I saw that this movie had broken all Box Office records. Then I thought maybe, just maybe, this movie would be special . But it?s not, sadly.I found a lot of negatives than positives. Let me talk about the good part first. The special effects/graphics are amazing! And by ?special effects?, I also mean the beautiful landscapes on different planets, the action, the spaceships and the droids. (I loved BB8 in the movie). And now the negatives. The two things that I disliked the MOST are the story and the acting (by most of the actors).It?s difficult t prove my point without giving spoilers, but it is true that a LOT of the plot elements/ incidents are very similar/same to what has happened in the previous six movies. I was sincerely hoping that Lucas would take the story in brand new direction. But how wrong I was. Almost everything seemed like a repetition of what occurred in the earlier movies. I thought Lucas was very creative. But for some reasons, he decided not go for something original; he just presented the very same concept, that had worked many years back, again. Now about the acting. The veterans have done a great job. Ford (as Han Solo) was remarkable and Fisher (as Leia) was also nice but her role was quite less. Most of the newer/ younger cast were disappointing. John Boyega (as Finn) was irritating. Adam Driver (as Kylo Ren) failed to live up to his role. Ren is actually a very evil character but Driver just didn?t do much justice to the role. Daisy Ridley (as Rey) was very good but sadly her character itself was not sketched properly. What I mean is, Rey is actually a scavenger, surviving by herself on a hostile junkyard of a planet. Now such a person should be very tough and emotionless but she seemed to get emotionally attached to a lot of people. She seemed like a teenage fangirl when she says ?THE Han Solo!!?!!? and ?Luke Skywalker!!??!!!?. Overall, the film has failed to meet my expectations. I was expecting a lot from this film, in all the departments. The story was again a rehash of the previous movies. Most of the newcomer actors were not fit to play the roles they were assigned. After seeing this movie, it?s pretty easy to guess what?s going to happen in the sequel. I was never a ?Star Wars? fan and this movie has failed to change that.

The first sequel in the new Star Wars sequel trilogy has been hyped up all year. Its been used to basically advertise everything, from trucks, to batteries, to oranges, etc. The movie was directed by J.J Abrams, though he was only brought in to direct The Force Awakens and not the other two in the sequel trilogy. The story, setting, and characters feel rehashed to a really big extent, It has good characters for the most part,and It feels like its rushed.  To begin with it has a really unoriginal plot. It basically mirrors A New Hope and the ending of The Empire Strikes Back. Most of its characters feels like rehashes like Rey being a copy and paste of Luke Skywalker. The settings feel exactly the same but with different names. Jakku is basically Tatoonie, its houses look the same, and the desert looks the same, just with a bunch of destroyed Rebel and Empire vehicles everywhere. The First Order's Starkiller Base is literally just a giant Death Star with a different name. It feels lazy altogether and could of used more creativity.  The Characters in the movie are hit or miss. Rey is too boring and dry. Kylo Ren is a Darth Vader fanatic who is childish, impatient and whiny. He throws a big temper tantrum when something doesn't go his way, which makes me hate him as a villain. Which is a good job to me.The character Finn in the movie was actually pretty good as he brought a new point of view as a defecting First Order storm trooper. A over hyped character named Captain Phasma appears for like 3 scenes and barely does anything, a total disappointment . Some of the actors from the original Star Wars trilogy comes back and they put on a pretty good performance. Most of the acting isn't bad but the acting that is, is down right terrible. Finally, the film feels rushed and made to only sell because of name not story. It seems extremely stale in the beginning and becomes exciting towards the end with tons of action. If they took more time it would go beyond of being a sub par movie. I would recommend seeing it, its a good OK movie for today's standards but nothing special. The original trilogy was special because it was made to be something different and was different from its time. The Force Awakens feels like it was trying to be too much like the original trilogy, but failed because of it.

Like a jigsaw puzzle with just one piece, this film hungers for the context and resonance of the bigger picture. But in its own right, The Force Awakens stands tall as a well-executed, impactful and fun adventure.

Critics of the movie are disgusting. The fans who like this movie are disgusting. Shallow and undeveloped characters, Hollywood computer graphics that bore intelligent watchers, and unimportant but large societies that stage battles over what? What do either of the enemies have as societies that anyone cares about except that the good side wins against the evil side.

Kudos to J.J. Abrams and the artistic team behind this tall order. They could have easily paid homage and lose their own creative vision through the process, but their passion bleeds purpose, and the reverence to older characters, while bittersweet, ties into the script quite naturally.The screenplay executes onscreen like a well-oiled machine, with every bit as conflict-ridden as a hero's journey should be. I loved the character arcs introduced. Finn as the ex-stormtrooper in search of an identity presents interesting opportunities, especially in later sequels. Rey commands the screen and flips Episode IV on its back as the heroine and not the damsel-in-distress. Kylo, as the new villain, conveys a welcome vulnerability in the early stages of the new trilogy. Although the film may harken back to A New Hope with its trope, I personally did not mind as long as the conflict remains fresh and characters develop consistently, as the film has shown.Overall, I was proud of the product that the producers and filmmakers agreed upon. It's a business saga for the universe, but the creative force remains strong.
Disney's first 'Star Wars' adventure amounts to mere fan service whenit could have been a more meaningful extension of a beloved mythos.

This movie, on a personal view, was extremely disappointing. First off, the Star Wars series is legendary. Everyone knows Star Wars by name. Growing up watching the series in chronological order makes one feel emotionally attached to the plot, the persona and the characters. Watching this film felt like watching a rushed and half-hearted prequel to the epic series. The movie did not hit the spot for those who feel sentimental towards this film. Many will disagree however the movie was a waste of time and it did not feel like it flowed from the series. The newer episodes (The phantom Menace to Revenge of the Sith) connected extremely well to the original series. However The Force Awakens does not connect from Return of The Jedi. Some questions that were left in my mind after the film was- How did Kylo Ren (which sounds like a pretty poor name for a sith) acquire his training and powers after evil was destroyed in the galaxy? How did Rey just know how to use the force and a lightsaber within a short space of time while every other Jedi in history has to undergo years of training to learn the skills she demonstrated? What was the point of replacing one of the most loved characters, R2 D2 with a completely new character, BB8 when everyone see's R2, they automatically think Star Wars? Why were Leia and Han so separate from each other? Yes, their son had turned evil but is that a true reason to break this much loved couple apart? And isn't the Star Wars series about the Skywalker family? Why is the new Jedi a scavenger that just happened to meet Han Solo? Overall the movie was a massive let down to one of the most epic stories in history and I have no intention in going to see episodes VII and IX. JJ Abrams should not have written the story and has taken George Lucas' movie and destroyed the plot completely.

This movie is the definition of fan-service. It is a movie meant for the audience that wants to see it. This is not meant to be disparaging, this is a fact. While it is good to applaud those who take risks and make bold choices, sometimes it's not making the bold choice that matters, it's making the right choice. The much-maligned prequels were chock full of bold choices, stuffed to the gills with them. Bold, and universally awful. The original films functioned by being the monomyth. They weren't even inventive (beyond their setting and certain technical aspects). They were just a regurgitation of a story that has existed from before the time of Gilgamesh. But it's a story so central to what it means to be human, that its regurgitation is-- in itself-- a form of magic. It is the story that is ever-new. That Abrams hewed close to that eternal tale, and in doing so seemingly "copied" A New Hope isn't a fault, its a necessary part of the machine. The changes he made WERE bold, if subtly so. So see this movie, if you haven't already. It's fan service in that it is exactly the movie we needed it to be.
Recycled, inconsistent & shallow.
Terrible, the worst Star Wars to date. It is just a rehash of the original. It could have been so much better
Stunning! A true tribute to the original trilogy, which will one day stand on its own as a series.

Semi spoiler review. Read at your own risk if you have not seen the movie and want to find out for yourself. Being an avid Star Wars fan I would have to say this movie was not anywhere up to par of where it should have been. Don't get me wrong it was a good movie but it could have been 100x better. The story is completely broken. Yes I know when star wars came out back in 1977 it was to also broken but at the same time George had the scripts made out to give the foundation for episodes 4, 5, and 6. I really commend Disney for bringing back Harrison Ford, Carrie Fisher, Mark Hamill and others that were part of the original saga but they screwed this up big time. I mean come on to me this looked like they took episodes 4 and 6 combined them together and added small pieces of the ending from episode 3 and called it a new movie. Come on if I wanted to see those movies again I would have just put them in my DVD player. The ending of episode 6 eliminates the Sith and the Imperial forces and in 7 all of a sudden you have a new Sith Lord with an apprentice. Where is the story at of where the Sith survived the destruction of the Death Star how they came to be. Then lets take the Death Star blow it up in size by 1000x (using a planet this time) and call it something completely different when in all actuality its still yet another Death Star. This is not original at all George Lucas did this twice. Terrible idea Disney. Then lets blow it up in almost the exact same way that it was blown up in Episode 6. While they are working on blowing it up lets take the way that episode 3 ends with Darth Vader getting his limbs chopped off left for dead and do almost the exact same thing to Kylo Ren except this time all we are going to do is put some cuts and slices on him from a lightsaber. Come on I have seen this already. Yes I know George Lucas was just a consultant on this movie but why have him as a consultant if every single idea that he gives you shoot down.I know I am probably being overly critical about this movie but I wanted to see something new something exciting and for me this movie did not do it all. Some of the graphics in my opinion were not George Lucas quality graphics. The lightsabers looked fake. To many edges and looked more like fire then a semi solide beam of light. And there are many more in the graphics that could have been much better.For this movie out of 5 stars I give a 2.5 and the only reason it gets this is because it did have some good action scenes. Even though the lightssabers looked fake to me the lightsaber battles were good. There was some suspense in the middle of the movie when the rebellion comes to help but after that the movie just falls off into the same old thing as before.I hope that when and if they release Episode 8 they do a much better job at telling the story and filling in the gaps that should have been put into this movie and make it 100x better in all aspects. The story, graphics, and even the battles.I wanted to see the Force Awakens not see hey heres the force it never left at all.

el ya famos abuso de CGI....pero almenos la historia era fresca con nuevas ideas y personajes.Ahora el Episodio 7:El Plot: nada mas que una reciclada del episodio 4 con unos aspectos del episodio 5....un gran copy paste que no tiene merito donde se nos presenta lo mismo solo que mas grande 3/10la cinematografia y efectos especiales: lo mejor de la pelicula que recupera el feeling de la original trilogia a excepsion de 2 personajes que bn pudieron ser hechos con efectos practicos en lugar de recurrir al CGI 10/10Musica: el episodio con la musica menos memorable de todas 0 intension A New Hope Awakens when the Force Returns after the Jedi Strike Back(or how to compress 3 movies into one)(spoiler alert)The movie beings with (Darth Vader/Kylo Ren) killing a Rebel/Village Leader in cold blood and then capturing the Rebel (Princess Leah/Poe) to try and get a secret. (Darth Vader/ Kylo Ren) then tortures (Princess Leah/Poe). Luckily, (Princess Leah/Poe) hid the secret in a droid which escapes into the desert and is discovered by Luke/Rey, a "nobody" unknowingly strong in the force, who grew up in poverty without his/her parents, and rescues the Droid from being turned into spare parts by Jawa/scavengers. The Storm Troopers murder a group of (Jawa+Luke's uncle+aunt /villagers), and (The Empire/First Order) tracks down R2-D2/BB-8 on this desert planet. Then Luke/Rey, with the help of a reformed (smuggler Han/stormtrooper Finn) escape in a ("piece of junk"/"garbage") known as The Millennium Falcon. Famous actor, (Alec Guiness/Harrison Ford) plays an older father figure, wise in the ways of the world, who has guilt because his pupil/son killed his fellow Jedi and became the scary bad guy in the black mask, (Darth Vader/Kylo Ren). However, (Darth Vader/Kylo Ren) is just the pawn of the wrinkled (Emperor Palpatine/Supreme Leader Snoke), who appears in a hologram, and when (Darth Vader/Kylo Ren) battles Luke/Rey, he tries to convince Luke/Rey to join him and become his apprentice. (Obi-Wan/Han Solo) also confronts (Darth Vader/Kylo Ren) one on one, and Luke/Rey is too far away to help and screams," Nooo!" when (Darth Vader/Kylo Ren) use a light saber to kill a defenseless (Obi-Wan/Han Solo).There are atmospheric touches such as Cantina/Castle full of various drunk and degenerate Aliens, or a short, wise elderly green/yellow alien who senses that The Force is strong in Luke/Rey. (The Empire/The First Order) has an ultimate weapon than can destroy an entire planet/system, run by authoritarian military commander, (Grand Moff Tarkin/General Hux), yet his weapon has an Achilles heel, a single vulnerability that can be destroyed by small one manned space fighters. Luckily, this vulnerability is such an open secret that even The First Order's sanitation department is aware of how to exploit it.It's up to Han Solo to go down to the (Forest Moon of Endor/surface of the weapon planet) to set off explosives and disable the shield. This way, the Rebels/Resistance, hiding out in a forest base, will mount an assault, and seconds before the ultimate weapon unleashes its death ray, will blow up the ultimate weapon by taking advantage of this vulnerability.In this way, over the course of one, instead of three, movies, Rey instead of Luke, will suddenly, instead slowly, learn the ways of the Jedi and, after no apparent reason, instead of arduous training, will go from having zero control of the Force to gaining skills such as learning to mind control (Jabba the Hutt's translator/a storm trooper), pulling a light saber out of the snow, and finally mastering enough Jedi powers to defeat Darth Vader/Kylo Ren in a light saber duel. In a similar way, The Rebellion, which by the end of "Return of the Jedi" has a fleet of large ships when it defeats The Empire, becomes the Army of the Republic. Yet, somehow, during the thirty years that the Republic rules the Galaxy, the love child of Lord Voldemort and Gollum has recruited a new generation of storm troopers while the Army of the Republic has lost its armada and has disintegrated into a "Resistance" of a few dozen X wing fighters (likely because Congress used Sequestration to cut the Republics' military budget).

Completely Awakening your faith in one of the most popular and influential franchises in film history, the latest Star Wars offers a reverential, entertaining, and seamless bridge to the classic trilogy while building a storyline with an entertaining and exciting Force that's nearly as strong as its forebear. Remember the fever-pitch fan intensity accompanying the release of The Phantom Menace over 15 years ago, the white hot fervor that kind of smoldered once audiences saw how bad a film it actually was? Well, it looks like we were all building ourselves up for the wrong film. Star Wars: The Force Awakens course corrects the series, offering none of the candy-colored video game-aping empty calories heaped on filmgoers in the prequel trilogy. What proves most amazing about this improbable reboot is that director J.J. Abrams, a man who's already demonstrated a genius knack for re-invigorating an iconic sci-fi series (2009's Star Trek), nails a tone and channels a through-line that Star Wars creator George Lucas himself could not in the prequels. While that mostly soulless threesome feels unrelated to the original and much superior triumvirate, The Force Awakens feels like the next authentic step for this storied universe and these iconic characters. Make no mistake about it, however, as Episode VII doesn't focus on these returning heroes. Rather, the story smartly turns the spotlight on some new Star Warriors, with Han Solo and Company offering perfectly nuanced support.In this PG-13-rated continuation of the saga created by George Lucas and set thirty years after Star Wars: Episode VI - Return of the Jedi, balance returns to the Force as the First Order, emerging from the ashes of the Empire, clashes with the Resistance, which includes scrappy newcomers as well as heroes from the former Rebel Alliance. Oh, the script sports a few interesting points that could lead to qualms for some. First off, the story purposely follows the original film's plotpoints to a T (SMALL SPOILERS AHEAD: a droid holding a secret plays an imperative role, a lightsaber gets handed down to a potential future Jedi, the First Order boasts a planet-destroying moon-sized weapon that must be decimated), but this makes it that much easier to fall into the overall framework. Secondly, connectivity plays a huge role (MORE SMALL SPOILERS AHEAD: some new and old characters are related, characters happen upon each other rather conveniently to forward the narrative, a classic character makes a sacrifice to help in the development of a newbie and inspire a revenge plotline for future films), but these films have always held true to the simplicities of the classic myth structure wherein these tropes play a key role. Beyond these arguable gripes, everything - from returning screenwriter Lawrence Kasdan's excellently structured script to the perfectly chosen cast and their well-played performances to original composer John Williams' powerful score to the brilliant use of practical as opposed to digital effects as much as possible - makes for an emotional nostalgia sequel that sets your heart racing with empathy, action, and anticipation.Bottom line: Force Majeure

Story: D+Light Side Casting: B+Dark Side Casting: DVisuals: ASound Effects: AMusic/Score: CTHERE WILL BE SIGNIFICANT SPOILERS IN THIS REVIEWI read the gushing reviews, I heard from friends how amazeballs this movie was, and I went in with hope, hope that this would not fall prey to the failures of the prequels. This movie was better than the prequels, but there are still significant failings (although there is good here too)VISUALSVisually this movie is stunning, similar to JJ Abrams work in the Star Trek reboots. However, image isn't everything unfortunately, and the visuals can't make up for other failings (specifically storyline related)MUSIC/SCOREWhen I hear certain songs from the original, they conjure up images of specific characters, locations or entire scenes. There was a magic to the music of the originals and there is not one song that stuck with me from this film that will bring me back to it when I hear it.LIGHT SIDE CASTINGI felt that both Finn, Rey and BB8 were fantastic additions to the series and show promise. Poe fell a bit flat for me as did the CGI lady in the poor man's Cantina scene with the big glasses.DARK SIDE CASTINGMan, where do I begin? Kylo Ren, initially, is pretty cool, when he keeps his mask on. When he stops Poe's blaster bolt in midair AND holds it there, pretty damned impressive (even Darth could only swat away a bolt, never saw him stop one).But it's when the mask comes off that the character just loses all appeal. His visage doesn't inspire terror, fear or respect. He struts around like a temper-tantrum throwing man-child.Likewise, the General for the New Order was horribly cast as well, failing to inspire any confidence in his abilities to lead this galaxy-dominating armada. He, too, comes across as a temper-tantrum throwing man-child who is constantly tossing snarky remarks at Kylo Ren.Further destroying some of the immersion is that Kylo Ren looks nothing like Han and Leia's son, not one ounce.COMEDYThe comedy in this film, for me, was fantastic. A lot of hilarious moments that elicited outright laughter from the audience. JJ Abrams did this with the Star Trek reboots as well and succeeded I feel.STORYLINE AND PAYING HOMAGE TO THE ORIGINALSWhere this film really falters is that it tries too hard to pay homage to the originals. It pays so much homage, that it outright copies them, to the detriment of this film.The problem is that Abrams went too far in paying homage, which prevents this film from having it's own stand-out moments, its own ability to shine on its own merits.There is yet another super weapon, conveniently with a glaring weakness to exploit, this time it's just all bigger (the super weapon AND the weakness). And while the super weapon draining a sun to power itself was cool to see, the battle to stop it was a huge let-down. Sure, you get X-Wings and Tie Fighters, but that's it. Where are the massive capital ships, frigates and fleets to slug it out? We get none of that and this battle fails to pack any punch.Another major issue is the development of the two primary characters, Finn and Rey. Finn is just thrust upon us with little introduction, little reason to care about him or to even understand his decision to flee the New Order. We discover he was assigned to sanitation duty, yet we also see him participating in a ground assault and later he is able to outgun experienced tie fighter pilots in a ship he's unfamiliar with, doing a task (gunner) that one can only assume he is equally unfamiliar with. Later he almost holds his own in a lightsaber duel with an experienced Sith.Rey is too good. She's an orphaned scavenger who can fix things, fly things, shoot guns with perfect accuracy, duel with lightsabers and develops her force powers in about one minutes time and is then able to challenge a trained and experienced Sith in combat. Remember all the training that Luke had and he still struggled? Yeah, well we don't really get that here.Some would argue "oh, she's just a natural!" but I say poppycock! She's a natural at fixing things, shooting blasters, flying, lightsabers and the force? C'mon son!BB8 is a welcome addition to the franchise and has his own comedic moments and is certainly no Jar Jar.Han's death was painfully obvious and quite clich in how it went down. Leia struggles to stand out like she did in the originals, Carry Fisher has been away from acting for too long methinks.Overall this film was a giant disappointment for me. Although there is some hope, perhaps a New Hope, on the horizon. With the director behind Looper at the helm of the next film, perhaps there is something that can be salvaged. I definitely feel that the new light side cast can help this trilogy shine, hopefully the dark side cast doesn't drag it down too much.

I think JJ Abrams has managed to perform the same trick with The Force Awakens that he did very successfully with his Star Trek reboots. What I mean is this is nothing new on the others in the franchise but he hasn't meddled too much with the bits that we like. It has the look and certainly the feel of Episode 4 and there are so many nods to this throughout that fans will recognise. Like Episode 4 it has a bar scene (with a band), a Jedi mind trick, a droid central to the mission, a massacre that changes everything and parental issues. There's more that I cannot recall right now but this is no bad thing.A couple of questions did spring to mind, firstly, who has the contract for building Death Stars in the Star Wars universe? Whoever does must surely be considered the wealthiest and most powerful entity out there. I also have a question about the design of space stations in the Sci-Fi universe and why do they insist on building razor thin walkways with no rails and a perilous drop either side? Isn't there such a thing as the Intergalactic Department for Health and Safety? If so then they need to stop sipping on Pan Galactic Gargleblasters at lunchtime and up their game. The flow of the film is very slick with excellent action sequences (esp. in IMAX) and it doesn't feel like a two hour plus film. Performances are good with perhaps Daisy Ridley (Rey) being the standout as it was difficult not to warm to her. Kylo Ren was also a decent baddie and what The Force Awakens does is introduce new characters, reintroduce old ones and setup things for the next one so hopefully (as with Star Trek) the best is yet to come.

Old meets new in one of the best Star Wars films since The Empire Strikes Back. Long time fans will love the nostalgia and new fans will appreciate the two young leads, especially Rey, who is one of the best characters to come around in the Star Wars universe in decades. The story may seem familiar, but J.J. Abrams still brings his own style, mixing CGI with practical effects which makes the film have a down to earth feel. The action is intense and the classic characters all have their moment. Harrison Ford is the anchor and he guides the new characters as the torch is passed to a new generation of heroes. It was 2 hours of fun and entertainment and that is what Star Wars is all about.Grade: A-

In trying to recapture what made 'Star Wars' so special, director J.J. Abrams and new franchise owner Disney decided to introduce a bevy of young characters, along with some old fan favorites, over a plot that is -- for all intents and purposes -- the same as George Lucas' original film. Star Wars has always been mythic storytelling, and even the prequels featured elements mirroring the original films. But this entire approach struck me as lazy and trying to play it over-safe. To make matters worse, Abrams kind of already did this with his rebooted take on 'Star Trek' -- I expected more of him, frankly. To the filmmakers' credit however, the new cast shows a lot of promise; under the guidance of a director less willing to hang themselves up on nostalgia and take some chances, this could bode well for further installments of the new trilogy.

I went to see Star Wars The Force Awakens around 2 weeks ago and as a big Star Wars fan I really enjoyed it. I was worried before going into the cinema thinking this might be like the prequels (even though the prequels were ok in my opinion). I liked the new characters, I liked the return of the old characters. I thought the chemistry was better and the dialogue was better than the prequel characters. It had funny banter, there was more emotion. A lot of the negative comments are all the same, "It's too much like A New Hope". A lot of the negative comments about the prequels were "It has too much CGI, no emotion, no action, no characters you get attached to, awkward dialogue etc etc and then when this film comes out which has none of that, people still complain. You just can't please some people no matter what you do like.Another thing people criticise is "How come Rey knows nothing about the force but can use a lightsaber all of a sudden?, it's stupid" Well if you watch A New Hope, Luke Skywalker has never flown a starship or x-wing before and here he is blowing up the death star and flying in space, here he is shooting at Stormtroopers even though he has never been in armed combat before. People seem to forget that.

I really wanted to be wowed by this film, after the disastrous storytelling of the Episodes I -III, J.J Abrams, gives us and the new generation of kids a satisfactory Star Wars adventure., it has lots of action, lots of good humour and a mixture of good CGI and practical effects.The story beats are quite similar to a New Hope, maps, droids rebel alliance an empire weapon which is similar to the original death star, a way to destroy it similar to both A New Hope and Return of the Jedi. Also character reveals likes all three of the originals. The darkness of Empire Strikes Back, it's all rolled into this one installment.The acting is solid and more grounded with John Boyega, Daisey Ridley, Oscar Isaac, Adam Driver and Domnhall Gleeson all give believable and highly enjoyable performances.Like I said I wasn't wowed by this film, I enjoyed and I liked it, and is perhaps the most enjoyable to date, but it didn't give me the wow factor that Man of Steel and Captain America Winter Soldier did, but then again that's just me.Overall a triumphant return to the benchmark space opera and franchise. Roll on Episode VIII
