For me this movie was incredibly painful. There were constant flaws within the character's stories and within the overall plot itself. Everything felt forced and rushed along as JJ Abrams tired his best to smash in all the Easter eggs he could that would give old timers a sense of nostalgia and make them forget what a bad movie they're watching.My problem with (inappropriate) humor:  Don't get me wrong, I've enjoyed humor in the previous films of Star Wars but this movie felt like a Marvel superhero film, with humor added in all the wrong situations. Star Wars films (the good movies) have a history of having darker tones until, despite all odds, the heroes barely manage to escape, where Marvel movies have gotten a reputation for lighthearted, funny movies without any real danger posing significant threat. Jokes are inserted at inappropriate times, ruining the gravity of grave situations for the heroes in The Force Awakens. The biggest example of this is when star-pilot Poe Dameron is captured and when face-to-face with the newly introduced Kylo Ren blabs out "So who talks first?" and other light hearted dialogue to get some cheap laughs out of the audience. Yes some people laughed, but at what cost to the mood? This ruins a potential scene for Kylo Ren to establish himself as fearsome and creates a scene for the audience to begin to associate danger with laughter, similar to Jar Jar Binks goofing around in the middle of a fire fight. My problem with the plot:Next we move on to the problem of the plot.... In that it is the same plot we have seen TWICE already. The resistance (the rebels) must defeat the First Order (empire) by blowing up the "weapon" (death star) by attacking an exposed portion with solo pilot aircraft which will lead to a system wide explosion rendering the battle station completely destroyed. Is this ringing any bells?My problem with "the weapon":The weapon is powered by SunnyD and the power of the sun. Despite the problems posed by bringing an entire sun into a planet and still having frozen snow on the surface, let alone any living thing not instantly being incinerated, it still takes the perfect amount of time for the rebels to win despite there being a perfect demonstration by blowing up the new republic government (a story I am left very curious about but I guess we'll never hear about it since they just get blown up). And what happens when the planet runs out of suns to use as fuel? Are there giant engines that will move it to the next sun, and can the First Order control the rotation of the planet or does gravity go all crazy when positioned to attack a new target. It must have some kind of rotation considering it is portrayed as being in orbit around some kind of sun. My problem with the character Finn: His entire role seems very forced for me. His affection for Rey is nearly immediate and he seems to be the only Stormtrooper that can aim in the entire franchise of Star Wars. He shows his prowess with a blaster during the raid of the new JJ Abrams' version of the Cantina. Killing soldiers left and right with his blaster, despite working sanitation and not firing his weapon once during his "first mission." His prowess with the lightsaber is thrown on the audience as well, defeating the Stormtrooper in close quarters combat and holding his own against the trained Kylo Ren. He is even able to use the TIE fighter's and Millennium Falcon's weapon systems with expertise, shooting down trained First Order pilots in while in both ships. My problem with the character Rey: Throughout the first portion of the movie we see her as alone, waiting for someone to come back to her, presumably her family, and only coming into contact with some other scavengers only to have a negative interaction with them. Despite this reclusive lifestyle she is able to understand what BB-8 is telling her, understand Chewbacca's language (Shriiwook), and seem to understand how the machinery in multiple ships work. My biggest problem with this character is possibly her actions. She was able to fly the Millennium Falcon flawlessly after around 15 seconds of trial and error, weaving through star destroyer wreckage and outmaneuvering the First Order's trained pilots. Also she seems to know the ship better than Han Solo himself as shown when she fixes the hyperdrive, while being portrayed as never having been in the Millennium Falcon before. Another thing, she is able to out-duel and use the force much better than the actually trained Kylo Ren. Even with training being so emphasized in the previous 6 movies she is able to defeat the feared Kylo Ren despite not even believing in the force until halfway through the movie.My problem with the character Kylo Ren: Being portrayed as the new Vader we see immediately that he is nowhere near as fearsome when instead of killing the messenger of a bad report he vents his anger out onto a control panel like a child throwing a tantrum. He finally loses all fearsome characteristics once he takes off his mask, showing that he is only a man, and a scared one at that, that bring back memories of pre-Vader Anakin Skywalker who whines his way through movies. The new Sith is shown as powerful with the force, stopping a laser blast and paralyzing two rebel fighters. But then when it is time to get information from Rey by using the force, which apparently can be used as some form of telepathy now, he is denied entry by Rey who is using the force for THE FIRST TIME IN HER LIFE! This does not show the power of Rey but merely the lack of power of Ren. Also when Kylo Ren kills his father, Han Solo, he leaves no room for redemption in his future. During the scene of Han's death the theme seems to fall upon Kylo Ren wanting redemption and to join the light side of the force, but after killing possibly the most loved character in the Star Wars universe he will find no love from the fans and if he is still alive by the end of the trilogy Disney will have needed to pull off a miracle if the fans are to accept Han's death going unavenged. My problem with the character Captain Phasma: Much like the rest of the First Order, Captain Phasma is initially portrayed as a character who will give the heroes a great deal of trouble. Eventually, during the short amount of screen time she got, she comes out looking like a wuss. She captured too easily and just agrees to the demands of the 4 rebels despite being on a base full of her loyal troops. Amazingly she agrees to turn off the most crucial aspect of the battle station's defenses. Without Captain Phasma, the rebels would have never succeeded. Her giving in so easily is surprising because she should know the risk that goes with her actions, she should have been a good soldier and made Solo, Rey, Chewy, and Finn kill her before she enables the rebels to destroy "the weapon" and possibly all of the First Order. My problem with Han Solo's death: I did not have a problem in the death of the character but rather in how it was handled. Han Solo is arguably the most loved character in the franchise and should be given a proper send off if he is to be killed off. I never got that from this movie. Han's death seems to be brushed aside for the sake of focusing more on Finn and Rey's story. There is never really screen time dedicated to dwell on the loss of everyone's favorite scoundrel. A quick look between Rey and Leia is all we get. One would think that there would be some ceremony for a hero of the rebellion but that just would not fit into the new jovial Star Wars. At least Qui-Gon got a funeral and he was only in one movie of the franchise but a fan-favorite completing his fourth movie barely gets 30 seconds of characters mourning for him. I was conflicted on what emotions JJ Abrams wanted me to feel exiting the movie. Of course I was still sad at the loss of Han and with no real closure or time to mourn him I stayed sad for the rest of the movie, meanwhile the tone shifted to one of hopefulness as Rey finds Luke (much easier than the movie made it seem it would be) and starts her training. Hopefulness and sadness are emotions that do not easily mix, though one could make the argument that I could feel sad for Han's death and hopeful that Rey will beat the Sith but she already did that. And since the rebels seem to have already beat the First Order I am left not knowing what to be hopeful for and feeling sad at the same time.My problem with the "epic duel": When it comes time to see the final duel at the end of the movie we have a matchup between the evil Kylo Ren against the two heroes, Rey and Finn. Kylo Ren is clearly hurt from a blaster as he took a blast from Chewbacca's crossbow but he demonstrates the ability to endure the pain and function regularly as he beats his wound repeatedly. What is expected is a complete massacre of a deserted soldier and a scavenger but what the audience gets is the opposite. Of course the good guys must win eventually but they do not need to win in the first movie of the newest trilogy. In both previous trilogies, successful or not, we see our hero attempt to face off against the villain and lose. This happened in the cases of Qui-Gon against Darth Maul in The Phantom Menace, Anakin and Obi-Wan against Count Dooku in Attack of the Clones, Yoda against Darth Sidious in Revenge of the Sith, and finally Luke Skywalker against Darth Vader in The Empire Strikes Back. These losses happened for a reason, to show that the hero is not yet ready to defeat the evil that opposes him/her. It gives added fear toward the main villain and shows how powerful he is. The idea of a Jedi training to gain skill has been stressed so much in the previous 6 movies the thought of even a novice Jedi defeating a Sith Lord would be absurd. But in Star Wars 7 we do not only see a scavenger beat a Sith, but we also see an ex-Stormtrooper hold his own against the "fury" of Kylo Ren. Having the new Darth Vader figure be beaten by a scavenger who has never wielded a lightsaber, never had any combat training against trained soldiers, and did not even believe in the force until halfway into the movie extremely belittles his ability to bring any concern to the audience over the danger of their hero. During the next movies we will possibly see Rey or another main character face off against Kylo Ren again. Now at the end of the movie we see Ren go to complete his training (I have no idea why he was in charge if his training was incomplete) but we also see Rey find Luke and begin her training. By Star Wars 8 both will have improved but one would think Rey would have improved exponentially due to her absolute lack of training during her entire life. We will have a face-off in later in the series that we have already seen, with no added tension because we there will not be much doubt about our hero due to Kylo Ren already being brutally defeated in Star Wars 7. Why are there still rebels?  It has been 20 years since the destruction of the empire and a new republic has been created. Usually when a rebel force overthrows a government they become the governing body and cease to be rebels, creating a capital and government to rule in. One would think that after the rebels create a new government that they would at least move their base to the planet where their new government is. So why do the rebels still exist in this movie? Also, why does this new republic allow the creation of a new death star? They must have clearly understood what was going on because it is hard to build or modify an entire planet without the ruling government finding out. And still nothing happens. No one remembered a few decades ago when an entire planet was destroyed and clearly no precautions have been enacted to stop this type of attack from happening again. But hey, everyone seems to love the lack of originality. At the end I was left searching for anything to like about this movie (I really wanted to like it), anything that would give me a decent overall feeling about the film, like the fight between Darth Maul, Qui-Gon and Obi-Wan with Dual of the Fates ringing in the background. But even the film score left me wanting something much better. Unless someone can convince me there is something to like about the movie besides less than 3 minutes of cool X-wing vs TIE-fighter action and a few Easter eggs, this movie will take its place as the 7th best in the franchise in my mind.

I will say this about the movie, it is entertaining. And when compared to some bad movies out there, this isn't necessarily a bad movie, overall it is very well done, the sound is great, the visuals, the effects, even the acting is good.However, when taken in the context of Star Wars, this just does not feel like a star wars movie, the pace is completely wrong, the characters are flat and basically rehashes of previous characters from the saga. There is just no sense of accomplishment anywhere, it is as if the plot just moves along, there is no sense of struggle for the heroes, everything just conveniently happens. I went in with fairly low expectations, so in some ways I was pleasantly surprised, but I left disappointed overall. It is better than the prequels, but not by much. This movie really is just Ep IV, V, and VI rolled into one, with a female Luke Skywalker.

Besides watching Harrison Ford and some of the humour, this is much of a fans movie. As for the story, it's pretty linear and it leaves A LOTS of "unanswered questions" which is pretty much a setup for the upcoming StarWars episode in 2017, another in 2018, and another one... until no one remember about the force....

This was a super-hyped, lukewarm imitation of the original Star Wars movie. Whole scenes have been lifted and re-imagined for a new audience. It's two and a half hours of my life I'll never get back. Couldn't have been more disappointed..

Star Wars Episode VII: The Force AwakensInitial Reaction: Did it have a good nap?Main Characters Finn: He's a stormtrooper played by John Boyega. Rey: She's a junk scavenger played by Daisy Ridley Han Solo: Yeah, that guy. He's played by Harrison Ford.Plot Summary A BB-8 droid has become the target of the First Order (new name for the Empire). Why? Because it has the location of Jedi Knight Luke Skywalker. After a short fight, the droid lands under the care of Rey, who teams up with Finn in order to make sense of the map in the BB-8. But to get off the planet, they have to get a ship - and they just happen to land the Millennium Falcon - Han Solo's ship. Soon after, Han gets the ship back and agrees to help out. Problem is that Han and Leia's son is on the First Order's side - and he will do anything to get the map.SCORING Main Characters Han's just like I remember him in all the other Star Wars films he's in (which is good). But what's really surprising is how well Rey and Finn fit into the mix. They've got some chemistry and an appealing back story. SCORE: 9 Supporting Cast The rest of the cast is good, lead by the main bad guy, Kylo Ren. And it's good to see Leia again - even without the iconic hair do. SCORE: 8 Plot This film is over two hours long, but I had no trouble sitting through it. It's great that they can bring in new characters yet make use of the old ones.  The only problem I had with the story is that I felt parts of it were just a rehash of Episode IV. But that's a minor complaint. SCORE: 8 Originality This film does the look and feel of a Star Wars film, but they do a few new things with the characters - namely Finn and BB-8. SCORE: 8 Violence Factor Lots of stuff gets blown up - and this time the wreckage just doesn't vanish into space. And there are shots of damage a laser blaster can do when it hits a person. And the stormtroopers can actually hit their intended targets. And someone gets killed when someone else thrusts a lightsaber through the chest. This is far more realistic than any of the other Star Wars films. SCORE: 8 Other Moral Issues This film is about trying to figure out what the best course of action is to save the day from an evil empire. But I wonder how did the First Order got so powerful in the first place? SCORE: 7 Final Score (out of 60): 48 % Score: 80% The force is strong with this film.

LOVED This movie! I know there are some "things" that I wanted to see and had issue with, but I know that in the next parts (8 & 9) that some of these "things" will be rectified in the upcoming movies. I understand why some people have issues with this movie but I feel like there is an explanation for everything and all that counters the hate for me. I saw this movie as a love letter, one that brings back the good old times of 4, 5, and 6. Go see this movie 3-4 times, every time you'll have even more appreciation for it. I was excited, laughed and even shed a few tears.

All in all, this reboot of the Star Wars franchise was great in the sense that it lived up for the most part to the prerelease hype it was given.I thought it was a great movie and Kylo Ren is one of the most intriguing characters in recent cinema. Kylo Ren's psychological struggles are genius and his temper tantrums per se make him all the more intriguing. This being said...I believe it to be a damn good movie but an overrated one at that... similar to, "Avatar."In terms of directing I do not believe it compares to: Ex Machina, The Hateful Eight, Birdman, or, The Revenant.As an action packed movie I believe it is second this year to...Mad Max: Fury RoadHowever, Star Wars buffs will not be displeased and it is a must watch.

This movie is designed to make you feel like a kid again. Sure it may be a near carbon copy of the original 1977 film (soft reboot is the term I keep hearing), while being a bit rushed or convenient at times, but my brain didn't care. My brain just said "Nostalgia! Exciting things flying around on screen! Smile dammit!" And I subsequently smiled and had a great deal of fun. It was the movie it needed to be. Nothing more. Nothing less. And that is extremely satisfying :)

Star Wars is back, and in my opinion is better than ever. Sure, I am super nostalgic about the original trilogy, but the original trilogy never had the caliber of actors and professionals working in it. The new cast elevates, in my opinion, this movie above the others. Rey, Finn, Poe and Kylo Ren are each interesting and well though out characters. In particular, for me Kylo Ren steals the show. Adam Driver gives us one of the most in depth and appealing villains in a long time...or is he a villain? All I know is that Vader is no longer the standard of a good Star Wars villain. The movie is always fun, and for the two and a half hours it plays, is a constant thrill ride. Time will indeed fly by. One of the best movies of the year without a doubt. Enjoyable every time you watch it!

Despite it has the similar plot as An New Hope, the Force Awakens brilliantly brings the magic of A Galaxy Far, Far Away with the same glance as the Original Trilogy. J. J. Abrams mastered the directing as Irvin Kershner did during the making of Empire Strikes Back, all new actors are great in their roles: Boyega is both charismatic and funny as Finn, Ridley's Rey is lovely, Isaac in Poe Dameron's boots is as cool as Wedge Antilles (not ironic) and despite Revan's influence of Adam Driver's Kylo Ren, Adam is great as a fallen Jedi Knights. All the original cast is excellent, especially Harrison Ford reprising his role of Han Solo. The effects are visually marvellous as well as glorious. Step back to practical effects in an era of computer-made films was a good idea. With one word: Epic. What else to say?

I loved it. I've seen all the movies and I love the originals and I can even see the positives in episodes 1-3 but I really liked this new iteration. I see it almost as a blend of a stand alone and prequel. It is a movie in itself but has set up a way for the world to go off in many different directs that I'm excited to explore. I am amazed that people are so upset by the unoriginality of the movie. For one, the original borrows so much from the epic tradition and adventure movies/novels of the past that it's hard to see the battle between good and evil as anything else. And episodes 5 and 6 are basically the same as episode 4 rehashed and expanded. I don't mean this as a criticism. It's an exciting series of movies and this continues in that fashion. I think, if the next two movies are well done and do explore the characters and how they deal with challenges then we will have another set of excellent movies. I loved the characters or Rey and Finn (and Po if he were in it more). I cried when Han died. I look forward to more Luke and Leia and I wasn't bored once. It's definitely lived up to my expectations!
A new star wars for the newer generation. And what a great start for the franchise. It had emotion, drama, action and humor in spades. Looking forward to the next installment.

This was not a bad movie, but not a great or epic one either. There's a lot of cut and paste of old ideas, kinda like code reuse. SPOILER ALERT from here forward:There's the usual alien bar scene, the outpost of scavengers, the my family member is evil seduced by the dark side but I think I can change him, the evil dude in the odd mask (who this time turns out to wear it because he wants to), the really big weapon that has awesome destructive force but can be destroyed by a small force yadda yadda. The line from Battlestar Galactica comes to mind, all this has happened before and will happen again (we can only hope not). And of course the reunion of all the old stars felt almost forced. I thin they almost needed to put a name tag on Princess Lea so we could recognize her, not to mention Luke's cameo. We saw it in IMAX 3D and I was also underwhelmed by that. The 3D did not seem to have the same "depth" to it, or the same depth of field. And you had to keep your head rotated at exactly the right angle or it was out of focus. All in all I would say wait for it to hit the small screen and you won't be disappointed (quite so much). I give it three and a half ... yawns :)

It's been a few days since I seen the movie. In the time I decided to drop my score another half a star. While I did enjoy this film for the most part. Much more than the previous installments, Episodes 1, 2, and 3. There are huge glaring flaws to this movie that really hurt it's potential to be more enjoyable. Biggest being the huge lack of chemistry among the cast. I found myself wishing that both Harrison Ford and Carrie Fisher were not in this film. They looked and felt absolutely uncomfortable whenever they had scenes together. While I found Rey to be a very likable character, someone I am truly interested in seeing where she goes in the future. I hope that future does not include the character of Finn. Boyega is another actor that didn't seem to have chemistry with the other actors, and that is not mentioning that this character was very poorly written. He was this movie's Jar Jar Binks, though not quiet as annoying, but getting there. Another peeve, too many references, hints and copying of Episode 4, there were moments when this felt as if it were a remake rather than continuation. We need more original ideas writers. As for Kylo Ren, the temper tantrums left me perplexed, really didn't add anything to the story, seemed like something that should have hit the cutting room floor in my opinion. My favorite things taken from this more were Rey (Daisy Ridley), BB8 ( had most of the successful humorous parts ), and the ending of the movie. Loved the ending, and left me very curious to see where the Skywalkers go in the next movie.
Very good, though a lot of borrowing from the originals.

Horrible unoriginal movie, which solely builds on nostalgia for the original trilogy, while ironically taking a crap on all the accomplishments of our heroes in Episode VI. As soon as the hype dies down this movie will be recognized for the cinematic faecal matter it is.

Star Wars: The franchise rebooted is a very safe by the numbers movie that did not excite me at all and this is a movie which I had low expectations for to begin with. Now, I might get some flack for this but let me explain why.Minor SpoilersBasically, the movie is a new hope re-packaged. Nothing has changed in the galaxy, except the Empire is has become vestigial and the old cast of the original trilogy ended up being a bunch screw ups that managed to get everything back to the same condition as a new hope. It's like watching the new spiderman reboot. Guys, I really don't need to watch uncle Ben die for the second time. The acting: The original cast.It was okay, it was nice to see Harrison play Han again. He even manages to put a performance that is slightly better than his performance as Indy Jones. Though, as character arc, having old Han Solo in the same spot as New Hope Han is quite disheartening. Carrie Fisher Leia is also a tragic figure, she is relegated to the role of Mon Mothma as Ms. Exposition mixed in with disheartened mom who for having the rank of general does very little commanding, that shit is taken by Admiral Ackbar.Mark Hamill Luke is barely in the movie as sequel bait. The only ones that didn't show their age was C3PO and Chewbacca. R2-D2 had one tiny part to play as he was shown up by the volleyball robot.The villains:New Darth Vader/Kylo Ren: Is a laughable villain, they managed to resurrected all the cringe worthy moments of Anakin Skywalker, with an actor that cannot play a torn soul and whose actions are so inept that new emperor should have killed him.New Emperor/Supreme Leader: Again a mere shadow of the menace that was Emperor Palpatine. Also poor Andy Serkis will be cursed to play CGI motion capture model for the rest of his career. He also just there as sequel bait.Quota Stormtrooper/Phasma: Why did they feel the need to waste Brianne of Tarth on this. She is NPC with like two lines and no reason to be there plot wise. She isn't even like a super Stormtrooper. WTF. Even gets captured.New Tarkin/Hux: Surprisingly manages to halfway steal the show, though his whole purpose was to be a Hitler knockoff. Just missing the mustache.The heroes:Reverse Darth Vader/Finn: Is not too bad, though I wish the story was a little more developed. Would have been nice to see him in the Stormtrooper role for a little longer and fuller arc to heroNew Luke/Rey: Again not too bad, thankfully sparing me" I'm female hero so that means I'm a mega bitch" to very minor levels which is actually is joke in the movie. Kind of wooden and also lacking development.New Han sorta/Po: Is missing from about half of the movie and is relegated to hand wave plot motion device that is actually quite sad.Minor charactersNew Yoda/Maz: A full-fledged alien Ms. Exposition who sole purpose is to push New Luke to Old Luke.The effects: Were good, if the camera work didn't excite. Thankfully, someone told JJ to knock it off with the lens flairs. The soundtrack: Classic John Williams, though there wasn't any Imperial March or Duel of Fates to speak of, it's kind of sad really.Finally, I'm pretty sure this movie is going to get high marks from everybody else cuz politics and money yo but my from my humble opinion Hollywood managed to make another cash grab by resurrecting storyline Frankenstein's monster style yet again. Not that the movie is prequel bad, just nothing new to see and no new story to tell.

Filled with cliche moments, plot holes, some things didn't make any absolute sense, too many sudden moments where characters meet up , the main "heroine" is a feminist propaganda mary-sue ,this is a FAIL of desperately trying to copy something from old movies but he copied the ENTIRE PLOT... JJ should be banned from producing anything in the future, he tried to mask our eyes with fancy WOW moments and cgi but that is all.. who gave this guy right to be a producer ? the whole movie industry is going slowly down the drain because of this, it's been like that for the past decade... 93% ? Most telling part of this movie: They forgot that C3PO has a silver leg. "Big Deal" you say. Well, yeah, so what? Just explain it away. He got a new one. He has a crazy Red Arm, anyway! So cool! Maybe he found a new, identical, C3PO droid leg. But wait a minute. We have to do that a lot in this movie. We have to make up our own plot explanations 20 or 30 times. OH, yeah.. that *could* have happened, whatever. A jawa trader just gave up a droid that's worth a fortune, sure, but he probably didn't know it was worth anything either. The bad guy took his mask off because some stupid smuggler pissed him off, sure. Princess Leia hugs Rey as if she's her long-lost daughter even though they've exchanged six words with each other. Poe and Fin are super duper best buddies even though right before they escaped, Poe pointed out that this guy is just a stormtrooper who wants to desert. But whatever, best friends now. We have to do that a lot, and it is annoying. Do all of the reviewers work for Disney? How does this have 8.5/10 rating?.There are two movies here. There's a really intriguing story about a girl who finds out that she has a deep, mysterious history that she never knew about, and rebel friends with a plan to bring freedom to a universe ruled by power and greed. And then there's a Hollywooded-out story where a bunch of characters that were almost really cool got left flat and the plot elements had to be resolved when the bad guy loses his super powers, the good guys suddenly gain unexplained super powers, and where the bad guy's base is really poorly defended and his minions easily beaten.I didn't hate it. Seriously. But it's hard not to hate the viral marketing (What's with those "No Spoilers!" memes ?? What is there to spoil? Are you afraid I'm going to tell my friends about the obvious plot holes?) This movie was sort of a cash grab. If it didn't have "Star Wars" all over it, it would be just another crappy Hollywood movie.The Plot Had Obvious ProblemsThe plot elements resolved themselves far too easily, and a lot of what happened did not make sense in the context of the Star Wars universe. One character's powers are "awakened" in the space of about twenty minutes - suddenly more powerful than other Jedi that have trained for years. The bad guy suddenly loses his powers for no reason. A janitor gives someone who is basically a kung-fu master a run for his money. The giant, quadzillion space-dollar space station has an obvious weakness and terrible network security, since its defenses can be deactivated by a random squad commander at a random, unguarded computer terminal. Wtf?There are dozens of moments that just don't make sense, which would have been *so easy* to just change slightly so the plot is a bit more intriguing. It all makes me think that the movie was named this just so they had a magical explanation for all of the ridiculously good luck that the heroes have.The Dialogue Fell Short -The lines seemed like they had been oversimplified to just a series of one-liners, which in most cases would make sense with just a bit more dialogue. The science and realism that could've easily been there, wasn't - it became clear that the writers don't respect the audience when they say "*the* sun" rather than "a star," or "this system's sun," or really, anything other than what they actually said, which sounded completely stupid. Another phrase I take issue with is "thermal oscillator." Semantically, that makes no sense. It would have been just as easy to say "thermal modulator." But, they didn't. And that upsets me.The plot is a bunch of recycled, generic Star Wars elements, yes. But, that said, it's hard to say what I would've been satisfied with. There is a lot that they could have messed up with this movie, or the next one.#1 Problem with the movie - The really cool, really intriguing bad guy takes off his mask. He apparently had gone through great pains to hide his face, and make the audience think he was awesome. In the first half of the movie, he's this awesome, violent masked character with a cool voice. In the second half of the movie, he's an insecure child whose force powers shut off by themselves for no reason. Ooh, I'm so scared.The point is, this movie could have been *so cool.* I think they should have gone with the plot that it's obvious they were trying to have. But somewhere along the lines, Hollywood happened to this movie and they decided to please the crowd by throwing all three of the previous episodes in a blender, and removing any really distinguishing plot elements from this film. Whatever. It was fun to watch, but nothing happened, and the real hero of the movie is a nameless X-ray pilot. On the surface, it looks really good, but I think that if you scratch the glass, this is a really generic Hollywood story with a bunch of Star Wars stickers on it.
Absolutely great! Daisy Ridley is a star in the making. A great foundation for the next saga.
The millenium falcon is the best thing in all the movie... Star Wars A new hope reboot

Jar Jar Abrhams has finally proved what the hardcore Star Wars fans thought wasn't possible. He made a movie so bad it makes Episode 1 look good. The movie is essentially a reboot of Episode 4. From a bigger deathstar (which the movie points our for you incase you weren't sure) to the death of a mentor which causes the main character to cry despite having met him only a few scenes earlier. This movie was bogus. Incase that isn't enough we even get a whinney tantrum throwing sith to enjoy. The humor was so randomly thrown in the movie that I wasn;t sure if I'm supposed to laugh or just stare awkwardly at the screen. They tried to make the Empire funny which made the movie even worse since the empire is supposed to be forboading and dangerous while the Rebellion tends to lean to more humanly charecteristics. As for the Rebellion they added it to this movie, but its called the "Resistance". They even have a bunker ust like in Episode 4 even though they won 30 years earlier. Theres not explenation as to why the Resistance isn't the Republic or as to why the Republic isn't helping the Resistance or why theres even a Resistance anyways. As for the "New Order" there isn't much explenation as to why it's around or why the REpublic lets it do it's thing and build massive planet sized Death Stars. I could go on and on, but if you're a hardcore fan and haven't seen this movie yet..don't waste 10 bucks on a ticket. Instead sit at home and watch A New Hope. Its the same thing anyways.

Ok, let's get this out of the way first: The new Star Wars movie does live up to the original trilogy. Besides that though, it also modernizes the franchise, while also being a hoot of an adventure movie for both newcomers and longtime fans. While the inclusion of familiar faces is sure to invigorate the audience, the best moments come from the new characters. Finn, Rey and Kylo Ren are all well-cast and instantly likable, and hopefully their back stories will be even more fleshed out in the sequels. Also, The Force Awakens is carried by a really tight script, and just like this year's Mad Max: Fury Road, it's jam-packed with action but still tells a story efficiently. Some emotional moments are a bit glossed over, and some story elements seem a bit too similar to the original Star Wars, but it's free of the annoying and childish tone that doomed the Star Wars prequels. Finally, Star Wars fans can sleep tight: Their signature series is back and with a brighter future than ever.

I thought Star Wars - The Force Awakens was terrible. They ruined the star wars franchise. Actors and acting was just atrocious. Story and plot was boring and not believable at all. I really don't like how it took Luke Skywalker three movies (including training by Yoda) before he could use/handle the force and defeat Darth Vader, but it takes this girl 14 seconds (with no training) to figure out and master all the nuances of the force and defeat the dark side/Kylo Ren. She went from scavenger/nobody to the ultimate jedi warrior in 14 seconds with no training. Just ridiculous and stupid. She is not believable as a hero/jedi saving the galaxy and Kylo Ren is not believable as the bad guy (new Darth Vader) - he's a wuss. I'm surprised they did not have him break down and cry and surrender to the girl. Terrible job as a villain. I won't bother going to see any more Star Wars movies now that Disney is doing them.

Episode 7 hat gute Effekte, gute Schauspieler, netten Humor, gutes Sezenenbild und ein paar coole Ideen. Das will ich nicht bestreiten. Aber leider fehlt dem Film in den Grundlagen des Filmemachens die Professionalit. Das Drehbuch ist uerst schwach geraten, obwohl gute Vorstze vorhanden sind. Das fngt bei der Grundlage an, dass im Grunde Episode 4 im greren Mastab mit ein bisschen Episode 3 fast identisch wiedergegeben wird, nur eben weniger dramatisch und spannend. Dem Zuschauer wird die Vorgeschichte der Personen und darin ihre Bewegrnde in einstzigen Unterhaltungen entgegengeworfen, so das keine Zeit bleibt, sich emotional in die Protagonisten und Antagonisten einzufhlen. Selbst der Hintergrund der beiden Hauptfiguren wird mit zwei Stzen abgehandelt. Was Solo, Leia und Luke in der Zwischenzeit getrieben haben, wird mit gefhlten 3 Silben behandelt und in hlzerne Gesprche gepresst. Es wird nicht einmal versucht sie realistisch wirken zu lassen. Man htte dem Film eine halbe Stunde mehr geben mssen, die mit guten Dialogen und Spannungsaufbau verbringen mssen, dann htte etwas daraus werden knnen. Aber dann htten sich da draussen wieder ein paar Jugendliche beschwert, weil es 10 Minuten lang zu keiner Explosion gekommen ist. Keylo Rens Absichten, warum er auf der dunklen Seite wandelt, werden nicht einmal genannt. Seine Herkunft wird ebenso mager erzhlt und als er spter sein Gesicht unter der Maske zeigt, fingen viele im Kinosaal unwillkrlich an zu lachen. Die Enthllung wirkt fast schon peinlich. Von der feinfhligen Entwicklung eines Anakin zum Darth Vader, trotz der damaligen Schchen in der Umsetzung, ist hier nicht das geringste zu spren. Und doch versucht man hier den emotionalen Inhalt von Episode 3 mit einzuarbeiten. Wer einen zweiten Darth Vader erwartet, kann lange warten. Man sieht hier eben auch deutlich die Handschrift von J.J. Abrams, der manchmal dazu neigt, das Drehbuch, was Dramatik und Substanz betrifft, nicht richtig auszureizen. Natrlich lag auf ihm ein unglaublicher Druck und Filmemachen ist nun ach nicht einfach. Aber das Interesse an ausgefeilten, emotionalen Drehbchern ist in den letzten Jahren stark gesunken. Wer vertrgt heute schon noch emotionale, nachdenklich machende Kost, wenn man auch schnelllebige, hirnausschalt-Kost haben kann. Doch so bleibt nichts, als ein schnell vergangenes Actionkino, das trotz dramatischem Inhalt, wie eine Runde "Avengers" vorbei geht und kein bisschen berhrt. George Lucas hat da ein besseres Hndchen gehabt. Die Magier seiner Filme, (auch wenn sie nicht perfekt waren und es ein paar Ausrutscher gab), dieser Kampf zwischen dunkler und heller Macht, war bei ihm viel sprbarer. Episode 7 hat Witz und ein paar gute Actionszenen. Aber ihm fehlt die Substanz um in Erinnerung zu bleiben und bemerkenswert zu sein.

WARNING! THE FOLLOWING CONTAINS MAJOR SPOILERS! There are rumors about how good this film is. They're true...all of them. The lack of lens flares....the characters...no midichlorian bullshit...all good. Though plot elements from the original trilogy are obviously used (Evil giant planet destroying death ball, old man death, opening on a desert planet) and we get more than enough nods to the original trilogy, it is done in a way all Star Wars fans would want and love. Fresh new batch of likable and interesting characters are introduced such as the stubborn, brave, tomboyish Rey, the badass pilot Poe, and the dude who is way in over his head, Finn. And we are also given the original characters we know and love. Han and Chewie are back and haven't changed a bit and Leia is back and her actress thankfully lost all that excess fat. Phew! Though I'm wondering if they put on too much make-up cuz she could barely make facial expressions. Kylo Ren is the antagonist we've been waiting for. Fans of the infamous Jacen Solo from the expanded universe will be pleased to know Kylo Ren's real name is Ben Solo. Many say Kylo Ren is an annoying whiny douchebag...well he kinda is, but isn't it better to have a bad guy like that. Rather than get a cliche pretty boy, we get a dopey, big eared, long faced, non-scary looking bad guy who actually looks scarier and more dangerous and even sounds better with the mask ON. This makes his obsession with Vader make more sense, as he wants to be as strong and dangerous as his late grandfather and thus has the Vader-ish mask. So this whiny wannabe is actually a great antagonist. As for the dark-colored female stormtropper...she didn't really do much so I'm hoping for more of her in the next film. Cuz she BORED me. Other issues include the galactic conflict? Instead of the First Order being the bad guys and the good guys being called the resistance...shouldnt the Resistance be the remains of the old empire trying to take over? And shouldn't Leia be leading the Republic's army to stop them from recreating the Empire? As for the map to Luke Skywalker....why is there a map? Who made it? Why did R2 have 90% of it? Who figured out the 10%? Leia was looking for him so was the map some kind of process of elimination thing? Calculated deduction? As a whole this movie is GREAT! Emotion! Action! Characters! Music! EVERYTHING! It makes you want MORE!One last question....WTF is Kylo Ren's uniform made of?! It looks like a plain cloak! And we was taken all those lightsaber blows like it was nothing. I'm assuming he has a layer of Mandalorian steel or something cuz...wow...that would hurt A LOT. Force Awakens gets a 5/5...barely.

As I was watching the movie, I enjoyed it. J.J. Abrams recaptures the tone, music, and effects of the original movie. Too bad it doesn't have an original bone in its body, except the Kylo Ren subplot. Hopefully the other two sequels have the balls to be more original.

It's GOOD, but its also damn frustrating and leaves me with many questions about where this going to go. SLIGHT SPOILERS ahead.... Ready? I just feel, in the end, the Resistance seems to have everything going their way, They've got Dapper Finn, the mysterious Rey, who's Force comes on like magic, and the (presumably) returning Skywalker. For the Dark side, we don't have any mega bad guys it seems. There are two would-be leaders who are forever squabbling to their shadowly overlord (who will probably turn out to be a midget who's broadcast to look 3 stories tall), Kylo Ren, quite menacing at the beginning, is made to look terribly weak in the end. And why that STUPID MASK? So yes, I have issues. Great action sequences though.
story line weak... A Sanitation guy and a scavenger take on highly trained army's. The scavenger develops the force out of thin air..lol Solo dies? Vader dies? Luke has no lines? so disappointing....

Completely unoriginal retread of a New Hope. right down to droids with stolen plans, a new Deathstar & rolling panoramic shots of key characters wandering through the desert. What they got right; Chewbacca, Han , Poe Dameron and the ensuing space combat. What they got wrong; At no times do we see the original cast together, which was the main strength of the original trilogy, Hans death was very anti climatic, NO LANDO..yet they managed to squeeze in Admiral Ackbar, Kylo Ren is nothing more than a emo goth kid going through a phase - he's not very intimidating. I'm more interested in where they are going with this re-warmed storyline. On it's own, this movie isn't very good..but it's part of an over-arcing plot one I hope is just finding it's footing.

A dead rip off of the original movie, Episode 4. From the crappy looking infinity CG roll opening sequence, bar scene and light sabre fights to a janitor identifying a weakness in the battle star, this movie is chock full of inside jokes and tired ideas. The only redeeming grace for this movie is a solid performance by Harrison Ford as Han Solo and a compelling performance by Daisy Ridley as Rey who represents the resurrection of the Jedi. Fun to watch and full of action, but there are numerous dead spots and far too much nod to the Star Wars wonks of yesteryear.

This was the most "UNDERWHELMING" of the Star Wars series. There were no new items (light saber, light speed transition, new civilizations,etc.). Although 40 years had passed both sides were using the exact same fighters - Disney couldn't even be bothered with new models. The new robot and the little woman at the bar were "little kid" cute, and belong in WallE, not Star Wars. Disney was definitely not up to this task.
Only down side at the moment is that watching it feels like a lifetime ago so probably will be watching it again soon

Well, that was fun. Abrams has really gone whole hog to please us ageing fans of the old films, and the plot was sometimes a bit too much like that of A New Hope.Still, it was fun, and that's all that matters. I'm guessing it's going to take a while for the fans to sort through all the layers of allusions back to the old series, but the story also lays the ground for a continuation that just might work. Not a masterpiece, but a satisfying continuation of the whole Star wars mythology.

El episodio nmero VII de la saga de "Star Wars", el universo creado por George Lucas e inspirado en los seriales de ciencia ficcin de los aos 40 y 50, est en buenas manos con los estudios Disney. El director J.J. Abrams, creador de la serie "Lost" y responsable de la resurreccin de la franquicia de "Star Trek", logra hacernos olvidar de las desastrosas precuelas dirigidas por Lucas a comienzos de la dcada del 2000 y vuelve a darle a "Star Wars" la energa, el sentido del asombro, la emocin y la diversin de la saga original. La estructura del guin escrito por Abrams y Lawrence Kasdan (antiguo colaborador de Lucas) copia prcticamente la estructura base de la pelcula original de 1977, pero la adorna con muchos elementos nuevos y sorpresas que no se vean venir. Han-Solo, la Princesa Leia, C-3PO, R2D2, Chewbacca e inclusive Luke Skywalker vuelven en esta entrega que se desarrolla 30 aos despus de los sucesos ocurridos en "The Return Of The Jedi", pero ahora estn acompaados de nuevos y grandiosos personajes: un carismtico robot llamado BB8, un stormtroopper renegado llamado Finn (un slido John Boyega de "Attack The Block"), una misteriosa chica solitaria llamada Rey (una tambin slida Daisy Ridley), un valiente y bondadoso piloto llamdo Poe (Oscar Isaac de "Inside Llewin Davis") y unos odiosos y misteriosos villanos llamados Kylo Ren (un potente Adam Driver) y el Lder Supremo Snoke (un malvado e imponente Andy Serkis). Estos nuevos personajes llegaron para quedarse y si los siguientes episodios de "Star Wars" planeados por Disney son as de buenos, me tendrn comprando las boletas por anticipado.

Although this is not a perfect film, it somehow exceeds the immeasurable expectations from the fans and hits every aspect of a great movie perfectly. The nostalgia from the original series, the chemistry between the characters, old and new, the break-neck speed of the plot, the sense of humor, the special and practical effects, everything.J. J. Abrams handled every puzzle pieces carefully and formed a new intricate world of Star Wars. The movie felt like it had given everything but leaves a lot more questions for the sequels.Star Wars: The Force Awakens is a dream come true for all the fans of the franchise. Truly, Star Wars is again back on its feet.

A strong return of the Star Wars franchise

I am not a Star Wars fan. Or at least I wasn't until this past weekend when I watched Stars Wars: The Force Awakensand fell in deep cosmic like. As a fan of romantic comedies and Oprah recommended films that tug at heart strings and make you cry, this most recent story, directed by J.J. Abrams,has won me over and I now anticipate the next installment.Yes, it was that good.This film is what Star Wars enthusiasts and super fans would call, "strong with the force." Why? Well, because as a novice to the franchise, I was never lost in a web of characters or plot subjects that needed over explaining in gap filling montages or flashbacks that would go over my head if I was not a previous viewer. Though a flashback did occur, it was executed in such a fashion that I didn't need my all knowing Star Wars encyclopedia of a brother to explain. Plus the cinematography is beautiful, wide shots are amazing, close-ups are meaningful, and the subtle pauses gives you time to take in the scenery that lingers on the perimeters of your mind as you continue to enjoy in awe and wonder.For all of my fashion and beauty gurus, Princess Leia, who is now General Leia, has a new twist on her cinnamon bun up-do, and to satisfy my yearning for romantic connections, Han Solo is still in love with the princess who inspired a thousand up-dos. General Leia still looks at Han with a, "come hither gaze," and all I wantedthem to do was to run off into the galaxy together and spoon in a space pod far far away, but alas the galaxy must be saved, and the Princess, I mean General Leia must send her love off into battle and save their son from the dark side. I have revealed too much.The blockbuster is filmed with themes of bravery, betrayal, internal conflict and self realization. Without giving too much away to those still waiting to go see the movie, a number of key characters have similar internal struggles: questioning where they belong, wondering if they are on the right path, many are being haunted by their pasts, and what is most interesting is that they are challenging galactic norms and departing from what is expected. Star Wars: The Force Awakens,is well written so that you don't have to be a sci-fi junkie to enjoy the drama, comedy, romance, tech and effects of the film. It satisfies the theatrical palette. It did not disappoint.Should you go see the movie? Yes, you should.

Really liked it. It was way better than episodes 1, 2, and 3. Fun to see Han Solo, Princess Leia and Luke Skywalker again. Also nice to have a female heroine. I'm looking forward to the next installment.
Nice movie, nice actors. I'm not a fan of this Saga, but i think that it could be a very nice begining of a new trilogy. Characters like Rey, Finn, Kylo and Poe will have a interesting growth.

The first hour of the film was interesting as it introduced us to the new generation of characters. Towards the end of this first hour though it becomes apparent that these aren't actually new characters at all, they are just the same characters from A New Hope, re-cycled with new actors & actresses and given new names. Once this becomes apparent, it is obvious that we are not watching a new film at all, but instead just a re-make of A New Hope. Therefore, the rest of the film is just spent watching happen, what you already know will happen.Yes of course it's got more bells and whistles, and the CGI means they can do fancier things, but we are just watching the exact same film. Those of us who were around to watch the original will not find anything new here to excite us, and new fans to the series will think it's a great film which inexplicably has some OAP's in.I don't really see any point in watching this film if you have already seen the original. And if you haven't seen the original, then watch that instead, it's better, funnier and doesn't have a Pound Shop Darth Vader for a villain.Having said all that of course it's still better than the prequels, so whilst Star Wars is in slightly better hands than it was when Lucas had it, if Disney are only going to re-cycle the same plot, almost scene for scene, then I won't get my hopes up too much for Episodes 8 & 9.

Amazing movie with a great balance between humor and action

The Force Awakens is one of the best Star Wars films in the saga. It borrows certain elements from the original trilogy, which they carry out smoothly enough, but some might still have a problem with it. The acting is great for the most part, the newer characters are fascinating, even though new villains still need to be developed a bit more. The effects are by far the best in the whole saga, which is to be excpected. The mixture between practical effects and CGI is great and help the film a lot. J.J. Abrams did an amazing job bringing people back home to the Star Wars universe, it's a film both the originals and prequels fans can join in together to love.

Movie was entertaining followed the standard hero journey and for loyal fans of the original movies a lot of similarities. I you were hoping for a reboot similar to what Abrams did with Star Trek you will be disappointed. This is more like the comfort of a familiar old blanket on a cold night. The new characters do not have much depth yet but you must remember that with the original characters there has been almost 40 years of backstory development in the various books. My biggest complaint that in an effort to create a strong female character they may have gone too far...Rey is Wesley Crusher the only person in the entire movie that is capable of anything. Need a starship fixed call Rey, Need a super Pilot call Rey, need a Jedi master in light sabres...Rey. I understand natural talent can overcome experience but if the first time she picks up a light saber in the woods she can be a Sith Apprentice with not much effort then it removes all suspense as the villian is so weak that what happens when she gets training. There is a nice three short story book that gives some background on the characters and Finn was a super skilled stormtrooper with a conscious unfortunately in the movie he is more of a bungling comic relief side kick. Again I realize that this is so Rey can be the ONLY hero in the story. I hope the second movie deviates from Empire strikes back and we do not get Luke as Yoda, some major battle with the First Order winning and one of our sidekicks put into stasis, suspense reveal of Rey's parents) The movie has introduced some good new characters it just needs to use them to tell a better story going forward. They need to make the villains more menacing Capt. Plasma was a disappointment and Kylo seemed more like a teen angst character from a Twilight movie than the successor to Darth Vader.

Couldn't describe the excitement during the beginning of the film when the theme and that classic title shows up! Screaming so hard inside of me. Everything are as impressive especially the graphics. Though, I personally think the nostalgic element there is real and that sort of brings every of the emotions out of people and enjoy it in many different ways. Overall, this is a really powerful piece of art that allows people to be amaze again by the magic it.
